built with pdoc

prosodic.lib.lexconvert

lexconvert v0.301 - convert phonemes between different speech synthesizers etc (c) 2007-19 Silas S. Brown. License: GPL

   1#!/usr/bin/env python
   2# May be run with either Python 2 or Python 3
   3
   4"""lexconvert v0.301 - convert phonemes between different speech synthesizers etc
   5(c) 2007-19 Silas S. Brown.  License: GPL"""
   6
   7# Run without arguments for usage information
   8
   9#    This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify
  10#    it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
  11#    the Free Software Foundation; either version 3 of the License, or
  12#    (at your option) any later version.
  13#
  14#    This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
  15#    but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
  16#    MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the
  17#    GNU General Public License for more details.
  18
  19# Old versions of this code are being kept in the E-GuideDog SVN repository at
  20# http://svn.code.sf.net/p/e-guidedog/code/ssb22/lexconvert
  21# and on GitHub at https://github.com/ssb22/lexconvert
  22# and on GitLab at https://gitlab.com/ssb22/lexconvert
  23# and on Bitbucket https://bitbucket.org/ssb22/lexconvert
  24# although some early ones are missing.
  25
  26def Phonemes():
  27   """Create phonemes by calling vowel(), consonant(),
  28     variant() and other().
  29   
  30     For the variants, if a particular variant does not
  31     exist in the destination format then we will treat it
  32     as equivalent to the last non-variant we created.
  33  
  34     For anything else that does not exist in the
  35     destination format, we will first try to break the
  36     source's phoneme into parts (e.g. see the treatment
  37     of opt_ol_as_in_gold by eSpeak and bbcmicro), and if
  38     that still doesn't work then we drop a character
  39     (warning depending on the source format's setting of
  40     safe_to_drop_characters).  makeDic does however warn
  41     about any non-variant consonants, or non-variant
  42     vowels that weren't marked optional, missing from a
  43     format. """
  44   a_as_in_ah = vowel()
  45   _, var1_a_as_in_ah = variant()
  46   _, var3_a_as_in_ah = variant()
  47   _, var4_a_as_in_ah = variant()
  48   _, var5_a_as_in_ah = variant()
  49   a_as_in_apple = vowel()
  50   u_as_in_but = vowel() # or the first part of un as in hunt
  51   _, var1_u_as_in_but = variant()
  52   o_as_in_orange = vowel()
  53   _, var1_o_as_in_orange = variant()
  54   _, var2_o_as_in_orange = variant()
  55   o_as_in_now = vowel()
  56   _, var1_o_as_in_now = variant()
  57   a_as_in_ago = vowel()
  58   _, var1_a_as_in_ago = variant()
  59   e_as_in_herd = vowel()
  60   _, ar_as_in_year = variant()
  61   eye = vowel()
  62   _, var1_eye = variant()
  63   b = consonant()
  64   ch = consonant()
  65   d = consonant()
  66   th_as_in_them = consonant()
  67   e_as_in_them = vowel()
  68   _, var1_e_as_in_them = variant()
  69   a_as_in_air = vowel()
  70   _, var1_a_as_in_air = variant()
  71   _, var2_a_as_in_air = variant()
  72   _, var3_a_as_in_air = variant()
  73   _, var4_a_as_in_air = variant()
  74   a_as_in_ate = vowel()
  75   _, var1_a_as_in_ate = variant()
  76   f = consonant()
  77   g = consonant()
  78   h = consonant()
  79   i_as_in_it = vowel()
  80   _, var1_i_as_in_it = variant()
  81   _, var2_i_as_in_it = variant()
  82   ear = vowel()
  83   _, var1_ear = variant()
  84   _, var2_ear = variant()
  85   e_as_in_eat = vowel()
  86   _, var1_e_as_in_eat = variant()
  87   j_as_in_jump = consonant()
  88   k = consonant()
  89   _, opt_scottish_loch = variant()
  90   l = consonant()
  91   _, var1_l = variant()
  92   m = consonant()
  93   n = consonant()
  94   ng = consonant()
  95   o_as_in_go = vowel()
  96   _, var1_o_as_in_go = variant()
  97   _, var2_o_as_in_go = variant()
  98   opt_ol_as_in_gold = opt_vowel() # see eSpeak / bbcmicro
  99   oy_as_in_toy = vowel()
 100   _, var1_oy_as_in_toy = variant()
 101   p = consonant()
 102   r = consonant()
 103   _, var1_r = variant()
 104   s = consonant()
 105   sh = consonant()
 106   t = consonant()
 107   _, var1_t = variant()
 108   th_as_in_think = consonant()
 109   oor_as_in_poor = vowel()
 110   _, var1_oor_as_in_poor = variant()
 111   _, opt_u_as_in_pull = variant()
 112   opt_ul_as_in_pull = opt_vowel() # see eSpeak / bbcmicro
 113   oo_as_in_food = vowel()
 114   _, var1_oo_as_in_food = variant()
 115   _, var2_oo_as_in_food = variant()
 116   close_to_or = vowel()
 117   _, var1_close_to_or = variant()
 118   _, var2_close_to_or = variant()
 119   _, var3_close_to_or = variant()
 120   v = consonant()
 121   w = consonant()
 122   _, var1_w = variant()
 123   y = consonant()
 124   z = consonant()
 125   ge_of_blige_etc = consonant()
 126   glottal_stop = other()
 127   syllable_separator = other()
 128   _, primary_stress = variant()
 129   _, secondary_stress = variant()
 130   text_sharp = other()
 131   text_underline = other()
 132   text_question = other()
 133   text_exclamation = other()
 134   text_comma = other()
 135   ipa_colon = other() # for catching missed cases
 136   del _ ; return locals()
 137
 138def LexFormats():
 139  """Makes the phoneme conversion tables of each format.
 140     Each table has string to phoneme entries and phoneme
 141     to string entries.  The string to phoneme entries are
 142     used when converting OUT of that format, and the
 143     phoneme to string entries are used when converting IN
 144     (so you can recognise phonemes you don't support and
 145     convert them to something else).  By default, a tuple
 146     of the form (string,phoneme) will create entries in
 147     BOTH directions; one-directional entries are created
 148     via (string,phoneme,False) or (phoneme,string,False).
 149     The makeDic function checks the keys are unique.
 150     
 151     First parameter is always a description of the
 152     format, then come the phoneme entries as described
 153     above, then any additional settings:
 154
 155       stress_comes_before_vowel (default False means any
 156       stress mark goes AFTER the affected vowel; set to
 157       True if the format requires stress placed before)
 158
 159       word_separator (default same as phoneme_separator)
 160       phoneme_separator (default " ")
 161       clause_separator (default newline)
 162
 163       (For a special case, clause_separator can also be
 164        set to a function.  If that happens, the function
 165        will be called whenever lexconvert needs to output
 166        a list of (lists of words) in this format.  See
 167        bbcmicro for an example function clause_separator)
 168
 169       safe_to_drop_characters (default False, can be a
 170       string of safe characters or True = all; controls
 171       warnings when unrecognised characters are found)
 172
 173       approximate_missing (default False) - if True,
 174       makeDic will attempt to compensate for missing
 175       phonemes by approximating them to others, instead of
 176       warning about them.  This is useful for American codes
 177       that can't cope with all the British English phonemes.
 178       (Approximation is done automatically anyway in the
 179       case of variant phonemes; approximate_missing adds in
 180       some additional approximations - see comments in code)
 181
 182       cleanup_regexps (default none) - optional list of
 183       (search,replace) regular expressions to "clean up"
 184       after converting each word INTO this format
 185       cleanup_func (default none) - optional special-case
 186       function to pass result through after cleanup_regexps
 187
 188       cvtOut_regexps (default none) - optional list of
 189       (search,replace) regular expressions to "clean up"
 190       before starting to convert OUT of this format
 191       cvtOut_func (default none) - optional special-case
 192       function to pass through before any cvtOut_regexps
 193  
 194       inline_format (default "%s") the format string for
 195       printing a word with --phones or --phones2phones
 196       (can be used to put markup around each word)
 197       (can also be a function taking the phonetic word
 198        and returning the resulting string, e.g. bbcmicro)
 199
 200       output_is_binary (default False) - True if the output
 201       is almost certainly unsuitable for a terminal; will
 202       cause lexconvert to refuse to print phonemes unless
 203       its standard output is redirected to a file or pipe
 204       (affects the --phones and --phones2phones options)
 205
 206       inline_header (default none) text to print first
 207         when outputting from --phones or --phones2phones
 208       inline_footer (default none) text to print last
 209       inline_oneoff_header (default none) text to print
 210         before inline_header on the first time only
 211
 212       lex_filename - filename of a lexicon file.  If this
 213       is not specified, there is no support for writing a
 214       lexicon in this format: there can still be READ
 215       support if you define lex_read_function to open the
 216       lexicon by itself, but otherwise the format can be
 217       used only with --phones and --phones2phones.
 218
 219       lex_entry_format - format string for writing each
 220       (word, pronunciation) entry to the lexicon file.
 221       This is also needed for lexicon-write support.
 222
 223       lex_header, lex_footer - optional strings to write
 224       at the beginning and at the end of the lexicon file
 225       (can also be functions that take the open file as a
 226        parameter, e.g. for bbcmicro; lex_footer is
 227        allowed to close the file if it needs to do
 228        something with it afterwards)
 229
 230       lex_word_case - optional "upper" or "lower" to
 231       force a particular case for lexicon words (not
 232       pronunciations - they're determined by the table).
 233       The default is to allow words to be in either case.
 234
 235       lex_type (default "") - used by the --formats
 236       option when summarising the support for each format
 237
 238       lex_read_function - Python function to READ the
 239       lexicon file and return a (word,phonemes) list.
 240       If this is not specified, there's no read support
 241       for lexicons in this format (but there can still be
 242       write support - see above - and you can still use
 243       --phones and --phones2phones).  If lex_filename is
 244       specified then this function will be given the open
 245       file as a parameter. """
 246  
 247  phonemes = Phonemes() ; globals().update(phonemes)
 248  return { "festival" : makeDic(
 249    "Festival's British voice",
 250    ('0',syllable_separator),
 251    ('1',primary_stress),
 252    ('2',secondary_stress),
 253    ('aa',a_as_in_ah),
 254    ('a',a_as_in_apple),
 255    ('uh',u_as_in_but),
 256    ('o',o_as_in_orange),
 257    ('au',o_as_in_now),
 258    ('@',a_as_in_ago),
 259    ('@@',e_as_in_herd),
 260    ('ai',eye),
 261    ('b',b),
 262    ('ch',ch),
 263    ('d',d),
 264    ('dh',th_as_in_them),
 265    ('e',e_as_in_them),
 266    (ar_as_in_year,'@@',False),
 267    ('e@',a_as_in_air),
 268    ('ei',a_as_in_ate),
 269    ('f',f),
 270    ('g',g),
 271    ('h',h),
 272    ('i',i_as_in_it),
 273    ('i@',ear),
 274    ('ii',e_as_in_eat),
 275    ('jh',j_as_in_jump),
 276    ('k',k),
 277    ('l',l),
 278    ('m',m),
 279    ('n',n),
 280    ('ng',ng),
 281    ('ou',o_as_in_go),
 282    ('oi',oy_as_in_toy),
 283    ('p',p),
 284    ('r',r),
 285    ('s',s),
 286    ('sh',sh),
 287    ('t',t),
 288    ('th',th_as_in_think),
 289    ('u@',oor_as_in_poor),
 290    ('u',opt_u_as_in_pull),
 291    ('uu',oo_as_in_food),
 292    ('oo',close_to_or),
 293    ('v',v),
 294    ('w',w),
 295    ('y',y),
 296    ('z',z),
 297    ('zh',ge_of_blige_etc),
 298    lex_filename=ifset("HOME",os.environ.get("HOME","")+os.sep)+".festivalrc",
 299    lex_entry_format="(lex.add.entry '( \"%s\" n %s))\n",
 300    lex_header=";; -*- mode: lisp -*-\n(eval (list voice_default))\n",
 301    lex_read_function = lambda *args:eval('['+getoutput("grep -vi parameter.set < ~/.festivalrc | grep -v '(eval' | sed -e 's/;.*//' -e 's/.lex.add.entry//' -e s/\"'\"'[(] *\"/[\"/' -e 's/\" [^ ]* /\",(\"/' -e 's/\".*$/&\"],/' -e 's/[()]/ /g' -e 's/  */ /g'")+']'),
 302    safe_to_drop_characters=True, # TODO: really? (could instead give a string of known-safe characters)
 303    cleanup_func = festival_group_stress,
 304  ),
 305
 306  "example" : makeVariantDic(
 307    "A small built-in example lexicon for testing when you don't have your full custom lexicon to hand.  Use --convert to write it in one of the other formats and see if a synth can import it.",
 308    lex_read_function = lambda *args: [
 309       ("Shadrach","shei1drak"),
 310       ("Meshach","mii1shak"),
 311       ("Abednego","@be1dniigou"),
 312    ], cleanup_func = None,
 313    lex_filename=None, lex_entry_format=None, noInherit=True),
 314
 315  "festival-cmu" : makeVariantDic(
 316    "American CMU version of Festival",
 317    ('ae',a_as_in_apple),
 318    ('ah',u_as_in_but),
 319    ('ax',a_as_in_ago),
 320    (o_as_in_orange,'aa',False),
 321    ('aw',o_as_in_now),
 322    ('er',e_as_in_herd), # TODO: check this one
 323    ('ay',eye),
 324    ('eh',e_as_in_them),
 325    (ar_as_in_year,'er',False),
 326    (a_as_in_air,'er',False),
 327    ('ey',a_as_in_ate),
 328    ('hh',h),
 329    ('ih',i_as_in_it),
 330    ('ey ah',ear),
 331    ('iy',e_as_in_eat),
 332    ('ow',o_as_in_go),
 333    ('oy',oy_as_in_toy),
 334    ('uh',oor_as_in_poor),
 335    ('uw',oo_as_in_food),
 336    ('ao',close_to_or),
 337  ),
 338
 339  "espeak" : makeDic(
 340    "eSpeak's default British voice", # but eSpeak's phoneme representation isn't always that simple, hence the regexps at the end
 341    ('%',syllable_separator),
 342    ("'",primary_stress),
 343    (',',secondary_stress),
 344    # TODO: glottal_stop? (in regional pronunciations etc)
 345    ('A:',a_as_in_ah),
 346    ('A@',a_as_in_ah,False),
 347    ('A',var1_a_as_in_ah),
 348    ('a',a_as_in_apple),
 349    ('aa',a_as_in_apple,False),
 350    ('a2',a_as_in_apple,False), # TODO: this is actually an a_as_in_apple variant in espeak; festival @1 is not in mrpa PhoneSet
 351    ('&',a_as_in_apple,False),
 352    ('V',u_as_in_but),
 353    ('0',o_as_in_orange),
 354    ('aU',o_as_in_now),
 355    ('@',a_as_in_ago),
 356    ('a#',a_as_in_ago,False), # (TODO: eSpeak sometimes uses a# in 'had' when in a sentence, and this doesn't always sound good on other synths; might sometimes want to convert it to a_as_in_apple; not sure what contexts would call for this though)
 357    ('3:',e_as_in_herd),
 358    ('3',var1_a_as_in_ago),
 359    ('@2',a_as_in_ago,False),
 360    ('@-',a_as_in_ago,False), # (eSpeak @- sounds to me like a shorter version of @, TODO: double-check the relationship between @ and @2 in Festival)
 361    ('aI',eye),
 362    ('aI2',eye,False),
 363    ('aI;',eye,False),
 364    ('aI2;',eye,False),
 365    ('b',b),
 366    ('tS',ch),
 367    ('d',d),
 368    ('D',th_as_in_them),
 369    ('E',e_as_in_them),
 370    (ar_as_in_year,'3:',False),
 371    ('e@',a_as_in_air),
 372    ('eI',a_as_in_ate),
 373    ('f',f),
 374    ('g',g),
 375    ('h',h),
 376    ('I',i_as_in_it),
 377    ('I;',i_as_in_it,False),
 378    ('i',i_as_in_it,False),
 379    ('I2',var2_i_as_in_it,False),
 380    ('I2;',var2_i_as_in_it,False),
 381    ('i@',ear),
 382    ('i@3',var2_ear),
 383    ('i:',e_as_in_eat),
 384    ('i:;',e_as_in_eat,False),
 385    ('dZ',j_as_in_jump),
 386    ('k',k),
 387    ('x',opt_scottish_loch),
 388    ('l',l),
 389    ('L',l,False),
 390    ('m',m),
 391    ('n',n),
 392    ('N',ng),
 393    ('oU',o_as_in_go),
 394    ('oUl',opt_ol_as_in_gold), # (espeak says "gold" in a slightly 'posh' way though) (if dest format doesn't have opt_ol_as_in_gold, it'll get o_as_in_go + the l)
 395    ('OI',oy_as_in_toy),
 396    ('p',p),
 397    ('r',r),
 398    ('r-',r,False),
 399    ('s',s),
 400    ('S',sh),
 401    ('t',t),
 402    ('T',th_as_in_think),
 403    ('U@',oor_as_in_poor),
 404    ('U',opt_u_as_in_pull),
 405    ('@5',opt_u_as_in_pull,False),
 406    ('Ul',opt_ul_as_in_pull), # if dest format doesn't have this, it'll get opt_u_as_in_pull from the U, then the l
 407    ('u:',oo_as_in_food),
 408    ('O:',close_to_or),
 409    ('O@',var3_close_to_or),
 410    ('o@',var3_close_to_or,False),
 411    ('O',var3_close_to_or,False),
 412    ('v',v),
 413    ('w',w),
 414    ('j',y),
 415    ('z',z),
 416    ('Z',ge_of_blige_etc),
 417    lex_filename = "en_extra",
 418    lex_entry_format = "%s %s\n",
 419    lex_read_function = lambda lexfile: [x for x in [l.split()[:2] for l in lexfile.readlines()] if len(x)==2 and not '//' in x[0]],
 420    lex_footer=lambda f:(f.close(),os.system("espeak --compile=en")), # see also a bit of special-case code in mainopt_convert
 421    inline_format = "[[%s]]",
 422    word_separator=" ",phoneme_separator="",
 423    stress_comes_before_vowel=True,
 424    safe_to_drop_characters="_: !",
 425    cleanup_regexps=[
 426      ("k'a2n","k'@n"),
 427      ("ka2n","k@n"),
 428      ("gg","g"),
 429      ("@U","oU"), # (eSpeak uses oU to represent @U; difference is given by its accent parameters)
 430      ("([iU]|([AO]:))@r$","\1@"),
 431      ("([^e])@r",r"\1_remove_3"),("_remove_",""),
 432      # (r"([^iU]@)l",r"\1L") # only in older versions of espeak (not valid in more recent versions)
 433      ("rr$","r"),
 434      ("3:r$","3:"),
 435      ("%%+","%"),("^%",""),("%$",""),
 436      # TODO: 'declared' & 'declare' the 'r' after the 'E' sounds a bit 'regional' (but pretty).  but sounds incomplete w/out 'r', and there doesn't seem to be an E2 or E@
 437      # TODO: consider adding 'g' to words ending in 'N' (if want the 'g' pronounced in '-ng' words) (however, careful of words like 'yankee' where the 'g' would be followed by a 'k'; this may also be a problem going into the next word)
 438    ],
 439     cvtOut_regexps = [
 440       ("e@r$","e@"), ("e@r([bdDfghklmnNprsStTvwjzZ])",r"e@\1"), # because the 'r' is implicit in other synths (but DO have it if there's another vowel to follow)
 441     ],
 442  ),
 443
 444  "sapi" : makeDic(
 445    "Microsoft Speech API (American English)",
 446    ('-',syllable_separator),
 447    ('1',primary_stress),
 448    ('2',secondary_stress),
 449    ('aa',a_as_in_ah),
 450    ('ae',a_as_in_apple),
 451    ('ah',u_as_in_but),
 452    ('ao',o_as_in_orange),
 453    ('aw',o_as_in_now),
 454    ('ax',a_as_in_ago),
 455    ('er',e_as_in_herd),
 456    ('ay',eye),
 457    ('b',b),
 458    ('ch',ch),
 459    ('d',d),
 460    ('dh',th_as_in_them),
 461    ('eh',e_as_in_them),
 462    ('ey',var1_e_as_in_them),
 463    (a_as_in_ate,'ey',False),
 464    ('f',f),
 465    ('g',g),
 466    ('h',h), # Jan suggested 'hh', but I can't get this to work on Windows XP (TODO: try newer versions of Windows)
 467    ('ih',i_as_in_it),
 468    ('iy',e_as_in_eat),
 469    ('jh',j_as_in_jump),
 470    ('k',k),
 471    ('l',l),
 472    ('m',m),
 473    ('n',n),
 474    ('ng',ng),
 475    ('ow',o_as_in_go),
 476    ('oy',oy_as_in_toy),
 477    ('p',p),
 478    ('r',r),
 479    ('s',s),
 480    ('sh',sh),
 481    ('t',t),
 482    ('th',th_as_in_think),
 483    ('uh',oor_as_in_poor),
 484    ('uw',oo_as_in_food),
 485    ('AO',close_to_or),
 486    ('v',v),
 487    ('w',w),
 488    # ('x',var1_w), # suggested by Jan, but I can't get this to work on Windows XP (TODO: try newer versions of Windows)
 489    ('y',y),
 490    ('z',z),
 491    ('zh',ge_of_blige_etc),
 492    approximate_missing=True,
 493    lex_filename="run-ptts.bat", # write-only for now
 494    lex_header = "rem  You have to run this file\nrem  with ptts.exe in the same directory\nrem  to add these words to the SAPI lexicon\n\n",
 495    lex_entry_format='ptts -la %s "%s"\n',
 496    inline_format = '<pron sym="%s"/>',
 497    safe_to_drop_characters=True, # TODO: really?
 498  ),

 555  "mac" : makeDic(
 556    "approximation in American English using the [[inpt PHON]] notation of Apple's US voices",
 557    ('=',syllable_separator),
 558    ('1',primary_stress),
 559    ('2',secondary_stress),
 560    ('AA',a_as_in_ah),
 561    ('aa',var5_a_as_in_ah),
 562    ('AE',a_as_in_apple),
 563    ('UX',u_as_in_but),
 564    (o_as_in_orange,'AA',False),
 565    ('AW',o_as_in_now),
 566    ('AX',a_as_in_ago),
 567    (e_as_in_herd,'AX',False), # TODO: is this really the best approximation?
 568    ('AY',eye),
 569    ('b',b),
 570    ('C',ch),
 571    ('d',d),
 572    ('D',th_as_in_them),
 573    ('EH',e_as_in_them),
 574    ('EY',a_as_in_ate),
 575    ('f',f),
 576    ('g',g),
 577    ('h',h),
 578    ('IH',i_as_in_it),
 579    ('IX',var2_i_as_in_it),
 580    ('IY',e_as_in_eat),
 581    ('J',j_as_in_jump),
 582    ('k',k),
 583    ('l',l),
 584    ('m',m),
 585    ('n',n),
 586    ('N',ng),
 587    ('OW',o_as_in_go),
 588    ('OY',oy_as_in_toy),
 589    ('p',p),
 590    ('r',r),
 591    ('s',s),
 592    ('S',sh),
 593    ('t',t),
 594    ('T',th_as_in_think),
 595    ('UH',oor_as_in_poor),
 596    ('UW',oo_as_in_food),
 597    ('AO',close_to_or),
 598    ('v',v),
 599    ('w',w),
 600    ('y',y),
 601    ('z',z),
 602    ('Z',ge_of_blige_etc),
 603    approximate_missing=True,
 604    lex_filename="substitute.sh", # write-only for now
 605    lex_type = "substitution script",
 606    lex_header = "#!/bin/bash\n\n# I don't yet know how to add to the Apple US lexicon,\n# so here is a 'sed' command you can run on your text\n# to put the pronunciation inline:\n\nsed -E -e :S \\\n",
 607    lex_entry_format=r" -e 's/(^|[^A-Za-z])%s($|[^A-Za-z[12=])/\1[[inpt PHON]]%s[[inpt TEXT]]\2/g'"+" \\\n",
 608    # but /g is non-overlapping matches and won't catch 2 words in the lex right next to each other with only one non-alpha in between, so we put :S at start and tS at end to make the whole operation repeat until it hasn't done any more substitutions (hence also the exclusion of [, 1, 2 or = following a word so it doesn't try to substitute stuff inside the phonemes; TODO: assert the lexicon does not contain "inpt", "PHON" or "TEXT")
 609    lex_footer = lambda f:(f.write(" -e tS\n"),f.close(),os.chmod("substitute.sh",493)), # 493 = 0755, but no way to specify octal that works on both Python 2.5 and Python 3 (0o works on 2.6+)
 610    inline_format = "[[inpt PHON]]%s[[inpt TEXT]]",
 611    word_separator=" ",phoneme_separator="",
 612    safe_to_drop_characters=True, # TODO: really?
 613  ),
 614

 801  "android-pico" : makeVariantDic(
 802    'X-SAMPA phonemes for the default \"Pico\" voice in Android (1.6+, American), wrapped in Java code', # you could put en-GB instead of en-US, but it must be installed on the phone
 803    ('A:',a_as_in_ah), # won't sound without the :
 804    (var5_a_as_in_ah,'A:',False), # a: won't sound
 805    ('@U:',o_as_in_go),
 806    ('I',var1_i_as_in_it), # '1' won't sound
 807    ('i:',e_as_in_eat), # 'i' won't sound
 808    ('u:',oo_as_in_food), # }: won't sound
 809    ('a_I',eye),('a_U',o_as_in_now),('e_I',a_as_in_ate),('O_I',oy_as_in_toy),(var1_oy_as_in_toy,'O_I',False),('o_U',var2_o_as_in_go),
 810    cleanup_regexps=[(r'\\',r'\\\\'),('"','&quot;'),('::',':')],
 811    lex_filename="",lex_entry_format="",
 812    lex_read_function=None,
 813    inline_oneoff_header=r'class Speak { public static void speak(android.app.Activity a,String s) { class OnInit implements android.speech.tts.TextToSpeech.OnInitListener { public OnInit(String s) { this.s = s; } public void onInit(int i) { mTts.speak(this.s, android.speech.tts.TextToSpeech.QUEUE_ADD, null); } private String s; }; if(mTts==null) mTts=new android.speech.tts.TextToSpeech(a,new OnInit(s),"com.svox.pico"); else mTts.speak(s, android.speech.tts.TextToSpeech.QUEUE_ADD, null); } private static android.speech.tts.TextToSpeech mTts = null; };'+'\n',
 814    inline_header=r'Speak.speak(this,"<speak xml:lang=\"en-US\">',
 815    inline_format=r'<phoneme alphabet=\"xsampa\" ph=\"%s\"/>',
 816    clause_separator=r".\n", # note r"\n" != "\n"
 817    inline_footer='</speak>");',
 818  ),

 947  # BEGIN PRE-32bit ERA SYNTHS (TODO: add an attribute to JS-hide them by default in HTML?  what about the SpeakJet which probably isn't a 32-bit chip but is post 32-bit era?  and then what about the 'approximation' formats - kana etc - would they need hiding by default also?  maybe best to just leave it)
 948  "apollo" : makeDic(
 949    'Dolphin Apollo 2 serial-port and parallel-port hardware synthesizers (in case anybody still uses those)',
 950    (syllable_separator,'',False), # I don't think the Apollo had anything to mark stress; TODO: control the pitch instead like bbcmicro ?
 951    ('_QQ',syllable_separator,False), # a slight pause
 952    ('_AA',a_as_in_apple),
 953    ('_AI',a_as_in_ate),
 954    ('_AR',a_as_in_ah),
 955    ('_AW',close_to_or),
 956    ('_A',a_as_in_ago),
 957    ('_B',b),
 958    ('_CH',ch),
 959    ('_D',d),
 960    ('_DH',th_as_in_them),
 961    ('_EE',e_as_in_eat),
 962    ('_EI',a_as_in_air),
 963    ('_ER',e_as_in_herd),
 964    ('_E',e_as_in_them),
 965    ('_F',f),
 966    ('_G',g),
 967    ('_H',h),
 968    ('_IA',ear),
 969    ('_IE',eye),
 970    ('_I',i_as_in_it),
 971    ('_J',j_as_in_jump),
 972    ('_K',k),
 973    ('_KK',k,False), # sCHool
 974    ('_L',l),
 975    ('_M',m),
 976    ('_NG',ng),
 977    ('_N',n),
 978    ('_OA',o_as_in_go),
 979    ('_OO',opt_u_as_in_pull),
 980    ('_OR',var3_close_to_or),
 981    ('_OW',o_as_in_now),
 982    ('_OY',oy_as_in_toy),
 983    ('_O',o_as_in_orange),
 984    ('_P',p),
 985    ('_PP',p,False), # sPeech (a stronger P ?)
 986    # _Q = k w - done by cleanup_regexps below
 987    ('_R',r),
 988    ('_SH',sh),
 989    ('_S',s),
 990    ('_TH',th_as_in_think),
 991    ('_T',t), ('_TT',t,False),
 992    ('_UU',oo_as_in_food),
 993    ('_U',u_as_in_but),
 994    ('_V',v),
 995    ('_W',w),
 996    # _X = k s - done by cleanup_regexps below
 997    ('_Y',y),
 998    ('_ZH',ge_of_blige_etc),
 999    ('_Z',z),
1000    # lex_filename not set (the hardware doesn't have one; HAL has an "exceptions dictionary" but I don't know much about it)
1001    approximate_missing=True,
1002    safe_to_drop_characters=True, # TODO: really?
1003    word_separator=" ",phoneme_separator="",
1004    cleanup_regexps=[('_K_W','_Q'),('_K_S','_X')],
1005    cvtOut_regexps=[('_Q','_K_W'),('_X','_K_S')],
1006  ),
1007  "dectalk" : makeDic(
1008    'DECtalk hardware synthesizers (American English)', # (1984-ish serial port; later ISA cards)
1009    (syllable_separator,'',False),
1010    ("'",primary_stress),
1011    ('aa',o_as_in_orange),

1019    ('ch',ch),
1020    ('d',d), ('dx',d,False),

1022    ('eh',e_as_in_them),
1023    ('el',l,False), # -le of bottle, allophone ?

1025    ('ey',a_as_in_ate),
1026    ('f',f),
1027    ('g',g),
1028    ('hx',h),
1029    ('ih',i_as_in_it), ('ix',i_as_in_it,False),
1030    ('iy',e_as_in_eat), ('q',e_as_in_eat,False),

1032    ('k',k),
1033    ('l',l), ('lx',l,False),
1034    ('m',m),

1036    ('nx',ng),

1039    ('p',p),
1040    ('r',r), ('rx',r,False),
1041    ('rr',e_as_in_herd),
1042    ('s',s),
1043    ('sh',sh),
1044    ('t',t), ('tx',t,False),

1050    ('yx',y),

1053    ('ihr',ear), # DECtalk makes this from ih + r
1054    approximate_missing=True,
1055    cleanup_regexps=[('yxuw','yu')], # TODO: other allophones ("x',False" stuff above)?
1056    cvtOut_regexps=[('yu','yxuw')],
1057    # lex_filename not set (depends on which model etc)
1058    stress_comes_before_vowel=True,
1059    safe_to_drop_characters=True, # TODO: really?
1060    word_separator=" ",phoneme_separator="",
1061    inline_header="[:phoneme on]\n",

1063  ),
1064  "doubletalk" : makeDic(
1065    'DoubleTalk PC/LT serial-port hardware synthesizers (American English; assumes DOS driver by default, otherwise set DTALK_COMMAND_CODE to your current command-code binary value, e.g. export DTALK_COMMAND_CODE=1)', # (1 is the synth's default; the DOS driver lets you put * instead)
1066    (syllable_separator,'',False),
1067    ("/",primary_stress), # TODO: check it doesn't need a balancing \ afterwards (docs do say it's a "temporary" change of pitch, but it's unclear how long a 'temporary')
1068    ('M',m),('N',n),('NX',ng),('O',o_as_in_go),

1072    ('R',r),('S',s),('SH',sh),('T',t),
1073    ('TH',th_as_in_think),('V',v),('W',w),('Z',z),
1074    ('ZH',ge_of_blige_etc),('K',k),('L',l),

1076    ('WH',w,False), ('KX',k,False), # ditto
1077    ('YY',y),('Y',y,False),
1078    ('UH',opt_u_as_in_pull),('UW',oo_as_in_food),

1088    ('IY',e_as_in_eat),('JH',j_as_in_jump),

1090    stress_comes_before_vowel=True,
1091    inline_format=markup_doubleTalk_word,
1092    format_is_binary=ifset('DTALK_COMMAND_CODE',True),
1093    # DoubleTalk does have a loadable "exceptions dictionary" but usually relies on a DOS tool to write it; I don't have the documentation about it (and don't know how much RAM is available for it - it's taken from the input buffer)
1094  ),
1095  "keynote" : makeDic(
1096    'Phoneme-read and lexicon-add codes for Keynote Gold hardware synthesizers (American English)', # ISA, PCMCIA, serial, etc; non-serial models give you an INT 2Fh param to get the address of an API function to call; not sure which software can send these codes directly to it)
1097    (syllable_separator,'',False),
1098    (primary_stress,"'"),(secondary_stress,'"'),
1099    ('w',w),('y',y),('h',h),('m',m),('n',n),('ng',ng),
1100    ('l',l),('r',r),('f',f),('v',v),('s',s),('z',z),
1101    ('th',th_as_in_think),('dh',th_as_in_them),('k',k),
1102    ('ch',ch),('zh',ge_of_blige_etc),('sh',sh),('g',g),
1103    ('jh',j_as_in_jump),('b',b),('p',p),('d',d),('t',t),
1104    ('i',e_as_in_eat),('I',i_as_in_it),
1105    ('e',a_as_in_ate),('E',e_as_in_them),
1106    ('ae',a_as_in_apple),('u',oo_as_in_food),
1107    ('U',opt_u_as_in_pull),('o',o_as_in_go),
1108    ('O',close_to_or),('a',o_as_in_orange),

1111    ('=',a_as_in_ago),

1117  ),
1118  "audapter" : makeVariantDic(
1119  "Audapter Speech System, an old hardware serial/parallel-port synthesizer (American English)", # 1989 I think.  The phonemes themselves are the same as the Keynote above, but there's an extra binary byte in the commands and the lex format is stricter.  I haven't checked but my guess is Audapter came before Keynote.
1120  inline_format='\x05[p] %s\x05[t]',
1121  format_is_binary=True,
1122  lex_filename="audapter.dat",
1123  lex_entry_format="\x05[x]%s %s\x05[t]\n", lex_footer="",
1124  ),
1125  "bbcmicro" : makeDic(
1126    "BBC Micro Speech program from 1985 (see comments in lexconvert.py for more details)",
1127    # Speech was written by David J. Hoskins and published by Superior Software.  It took 7.5k of RAM including 3.1k of samples (49 phonemes + 1 for fricatives at 64 bytes each, 4-bit ~5.5kHz), 2.2k of lexicon, and 2.2k of machine code; sounds "retro" by modern standards but quite impressive for the BBC Micro in 1985.  Samples are played by amplitude-modulating the BBC's tone generator.
1128    # If you use an emulator like BeebEm, you'll need diskimg/Speech.ssd.  This can be made from your original Speech disc, or you might be able to find one but beware of copyright!  Same goes with the ROM images included in BeebEm (you might want to delete ones you didn't have).  There has been considerable discussion over whether UK copyright law does or should allow "format-shifting" your own legally-purchased media, and I don't fully understand all the discussion so I don't want to give advice on it here.  The issue is "format-shifting" your legally-purchased BBC Micro ROM code and Speech disc to emulator images; IF this is all right then I suspect downloading someone else's copy is arguably allowed as long as you bought it legally "back in the day", but I'm not a solicitor so I don't know.
1129    # (Incidentally, yes I was the Silas Brown referred to in Beebug 11.1 p.59, 11.9 p.50/11.10 p.47 and 12.10 p.24, and, no, the question in the final issue wasn't quite how I put it, but all taken in good humour.)
1130    # lexconvert's --phones bbcmicro option creates *SPEAK commands which you can type into the BBC Micro or paste into an emulator, either at the BASIC prompt, or in a listing with line numbers provided by AUTO.  You have to load the Speech program first of course.
1131    # To script this on BeebEm, first turn off the Speech disc's boot option (by turning off File / Disc options / Write protect and entering "*OPT 4,0"; use "*OPT 4,3" if you want it back later; if you prefer to edit the disk image outside of the emulator then change byte 0x106 from 0x33 to 0x03), and then you can do (e.g. on a Mac) open /usr/local/BeebEm3/diskimg/Speech.ssd && sleep 1 && (echo '*SPEECH';python lexconvert.py --phones bbcmicro "Greetings from 19 85") | pbcopy && osascript -e 'tell application "System Events" to keystroke "v" using command down'
1132    # or if you know it's already loaded: echo "Here is some text" | python lexconvert.py --phones bbcmicro | pbcopy && osascript -e 'tell application "BeebEm3" to activate' && osascript -e 'tell application "System Events" to keystroke "v" using command down'
1133    # (unfortunately there doesn't seem to be a way of doing it without giving the emulator window focus)
1134    # If you want to emulate a Master, you might need a *DISK before the *SPEECH (to take it out of ADFS mode).
1135    # You can also put Speech into ROM, but this can cause problems: see comments on SP8000 later.
1136    (syllable_separator,'',False),
1137    ('4',primary_stress),
1138    ('5',secondary_stress), # (these are pitch numbers on the BBC; normal pitch is 6, and lower numbers are higher pitches, so try 5=secondary and 4=primary; 3 sounds less calm)
1139    ('AA',a_as_in_ah),
1140    ('AE',a_as_in_apple),
1141    ('AH',u_as_in_but),
1142    ('O',o_as_in_orange),
1143    ('AW',o_as_in_now),
1144    (a_as_in_ago,'AH',False),
1145    ('ER',e_as_in_herd),
1146    ('IY',eye),
1147    ('B',b),
1148    ('CH',ch),
1149    ('D',d),
1150    ('DH',th_as_in_them),
1151    ('EH',e_as_in_them),
1152    (ar_as_in_year,'ER',False),
1153    ('AI',a_as_in_air),
1154    ('AY',a_as_in_ate),
1155    ('F',f),
1156    ('G',g),
1157    ('/H',h),
1158    ('IH',i_as_in_it),
1159    ('IX',var2_i_as_in_it), # (IX sounds to me like a slightly shorter version of IH)
1160    ('IXAH',ear),
1161    ('EER',var2_ear), # e.g. 'hear', 'near' - near enough
1162    ('EE',e_as_in_eat),
1163    ('J',j_as_in_jump),
1164    ('K',k),
1165    ('C',k,False), # for CT as in "fact", read out as K+T
1166    ('L',l),
1167    ('M',m),
1168    ('N',n),
1169    ('NX',ng),
1170    ('OW',o_as_in_go),
1171    ('OL',opt_ol_as_in_gold), # (if dest format doesn't have this, it'll get o_as_in_orange from the O, then the l)
1172    ('OY',oy_as_in_toy),
1173    ('P',p),
1174    ('R',r),
1175    ('S',s),
1176    ('SH',sh),
1177    ('T',t),
1178    ('TH',th_as_in_think),
1179    ('AOR',oor_as_in_poor),
1180    ('UH',oor_as_in_poor,False), # TODO: really? (espeak 'U' goes to opt_u_as_in_pull, and eSpeak also used U for the o in good, which sounds best with Speech's default UH4, hence the line below, but where did we get UH->oor_as_in_poor from?  Low-priority though because how often do you convert OUT of bbcmicro format)
1181    (opt_u_as_in_pull,'UH',False),
1182    ('/U',opt_u_as_in_pull,False),
1183    ('/UL',opt_ul_as_in_pull), # if dest format doesn't have this, it'll get opt_u_as_in_pull from the /U, then l
1184    ('UW',oo_as_in_food),
1185    ('UX',oo_as_in_food,False),
1186    ('AO',close_to_or),
1187    ('V',v),
1188    ('W',w),
1189    ('Y',y),
1190    ('Z',z),
1191    ('ZH',ge_of_blige_etc),
1192    lex_filename=ifset("MAKE_SPEECH_ROM","SPEECH.ROM","BBCLEX"),
1193    lex_entry_format=as_utf8("> %s_")+chr(128)+as_utf8("%s"), # (specifying 'whole word' for now; remove the space before or the _ after if you want)
1194    lex_read_function = lambda lexfile: [(w[0].lstrip().rstrip('_').lower(),w[1]) for w in filter(lambda x:len(x)==2,[w.split(chr(128)) for w in getBuf(lexfile).read().split('>')])], # TODO: this reads back the entries we generate, but is unlikely to work well with the wildcards in the default lexicon that would have been added if SPEECH_DISK was set (c.f. trying to read eSpeak's en_rules instead of en_extra)
1195    lex_word_case = "upper",
1196    lex_header = bbc_prepDefaultLex,
1197    lex_footer = bbc_appendDefaultLex, # + ">**"
1198    inline_format = markup_bbcMicro_word,
1199    word_separator=" ",phoneme_separator="",
1200    clause_separator=write_bbcmicro_phones, # special case
1201    safe_to_drop_characters=True, # TODO: really?
1202    cleanup_regexps=[
1203      ('KT','CT'), # Speech instructions: "CT as in fact"
1204      ('DYUW','DUX'), # "DUX as in duke"
1205      ('AHR$','AH'), # usually sounds a bit better
1206    ],
1207    cvtOut_regexps=[('DUX','DYUW')], # CT handled above
1208  ),
1209  "bbcmicro-cc" : makeDic(
1210     "Computer Concepts Speech ROM which provided phonemes for the BBC Micro's TMS5220 \"speech chip\" add-on (less widely sold than the software-only product)", # (and harder to run on an emulator.  It wasn't the only phoneme ROM, e.g. Easytalk Speech Utility ROM by Galaxy, reviewed in Beebug Jan/Feb 1985 (3.8) p.32, expanded on Acorn's original PHROM with commands like *SAY Y.U:N.I.V.ER.S but we don't know all the phonemes; there were also some allophone-based hardware boards)
1211     (syllable_separator,"",False),
1212     ('*',primary_stress),('+',secondary_stress),
1213     ('E',e_as_in_eat),('i',i_as_in_it),('e',e_as_in_them),
1214     ('a',a_as_in_apple),('u',u_as_in_but),('AR',a_as_in_ah),
1215     ('o',o_as_in_orange),('OR',close_to_or),('oo',opt_u_as_in_pull),
1216     ('OO',oo_as_in_food),('ER',e_as_in_herd),('A',a_as_in_ate),
1217     ('I',eye),('O',o_as_in_go),('OY',oy_as_in_toy),
1218     ('AW',o_as_in_now),('EA',ear),('ea',a_as_in_air),
1219     ('UR',oor_as_in_poor),('UH',a_as_in_ago),
1220     ('P',p),('B',b),('T',t),
1221     ('D',d),('K',k),('G',g),
1222     ('CH',ch),('J',j_as_in_jump),('F',f),
1223     ('V',v),('TH',th_as_in_think),('DH',th_as_in_them),
1224     ('S',s),('Z',z),('SH',sh),
1225     ('ZH',ge_of_blige_etc),('H',h),('M',m),
1226     ('N',n),('NG',ng),('L',l),
1227     ('R',r),('Y',y),('W',w),
1228     stress_comes_before_vowel=True,
1229     inline_header="*UTTER <1> ",
1230     clause_separator="\n*UTTER <1> ", # TODO: manual does not say what the maximum length is; longest parameter in examples is 80 bytes; should we use inline_format to make each WORD a separate command?
1231     cleanup_regexps=[('[*] ','*'),('[+] ','+')],
1232     safe_to_drop_characters=' ',
1233  ),
1234     
1235  "amiga" : makeDic(
1236    'AmigaOS speech synthesizer (American English)', # shipped with the 1985 Amiga release; developed by SoftVoice Inc
1237    # All I had to go by for this was a screenshot on Marcos Miranda's "blog".  I once saw this synth demonstrated but never tried it.  My early background was the BBC Micro, not Amigas etc.  But I know some people are keen on Amigas so I might as well include it.
1238    # (By the way I think David Hoskins had it harder than SoftVoice.  Yes they were both in 1985, but the Amiga was a new 16-bit machine while the BBC was an older 8-bit one.  See the "sam" format for an even older one though, although probably not written by one person.)
1239    (syllable_separator,'',False),
1240    ('4',primary_stress),('3',secondary_stress),
1241    ('/H',h),
1242    ('EH',e_as_in_them),
1243    ('L',l),
1244    ('OW',o_as_in_go),
1245    ('AY',eye),
1246    ('AE',a_as_in_apple),
1247    ('M',m),
1248    ('DH',th_as_in_them),
1249    ('IY',e_as_in_eat),
1250    ('AH',a_as_in_ago),
1251    ('G',g),
1252    ('K',k),
1253    ('U',u_as_in_but),
1254    ('P',p),
1255    ('Y',y),
1256    ('UW',oo_as_in_food),
1257    ('T',t),
1258    ('ER',var1_a_as_in_ago),
1259    ('IH',i_as_in_it),
1260    ('S',s),
1261    ('Z',z),
1262    ('AW',o_as_in_now),
1263    ('AA',a_as_in_ah),
1264    ('R',r),
1265    ('D',d),('F',f),('N',n),('NX',ng),('J',j_as_in_jump),
1266    ('B',b),('V',v),('TH',th_as_in_think),
1267    ('OH',close_to_or),('EY',a_as_in_ate),
1268    # The following consonants were not on the screenshot
1269    # (or at least I couldn't find them) so I'm guessing.
1270    # I think this should work given the way the other
1271    # consonants work in this table.
1272    ('W',w),('CH',ch),('SH',sh),
1273    # The following vowels were not in the screenshot and
1274    # we just have to hope this guess is right - when
1275    # someone tries it on an Amiga and says it doesn't
1276    # work, maybe we can update this....
1277    ('O',o_as_in_orange),('OY',oy_as_in_toy),
1278    # and these ones we can approximate to ones we already know (given that we're having to approximate British to an American voice anyway, it can't hurt TOO much more)
1279     (a_as_in_air,'EH',False),
1280     (e_as_in_herd,'ER',False),
1281     (ar_as_in_year,'ER',False),
1282     (ear,'IYAH',False), # or try IYER, or there might be a phoneme for it
1283     (ge_of_blige_etc,'J',False),
1284     (oor_as_in_poor,'OH',False),
1285    # lex_filename not set (I have no idea how the Amiga lexicon worked)
1286    safe_to_drop_characters=True, # TODO: really?
1287    word_separator=" ",phoneme_separator="",
1288  ),
1289  "sam" : makeDic(
1290  'Software Automatic Mouth (1982 American English synth that ran on C64, Atari 400/800/etc and Apple II/etc)', # *might* be similar to Macintalk on the 1st Macintosh in 1984
1291  (syllable_separator,'',False),
1292  (primary_stress,'4'),
1293  (secondary_stress,'5'),
1294  ('IY',e_as_in_eat),
1295  ('IH',i_as_in_it),
1296  ('EH',e_as_in_them),
1297  ('AE',a_as_in_apple),
1298  ('AA',o_as_in_orange),
1299  ('AH',u_as_in_but),
1300  ('AO',close_to_or),
1301  ('OH',o_as_in_go),
1302  ('UH',opt_u_as_in_pull),
1303  ('UX',oo_as_in_food),
1304  ('ER',e_as_in_herd),
1305  ('AX',a_as_in_apple,False), # allophone?
1306  ('IX',i_as_in_it,False), # allophone?
1307  ('EY',a_as_in_ate),
1308  ('AY',eye),('OY',oy_as_in_toy),
1309  ('AW',o_as_in_now),('OW',o_as_in_go,False),
1310  ('UW',oo_as_in_food,False), # allophone?
1311  ('R',r),('L',l),('W',w),('WH',w,False),('Y',y),('M',m),
1312  ('N',n),('NX',ng),('B',b),('D',d),('G',g),('Z',z),
1313  ('J',j_as_in_jump),('ZH',ge_of_blige_etc),('V',v),
1314  ('DH',th_as_in_them),('S',s),('SH',sh),('F',f),
1315  ('TH',th_as_in_think),('P',p),('T',t),('K',k),
1316  ('CH',ch),('/H',h),('Q',glottal_stop),
1317  approximate_missing=True,
1318  word_separator=" ",phoneme_separator="",
1319  # TODO: inline_format etc similar to bbcmicro?
1320  # In Atari BASIC, you set SAM$ to the phonemes and then
1321  # do A=USR(8192).  I don't know about the C64 etc versions.
1322  # (max 255 phonemes per string; don't know max line len.)
1323  ),
1324  # END (?) PRE-32bit ERA SYNTHS (but see TODO above re SpeakJet, which is below)
1325
1326  "speakjet" : makeDic(
1327    'Allophone codes for the American English "SpeakJet" speech synthesis chip (the conversion from phonemes to allophones might need tweaking).  Set the SPEAKJET_SYM environment variable to use mnemonics, otherwise numbers are used (set SPEAKJET_BINARY for binary output).',
1328  # TODO: might want to do something similar for the older Votrax SC-02 chip, but would need to check how exactly its phoneme interface was exposed to software by the PC cards that used it (Heathkit HV-2000 etc; not sure if any are still in use though)

1465  "unicode-ipa" : makeDic(
1466    "IPA symbols in Unicode, as used by an increasing number of dictionary programs, websites etc",
1467    ('.',syllable_separator,False),
1468    (syllable_separator,'',False),
1469    (u'\u02c8',primary_stress),
1470    (u'\u02cc',secondary_stress),
1471    # NB the above two are "modifier", not "combining",
1472    # Unicode characters.  There IS a difference.  If
1473    # your software displays them as overprinting the
1474    # surrounding letters, you have a bug.
1475    # (E.g. WeChat v1.2.2.1 on Mac OS 10.7)
1476    ('#',text_sharp),
1477    ('_',text_underline),
1478    ('?',text_question),
1479    ('!',text_exclamation),
1480    (',',text_comma),
1481    (u'\u0251',a_as_in_ah),
1482    (u'\u02d0',ipa_colon),
1483    (u'\u0251\u02d0',var3_a_as_in_ah),
1484    (u'\u0251\u0279',var4_a_as_in_ah),
1485    (u'a\u02d0',var5_a_as_in_ah),
1486    (u'\xe6',a_as_in_apple),
1487    ('a',a_as_in_apple,False),
1488    (u'\u028c',u_as_in_but),

1577  "Like unicode-ipa but with syllable separators preserved",

1582  "yinghan" : makeVariantDic(
1583     "As unicode-ipa but, when converting a user lexicon, generates Python code that reads Wenlin Yinghan dictionary entries and adds IPA bands to matching words",
1584    lex_filename="yinghan-ipa.py", # write-only for now
1585    lex_type = "Python script",
1586    lex_header = '#!/usr/bin/env python\n# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-\n# Works in both Python 2 and Python 3\n\nimport sys; d={',
1587    lex_entry_format='u"%s":u"%s",\n',
1588    lex_footer = "}\nimport re\ntry: i,o=sys.stdin.buffer,sys.stdout.buffer # Python 3\nexcept AttributeError: i,o=sys.stdin,sys.stdout # Python 2\nfor k in list(d.keys()): d[k.lower().encode('utf-8')]=d[k]\nnextIsHead=False\nfor l in i:\n o.write(l)\n if nextIsHead and l.strip():\n  w=l.split()\n  if w[0]==u'ehw'.encode('utf-8'): l=u' '.encode('utf-8').join(w[1:])\n  k = re.sub(u'\\\\([^)]*\\\\)$'.encode('utf-8'),u''.encode('utf-8'),l.strip()).strip().lower()\n  if k in d: o.write(u'ipa '.encode('utf-8')+d[k].encode('utf-8')+u'\\n'.encode('utf-8'))\n if l.startswith(u'*** '.encode('utf-8')): nextIsHead=True\n", # (allow parenthesised explanation after headword when matching)
1589    noInherit=True
1590  ),
1591

1739  "latex-ipa" : makeDic(
1740    'IPA symbols for typesetting in LaTeX using the "tipa" package',
1741    ('.',syllable_separator,False),
1742    ('"',primary_stress),
1743    ('\\textsecstress{}',secondary_stress),
1744    ('\\#',text_sharp),
1745    ('\\_',text_underline),
1746    ('?',text_question),
1747    ('!',text_exclamation),
1748    (',',text_comma),
1749    ('A',a_as_in_ah),
1750    (':',ipa_colon),
1751    ('A:',var3_a_as_in_ah),
1752    ('A\\textturnr{}',var4_a_as_in_ah),
1753    ('a:',var5_a_as_in_ah),
1754    ('\\ae{}',a_as_in_apple),
1755    ('2',u_as_in_but),
1756    ('6',o_as_in_orange),
1757    (var1_o_as_in_orange,'A',False),
1758    ('O',var2_o_as_in_orange),
1759    ('aU',o_as_in_now),
1760    ('\\ae{}O',var1_o_as_in_now),
1761    ('@',a_as_in_ago),
1762    ('@:',e_as_in_herd),
1763    ('\\textrhookschwa{}',var1_a_as_in_ago),
1764    ('aI',eye),
1765    ('Ae',var1_eye),
1766    ('b',b),
1767    ('tS',ch),
1768    ('d',d),
1769    ('D',th_as_in_them),
1770    ('E',e_as_in_them),
1771    ('e',var1_e_as_in_them),
1772    ('3:',ar_as_in_year),
1773    ('E@',a_as_in_air),
1774    ('E\\textturnr{}',var1_a_as_in_air),
1775    ('e:',var2_a_as_in_air),
1776    ('E:',var3_a_as_in_air),
1777    ('e@',var4_a_as_in_air),
1778    ('eI',a_as_in_ate),
1779    ('\\ae{}I',var1_a_as_in_ate),
1780    ('f',f),
1781    ('g',g),
1782    ('h',h),
1783    ('I',i_as_in_it),
1784    ('1',var1_i_as_in_it),
1785    ('I@',ear),
1786    ('I\\textturnr{}',var1_ear),
1787    ('I@\\textturnr{}',var2_ear), # ?
1788    ('i',e_as_in_eat),
1789    ('i:',var1_e_as_in_eat),
1790    ('dZ',j_as_in_jump),
1791    ('k',k),
1792    ('x',opt_scottish_loch),
1793    ('l',l),
1794    ('d\\textltilde{}',var1_l),
1795    ('m',m),
1796    ('n',n),
1797    ('N',ng),
1798    ('@U',o_as_in_go),
1799    ('o',var1_o_as_in_go),
1800    ('oU',var2_o_as_in_go),
1801    ('@0',var1_u_as_in_but),
1802    ('OI',oy_as_in_toy),
1803    ('oI',var1_oy_as_in_toy),
1804    ('p',p),
1805    ('\\textturnr{}',r),
1806    (var1_r,'r',False),
1807    ('s',s),
1808    ('S',sh),
1809    ('t',t),
1810    ('R',var1_t),
1811    ('T',th_as_in_think),
1812    ('U@',oor_as_in_poor),
1813    ('U\\textturnr{}',var1_oor_as_in_poor),
1814    ('U',opt_u_as_in_pull),
1815    ('0:',oo_as_in_food),
1816    ('u:',var1_oo_as_in_food),
1817    ('u',var2_oo_as_in_food),
1818    ('O:',close_to_or),
1819    (var1_close_to_or,'O',False),
1820    ('o:',var2_close_to_or),
1821    ('v',v),
1822    ('w',w),
1823    ('\\textturnw{}',var1_w),
1824    ('j',y),
1825    ('z',z),
1826    ('Z',ge_of_blige_etc),
1827    ('P',glottal_stop),
1828    lex_filename="words-ipa.tex", # write-only for now
1829    lex_type = "document",
1830    lex_header = r'\documentclass[12pt,a4paper]{article} \usepackage[safe]{tipa} \usepackage{longtable} \begin{document} \begin{longtable}{ll}',
1831    lex_entry_format=r"%s & \textipa{%s}\\"+"\n",
1832    lex_footer = r"\end{longtable}\end{document}"+"\n",
1833    inline_format = "\\textipa{%s}",
1834    inline_oneoff_header = r"% In preamble, put \usepackage[safe]{tipa}"+"\n", # (the [safe] part is recommended if you're mixing with other TeX)
1835    word_separator=" ",phoneme_separator="",
1836    clause_separator=r"\\"+"\n",
1837    stress_comes_before_vowel=True,
1838    safe_to_drop_characters=True, # TODO: really?
1839  ),
1840
1841  "pinyin-approx" : makeDic(
1842    "Rough approximation using roughly the spelling rules of Chinese Pinyin (for getting Chinese-only voices to speak some English words - works with some words better than others)", # write-only for now
1843    ('4',primary_stress),
1844    ('2',secondary_stress),
1845    ('a5',a_as_in_ah),
1846    ('ya5',a_as_in_apple),
1847    ('e5',u_as_in_but),
1848    ('yo5',o_as_in_orange),
1849    ('ao5',o_as_in_now),
1850    (e_as_in_herd,'e5',False),
1851    ('ai5',eye),
1852    ('bu0',b),
1853    ('che0',ch),
1854    ('de0',d),
1855    ('ze0',th_as_in_them),
1856    ('ye5',e_as_in_them),
1857    (a_as_in_air,'ye5',False),
1858    ('ei5',a_as_in_ate),
1859    ('fu0',f),
1860    ('ge0',g),
1861    ('he0',h),
1862    ('yi5',i_as_in_it),
1863    ('yi3re5',ear),
1864    (e_as_in_eat,'yi5',False),
1865    ('zhe0',j_as_in_jump),
1866    ('ke0',k),
1867    ('le0',l),
1868    ('me0',m),
1869    ('ne0',n),
1870    ('eng0',ng),
1871    ('ou5',o_as_in_go),
1872    ('ruo2yi5',oy_as_in_toy),
1873    ('pu0',p),
1874    ('re0',r),
1875    ('se0',s),
1876    ('she0',sh),
1877    ('te0',t),
1878    (th_as_in_think,'zhe0',False),
1879    (oor_as_in_poor,'wu5',False),
1880    ('yu5',oo_as_in_food),
1881    ('huo5',close_to_or),
1882    (v,'fu0',False),
1883    ('wu0',w),
1884    ('yu0',y),
1885    (z,'ze0',False),
1886    (ge_of_blige_etc,'zhe0',False),
1887    approximate_missing=True,
1888    lex_filename="words-pinyin-approx.txt", # write-only for now
1889    lex_type = "text",
1890    lex_header = "Pinyin approxmations (very approximate!)\n----------------------------------------\n",
1891    lex_entry_format = "%s ~= %s\n",
1892    word_separator=" ",phoneme_separator="",
1893    cleanup_regexps=[
1894      ("te0ye","tie"),
1895      ("e0e5","e5"),("([^aeiou][uo])0e(5)",r"\1\2"),
1896      ("yu0y","y"),
1897      ("wu0yo5","wo5"),
1898      ("([bdfghklmnpwz])[euo]0ei",r"\1ei"),
1899      ("([bdghklmnpstwz])[euo]0ai",r"\1ai"),
1900      ("([ghklmnpstyz])[euo]0ya",r"\1a"),("([ghklmnpstz])a([0-5]*)ne0",r"\1an\2"),
1901      ("([bdfghklmnpstwyz])[euo]0a([1-5])",r"\1a\2"),
1902      ("([bdjlmnpt])[euo]0yi",r"\1i"),("([bjlmnp])i([1-5]*)ne0",r"\1in\2"),
1903      ("([zs])he0ei",r"\1hei"),
1904      ("([dfghklmnprstyz])[euo]0ou",r"\1ou"),
1905      ("([dghklnrst])[euo]0huo",r"\1uo"),
1906      ("([bfpm])[euo]0huo",r"\1o"),
1907      ("([bdghklmnprstyz])[euo]0ao",r"\1ao"),
1908      ("([zcs])h[eu]0ao",r"\1hao"),
1909      ("re0r","r"),
1910      ("zhe0ne0","zhun5"),
1911      ("54","4"),
1912      ("52","2"),
1913      ("([bdjlmnpty])i([1-9])eng0",r"\1ing\2"),
1914      ("ya([1-9])eng0",r"yang\1"),
1915      ("ya([1-9])ne0",r"an\1"),
1916      ("ye([1-9])ne0",r"yan\1"),("([wr])[eu]0yan",r"\1en"),
1917      ("yi([1-9])ne0",r"yin\1"),
1918      
1919      ("yu0","yu5"),("eng0","eng5"), # they won't work unvoiced anyway
1920      ("0","5"), # comment out if the synth supports 'tone 0 for unvoiced'
1921      #("[euo]0","0"), # comment in if it expects consonants only when doing that
1922    ],
1923  ),
1924
1925  "kana-approx" : makeDic(
1926  "Rough approximation using kana (for getting Japanese computer voices to speak some English words - works with some words better than others).  Set KANA_TYPE environment variable to hiragana or katakana (which can affect the sounds of some voices); default is hiragana", # for example on Mac OS 10.7+ (with Japanese voice installed in System Preferences) try PHONES_PIPE_COMMAND='say -v Kyoko' (this voice has a built-in converter from English as well, but lexconvert --phones kana-approx can work better with some complex words, although the built-in converter does seem to have access to slightly more phonemes and can therefore produce words like "to" better).  Default is hiragana because I find hiragana easier to read than katakana, although the Kyoko voice does seem to be able to say 'v' a little better when using kata.  Mac OS 10.7+'s Korean voices (Yuna and Narae) can also read kana, and you could try doing a makeVariantDic and adding in some Korean jamo letters for them (you'd be pushed to represent everything in jamo but kana+jamo seems more hopeful in theory), but again some words work better than others (not all phonetic combinations are supported and some words aren't clear at all).
1927    # This kana-approx format is 'write-only' for now (see comment in cleanup_regexps re possible reversal)
1928    (u'\u30fc',primary_stress),
1929    (secondary_stress,ifset('KANA_MORE_EMPH',u'\u30fc'),False), # set KANA_MORE_EMPH environment variable if you want to try doubling the secondary-stressed vowels as well (doesn't always work very well; if it did, I'd put this line in a makeVariantDic called kana-approx-moreEmph or something)
1930    # The following Unicode codepoints are hiragana; KANA_TYPE is handled by cleanup_func below
1931    (u'\u3042',a_as_in_apple),
1932    (u'\u3044',e_as_in_eat),
1933    (u'\u3046',oo_as_in_food),
1934    (u'\u3048',e_as_in_them),
1935    (u'\u304a',o_as_in_orange),
1936    (u'\u3042\u3044',eye), # ai
1937    (u'\u3042\u304a',o_as_in_now), # ao
1938    (u'\u3048\u3044',a_as_in_ate), # ei
1939    (u'\u304a\u3044',oy_as_in_toy), # oi
1940    (u'\u304a\u3046',o_as_in_go), # ou
1941    (a_as_in_ah,u'\u3042',False),
1942    (a_as_in_ago,u'\u3046\u304a',False), # TODO: \u3042, \u304a or \u3046 depending on the word?
1943    (e_as_in_herd,u'\u3042',False), # TODO: really?
1944    (i_as_in_it,u'\u3044',False), # TODO: really?
1945    (u_as_in_but,u'\u3046',False), # TODO: really?
1946    (ar_as_in_year,u'\u3048',False), # TODO: really?
1947    (ear,u'\u3044\u304a',False), # TODO: really?
1948    (a_as_in_air,u'\u3048',False), # TODO: really?
1949    (oor_as_in_poor,u'\u304a',False), # TODO: really?
1950    (close_to_or,u'\u304a\u30fc'), # TODO: really?
1951    (u'\u3076',b), # bu (with vowel replacements later)
1952    (u'\u3061\u3047',ch), # chu (ditto)
1953    (u'\u3065',d), # du (and so on)
1954    (u'\u3066\u3085',th_as_in_think), (th_as_in_them,u'\u3066\u3085',False),
1955    (u'\u3075',f),
1956    (u'\u3050',g),
1957    (u'\u306f',h), # ha (as hu == fu)
1958    (u'\u3058\u3085',j_as_in_jump), (ge_of_blige_etc,u'\u3058\u3085',False),
1959    (u'\u304f',k),
1960    (u'\u308b',l), (r,u'\u308b',False),
1961    (u'\u3080',m),
1962    (u'\u306c',n),
1963    (u'\u3093\u3050',ng),
1964    (u'\u3077',p),
1965    (u'\u3059',s),
1966    (u'\u3057\u3085',sh),
1967    (u'\u3064',t),
1968    (u'\u308f',w), # use 'wa' (as 'wu' == 'u')
1969    (v,ifset('KANA_V_AS_W',u'\u308f',u'\u3094'),False), # TODO: document KANA_V_AS_W variable.  Is vu always supported? (it doesn't seem to show up in all fonts)
1970    (u'\u3086',y),
1971    (u'\u305a',z),
1972    lex_filename="words-kana-approx.txt",
1973    lex_type = "text",
1974    lex_header = "Kana approxmations (very approximate!)\n--------------------------------------\n",
1975    lex_entry_format = "%s ~= %s\n",
1976    word_separator=" ",phoneme_separator="",
1977    clause_separator=u"\u3002\n".encode('utf-8'),
1978    cleanup_regexps=[(u"\u306c$",u"\u3093\u30fc"), # TODO: or u"\u3093\u3093" ?
1979       # now the vowel replacements (bu+a -> ba, etc) (in most cases these can be reversed into cvtOut_regexps if you want to use the kana-approx table to convert hiragana into approximate English phonemes (plus add a (u"\u3093\u30fc*",u"\u306c") and perhaps de-doubling rules to convert back to emphasis) but the result is unlikely to be any good)
1980       (u"\u3076\u3042",u"\u3070"),(u"\u3076\u3044",u"\u3073"),(u"\u3076\u3048",u"\u3079"),(u"\u3076\u304a",u"\u307c"),(u"\u3076\u3046",u"\u3076"),
1981       (u"\u3061\u3085\u3042",u"\u3061\u3083"),(u"\u3061\u3085\u3046",u"\u3061\u3085"),(u"\u3061\u3085\u3048",u"\u3061\u3047"),(u"\u3061\u3085\u304a",u"\u3061\u3087"),(u"\u3061\u3085\u3044",u"\u3061"),
1982       (u"\u3065\u3042",u"\u3060"),(u"\u3065\u3044",u"\u3062"),(u"\u3065\u3048",u"\u3067"),(u"\u3065\u304a",u"\u3069"),(u"\u3065\u3046",u"\u3065"),
1983       (u"\u3066\u3085\u3042",u"\u3066\u3083"),(u"\u3066\u3085\u3044",u"\u3066\u3043"),(u"\u3066\u3043\u3046",u"\u3066\u3085"),(u"\u3066\u3085\u3048",u"\u3066\u3047"),(u"\u3066\u3085\u304a",u"\u3066\u3087"),
1984       (u"\u3075\u3042",u"\u3075\u3041"),(u"\u3075\u3044",u"\u3075\u3043"),(u"\u3075\u3048",u"\u3075\u3047"),(u"\u3075\u304a",u"\u3075\u3049"),(u"\u3075\u3046",u"\u3075"),
1985       (u"\u306f\u3044",u"\u3072"),(u"\u306f\u3046",u"\u3075"),(u"\u306f\u3048",u"\u3078"),(u"\u306f\u304a",u"\u307b"),(u"\u306f\u3042",u"\u306f"),
1986       (u"\u3050\u3042",u"\u304c"),(u"\u3050\u3044",u"\u304e"),(u"\u3050\u3048",u"\u3052"),(u"\u3050\u304a",u"\u3054"),(u"\u3050\u3046",u"\u3050"),
1987       (u"\u3058\u3085\u3042",u"\u3058\u3083"),(u"\u3058\u3085\u3046",u"\u3058\u3085"),(u"\u3058\u3085\u3048",u"\u3058\u3047"),(u"\u3058\u3085\u304a",u"\u3058\u3087"),(u"\u3058\u3085\u304a",u"\u3058"),
1988       (u"\u304f\u3042",u"\u304b"),(u"\u304f\u3044",u"\u304d"),(u"\u304f\u3048",u"\u3051"),(u"\u304f\u304a",u"\u3053"),(u"\u304f\u3046",u"\u304f"),
1989       (u"\u308b\u3042",u"\u3089"),(u"\u308b\u3044",u"\u308a"),(u"\u308b\u3048",u"\u308c"),(u"\u308b\u304a",u"\u308d"),(u"\u308b\u3046",u"\u308b"),
1990       (u"\u3080\u3042",u"\u307e"),(u"\u3080\u3044",u"\u307f"),(u"\u3080\u3048",u"\u3081"),(u"\u3080\u304a",u"\u3082"),(u"\u3080\u3046",u"\u3080"),
1991       (u"\u306c\u3042",u"\u306a"),(u"\u306c\u3044",u"\u306b"),(u"\u306c\u3048",u"\u306d"),(u"\u306c\u304a",u"\u306e"),(u"\u306c\u3046",u"\u306c"),
1992       (u"\u3077\u3042",u"\u3071"),(u"\u3077\u3044",u"\u3074"),(u"\u3077\u3048",u"\u307a"),(u"\u3077\u304a",u"\u307d"),(u"\u3077\u3046",u"\u3077"),
1993       (u"\u3059\u3042",u"\u3055"),(u"\u3059\u3048",u"\u305b"),(u"\u3059\u304a",u"\u305d"),(u"\u3059\u3046",u"\u3059"),
1994       (u"\u3057\u3085\u3042",u"\u3057\u3083"),(u"\u3057\u3085\u3046",u"\u3057\u3085"),(u"\u3057\u3085\u3048",u"\u3057\u3047"),(u"\u3057\u3085\u304a",u"\u3057\u3087"),(u"\u3057\u3085\u3044",u"\u3057"),
1995       (u"\u3064\u3042",u"\u305f"),(u"\u3064\u3044",u"\u3061"),(u"\u3064\u3048",u"\u3066"),(u"\u3064\u304a",u"\u3068"),(u"\u3064\u3046",u"\u3064"),
1996       (u"\u3086\u3042",u"\u3084"),(u"\u3086\u3048",u"\u3044\u3047"),(u"\u3086\u304a",u"\u3088"),(u"\u3086\u3046",u"\u3086"),
1997       (u"\u305a\u3042",u"\u3056"),(u"\u305a\u3044",u"\u3058"),(u"\u305a\u3048",u"\u305c"),(u"\u305a\u304a",u"\u305e"),(u"\u305a\u3046",u"\u305a"),
1998       (u"\u308f\u3044",u"\u3046\u3043"),(u"\u308f\u3046",u"\u3046"),(u"\u308f\u3048",u"\u3046\u3047"),(u"\u308f\u304a",u"\u3092"),(u"\u308f\u3042",u"\u308f"),
1999       (u'\u3046\u3043\u3066\u3085', u'\u3046\u3043\u3065'), # sounds a bit better for words like 'with'
2000       (u'\u3085\u3046',u'\u3085'), # and 'the' (especially with a_as_in_ago mapping to u'\u3046\u304a'; it's hard to get a convincing 'the' though, especially in isolation)
2001       (u'\u3050\u3050',u'\u3050'), # gugu -> gu, sometimes comes up with 'gl-' combinations
2002       (u'\u30fc\u30fc+',u'\u30fc'), # in case we put 30fc in the table AND a stress mark has been applied to it
2003       (u'^(.)$',u'\\1\u30fc'), # lengthen any word that ends up as a single kana (otherwise can be clipped badly)
2004    (u'^([\u3042\u3070\u3060\u304c\u304b\u3089\u307e\u306a\u3071\u3055\u305f\u3084\u3056\u308f]\u3044)$',u'\\1\u30fc'), # ditto for -ai (TODO: -ao might need lengthening sometimes?? depends on context.  -ei, -oi, -ou seem OK)
2005    ],
2006    cleanup_func = hiragana_to_katakana
2007  ),
2008  "names" : makeDic(
2009    "Lexconvert internal phoneme names (sometimes useful with the --phones option while developing new formats)",
2010     *[(phName,phVal) for phName,phVal in phonemes.items()])}
2011
2012# The mainopt_...() functions are the main options
2013# (if you implement a new one, main() will detect it);
2014# 1st line of doc string should be parameter summary
2015# (start the doc string with \n if no parameters); if 1st
2016# character of doc string is * then this function is put
2017# among the first in the help (otherwise alphabetically).
2018# If function returns a string, that's taken to be a
2019# message to be printed with error exit.  Same if it raises
2020# an exception of type Message.
2021
2022def mainopt_try(i):
2023   """*<format> [<pronunciation>]
2024Convert input from <format> into eSpeak and try it out.
2025(Requires the 'espeak' command.)
2026E.g.: python lexconvert.py --try festival h @0 l ou1
2027 or: python lexconvert.py --try unicode-ipa '\\u02c8\\u0279\\u026adn\\u0329' (for Unicode put '\\uNNNN' or UTF-8)"""
2028   format = sys.argv[i+1]
2029   if not format in lexFormats: return "No such format "+repr(format)+" (use --formats to see a list of formats)"
2030   for phones in getInputText(i+2,"phonemes in "+format+" format",'maybe'):
2031      espeak = convert(phones,format,'espeak')
2032      w = os.popen("espeak -x","w")
2033      getBuf(w).write(markup_inline_word("espeak",espeak)+as_utf8('\n')) # separate process each item for more responsiveness from the console (sending 'maybe' to getInputText means won't lose efficiency if not read from console)
2034
2035def mainopt_trymac(i):
2036   """*<format> [<pronunciation>]
2037Convert phonemes from <format> into Mac and try it using the Mac OS 'say' command"""
2038   format = sys.argv[i+1]
2039   if not format in lexFormats: return "No such format "+repr(format)+" (use --formats to see a list of formats)"
2040   for resp in getInputText(i+2,"phonemes in "+format+" format",'maybe'):
2041      mac = convert(resp,format,'mac')
2042      toSay = markup_inline_word("mac",mac)
2043      print(as_printable(toSay))
2044      w = os.popen(macSayCommand()+" -v Vicki","w")
2045      getBuf(w).write(toSay) # Need to specify a voice because the default voice might not be able to take Apple phonemes.  Vicki has been available since 10.3, as has the 'say' command (previous versions need osascript, see Gradint's code)
2046
2047def mainopt_trymac_uk(i):
2048   """*<format> [<pronunciation>]
2049Convert phonemes from <format> and try it with Mac OS British voices (see --mac-uk for details)"""
2050   assert sys.version_info[0]==2, "--trymac-uk has not been tested with Python 3, I don't want to risk messing up your system files, please use Python 2"
2051   format = sys.argv[i+1]
2052   if not format in lexFormats: return "No such format "+repr(format)+" (use --formats to see a list of formats)"
2053   for resp in getInputText(i+2,"phonemes in "+format+" format",'maybe'):
2054     macuk = convert(resp,format,'mac-uk')
2055     m = MacBritish_System_Lexicon("",os.environ.get("MACUK_VOICE","Daniel"))
2056     try:
2057      try: m.speakPhones(macuk.split())
2058      finally: m.close()
2059     except KeyboardInterrupt:
2060      sys.stderr.write("Interrupted\n")
2061
2062def mainopt_phones(i):
2063   """*<format> [<words>]
2064Use eSpeak to convert text to phonemes, and then convert the phonemes to format 'format'.
2065E.g.: python lexconvert.py --phones unicode-ipa This is a test sentence.
2066Set environment variable PHONES_PIPE_COMMAND to an additional command to which to write the phones as well as standard output.  (If standard input is a terminal then this will be done separately after each line.)
2067(Some commercial speech synthesizers do not work well when driven entirely from phonemes, because their internal format is different and is optimised for normal text.)
2068Set format to 'all' if you want to see the phonemes in ALL supported formats."""
2069   format = sys.argv[i+1]
2070   if format=="example": return "The 'example' format cannot be used with --phones; try --convert, or did you mean --phones festival" # could allow example anyway as it's basically Festival, but save confusion as eSpeak might not generate the same phonemes if our example words haven't been installed in the system's eSpeak.  (Still allow it to be used in --try etc though.)
2071   if not format in lexFormats and not format=="all": return "No such format "+repr(format)+" (use --formats to see a list of formats)"
2072   hadOneoff = False
2073   for response in getInputText(i+2,"text",'maybe'):
2074    response = pipeThroughEspeak(as_utf8(response).replace(u'\u2032'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8('')).replace(u'\u00b4'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8('')).replace(u'\u02b9'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8('')).replace(u'\u00b7'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8(''))) # (remove any 2032 and b7 pronunciation marks before passing to eSpeak)
2075    if not as_utf8('\n') in response.rstrip() and as_utf8('command') in response: return response.strip() # 'bad cmd' / 'cmd not found'
2076    if format=="all": formats = sorted(k for k in lexFormats.keys() if not k=="example")
2077    else: formats = [format]
2078    for format in formats:
2079       def out(doOneoff=True):
2080          if len(formats)>1: writeFormatHeader(format)
2081          if doOneoff: getBuf(sys.stdout).write(as_utf8(checkSetting(format,"inline_oneoff_header")))
2082          getBuf(sys.stdout).write(as_utf8(checkSetting(format,"inline_header")))
2083          output_clauses(format,convert(parseIntoWordsAndClauses("espeak",response),"espeak",format))
2084          getBuf(sys.stdout).write(as_utf8(checkSetting(format,"inline_footer")))
2085          print("")
2086          sys.stdout.flush() # in case it's being piped
2087       out(not hadOneoff) ; hadOneoff = True
2088       if os.environ.get("PHONES_PIPE_COMMAND",""):
2089          o,sys.stdout = sys.stdout,os.popen(os.environ["PHONES_PIPE_COMMAND"],'w')
2090          out()
2091          sys.stdout = o
2092
2093def mainopt_ruby(i):
2094   """*<format> [<words>]
2095Like --phones but outputs the result as HTML RUBY markup, with each word's pronunciation symbols placed above the corresponding English word.
2096E.g.: python lexconvert.py --ruby unicode-ipa This is a test sentence.
2097This option is made more complicated by the fact that different versions of eSpeak may space the phoneme output differently, for example when handling numbers; if your eSpeak version is not recognised then all numbers are unannotated. Anyway you are advised not to rely on this option working with the new development NG versions of eSpeak. If the version you have behaves unexpectedly, words and phonemes output might lose synchronisation. However this option is believed to be stable when used with simple text and the original eSpeak.
2098You can optionally set the RUBY_GRADINT_CGI environment variable to the URL of an instance of Gradint Web Edition to generate audio links for each word.  If doing this in a Web Adjuster filter, see comments in the lexconvert source for setup details."""
2099   # htmlFilter with --htmlText of course.  Set separator to two newlines and copy the generated 'h5a' function (from a manual run or the lexconvert source) into Adjuster's headAppend option (but don't expect HTML5 audio to work from Adjuster's submitBookmarklet option; pronunciation links will take you off the page if it doesn't).
2100   # Use double newlines as single newlines are used in the h5a script; adding that script via bookmarklet doesn't always run it
2101   format = sys.argv[i+1]
2102   if format=="example": return "The 'example' format cannot be used with --ruby; did you mean festival?" # as above
2103   elif format=="all": return "The --phones all option cannot be used with --ruby" # (well you could implement it if you want but the resulting ruby would be quite unwieldy)
2104   if not format in lexFormats: return "No such format "+repr(format)+" (use --formats to see a list of formats)"
2105   text = as_utf8(getInputText(i+2,"text")).replace(u'\u2019'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8("'")).replace(u'\u2032'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8("'")).replace(u'\u00b4'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8("'")).replace(u'\u02b9'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8("'")).replace(u'\u00b7'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8('')).replace(u'\u00a0'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8(' '))
2106   # eSpeak's basic idea of an alphabetical word (most versions?) -
2107   wordRegexps = [r"(?:[A-Z]+['?-])*(?:(?:(?<![A-z.])(?:[A-z]\.)+[A-z](?![A-z.]))|[A-Z]+[a-z](?![A-z])|[A-Z][A-Z]+(?![a-z][A-z])|[A-Z]?(?:[a-z]['?-]?)+|[A-Z])"]
2108   # A dot, when not part of an elipses, followed by a letter is pronounced "dot", and two of them are pronounced "dot dot":
2109   wordRegexps.append(r"(?<!\.\.)\.(?=[A-z])|(?<!\.)\.(?=\.[A-z])")
2110   # ! followed by a letter is pronounced "exclamation", and .! is "dotexclamation"; @ symbols similarly; copyright
2111   atEtc = u"(?:[@!:]|\u00a9)*".encode('utf-8')
2112   wordRegexps.append(as_utf8(r"\.?[!@]+(?=[A-z])|(?<![A-z])@")+atEtc+as_utf8("(?![A-z])|")+unichr(0xa9).encode('utf-8')+atEtc)
2113   # : between numbers if NOT followed by 2 digits:
2114   wordRegexps.append(r"(?<![A-z]):(?![A-z]|[0-9][0-9])")
2115   # - between numbers
2116   wordRegexps.append(r"(?<=[0-9])-(?=[0-9])")
2117   # TODO: if you paste in (e.g.) CJK characters, eSpeak will say "symbol-symbol-symbol" etc, but this is not accounted for by the above regexp so it'll go onto following words.
2118   vLine = espeak_version_line()
2119   if "1.45." in vLine:
2120      # This seems to work in eSpeak 1.45:
2121      # (TODO: test leading 0s & leading decimal)
2122      # a number of 4 digits or less (with any number of digits after the decimal point) is grouped as 1 word:
2123      wordRegexps.append(r"(?<![0-9])[0-9]{1,4}(?:\.[0-9]+)?(?!,?[0-9])")
2124      # and a number of 1 to 3 digits with any number of 000 or ,000 groups, with optional decimal point followed by any number of digits, OR when placed before an integer number of 3-digit groups, is grouped as 1 word:
2125      wordRegexps.append(r"[0-9]{1,3}(?:,?000)*(?:\.[0-9]+)?,?(?=(?:,?[0-9]{3,3})*,?(?:[^0-9]|$))")
2126      text2 = text
2127   elif "1.48." in vLine:
2128      # In eSpeak 1.48 the groups are smaller.
2129      # Decimal point and everything after it = individual
2130      wordRegexps.append(r"(?<=[0-9])\.(?=[0-9])")
2131      for places in range(25): # TODO: really want unbounded, but (?<=...) is fixed-length
2132         wordRegexps.append(r"(?<=[0-9]\."+"[0-9]"*places+r")[0-9]")
2133      # Number with a leading dot grouped as 1 word:
2134      wordRegexps.append(r"(?<![0-9])\.[0-9]+")
2135      # TODO: leading 0s (0000048 goes to 0 000 048)
2136      # For normal numbers:
2137      # A null string w. 3 or 6 digits to go and digits b4 shld match for 'thousand', 'million' (unless 3+ digits are leading 0s, or fewer than 3 leading 0s and whole thing begins with a 0, or it's part of a decimal expansion, in which case different rules apply, but (?<=...) must be fixed-length, so we need another one of these awful loops) :
2138      for prevDigits in range(10):
2139         for beforeThat in ["^",r"[^.0-9,]"]: # beginning of string, or something OTHER than a decimal point / num
2140            wordRegexps.append(r"(?<="+beforeThat+"[1-9]"+"[0-9,]"*prevDigits+r")(?<!,)(?<!000)(?# empty string )(?=(?:,?(?:[0-9]{3,3}))+(?:[^0-9]|$))")
2141      # 1-9 (not 0) with 2, 5 or 8 etc digits to go = "N-hundred-and" :
2142      wordRegexps.append(r"[1-9](?=[0-9][0-9](?:,?(?:[0-9]{3,3}))*(?:[^0-9]|$))")
2143      # + 0 with 2 digits to go when preceded by digits = "and", as long as followed by at least one non-0:
2144      wordRegexps.append(r"(?<=[0-9,])0(?=(?:[0-9][1-9]|[1-9][0-9])(?:[^0-9,]|$))")
2145      # 1 or 2 digits with 0,3,6.. to go = "seventy-six" or whatever, as long as they're not both 0 :
2146      wordRegexps.append(r"(?:0[1-9]|[1-9][0-9]?)(?=(?:,?(?:[0-9]{3,3}))*(?:[^0-9]|$))")
2147      # 0 by itself (not preceded by digits) = "nought" :
2148      wordRegexps.append(r"(?<![0-9])0(?=[^0-9]|$)")
2149      wordRegexps.insert(0,"(?<=[^A-Za-z0-9_-])(?:of|on|in|that|with|for|was) (?:the|a)(?= )")
2150      wordRegexps.insert(0,"(?:Of|On|In|That|With|For|Was) (?:the|a)(?= )")
2151      wordRegexps.insert(0,"(?<=[^A-Za-z0-9_-])not a(?= )")
2152      wordRegexps.insert(0,"(?<=[^A-Za-z0-9_-])(?:some|that) one(?= )")
2153      wordRegexps.insert(0,"(?:Some|That) one(?= )")
2154      text2 = text
2155   else: text2 = re.sub(r"\.?[0-9]+","",text) # unknown eSpeak version: don't annotate the numbers
2156   response = pipeThroughEspeak(text2)
2157   if not as_utf8('\n') in response.rstrip() and as_utf8('command') in response: return response.strip() # 'bad cmd' / 'cmd not found'
2158   gradint_cgi = os.environ.get("RUBY_GRADINT_CGI","")
2159   if gradint_cgi:
2160      linkStart,linkEnd = lambda w:maybe_bytes('<a href="',w)+maybe_bytes(gradint_cgi,w)+maybe_bytes('?js=[[',w)+w.replace(maybe_bytes('%',w),maybe_bytes('%25',w)).replace(maybe_bytes('&',w),maybe_bytes('%26',w))+maybe_bytes(']]&jsl=en" onclick="return h5a(this);">',w), '</a>'
2161      print(r"""<script><!-- // HTML5-audio function
2162function h5a(link) {
2163 if (document.createElement) {
2164   var ae = document.createElement('audio');
2165   if (ae.canPlayType && function(s){return s!="" && s!="no"}(ae.canPlayType('audio/mpeg'))) {
2166     ae.setAttribute('src', link.href);
2167     ae.play(); return false;
2168   } else if (ae.canPlayType && function(s){return s!="" && s!="no"}(ae.canPlayType('audio/ogg'))) {
2169     ae.setAttribute('src', link.href+"&filetype=ogg");
2170     ae.play(); return false; }
2171 } return true; }
2172//--></script>""")
2173   else: linkStart,linkEnd = lambda w:maybe_bytes("",w), ""
2174   rubyList = []
2175   for clause in parseIntoWordsAndClauses("espeak",response):
2176      for w in clause:
2177         converted = convert(w,"espeak",format)
2178         if not converted: continue # e.g. a lone _:_:
2179         m = markup_inline_word(format,converted)
2180         rubyList.append(linkStart(w)+m.replace(maybe_bytes("&",m),maybe_bytes("&amp;",m)).replace(maybe_bytes("<",m),maybe_bytes("&lt;",m))+maybe_bytes(linkEnd,w))
2181   rubyList.reverse() # so can pop() left-to-right order
2182   # Write out re.sub ourselves, because (1) some versions of the library (e.g. on 2.7.12) try to do some things in-place, and we're using previous-context regexps that aren't compatible with previous things having been already <ruby>'ified, and (2) if we match a 0-length string, re.finditer won't ALSO return a non-0 length match starting in the same place, and we want both (so we're using wordRegexps as a list rather than an | expression)
2183   matches = {}
2184   debug = False # if True, will add ruby title=(index of the regexp that matched)
2185   debugCount = 0
2186   for r in wordRegexps:
2187      for match in re.finditer(maybe_bytes(r,text),text):
2188         matches[(match.start(),match.end())] = debugCount
2189      debugCount += 1
2190   i = 0 ; r = []
2191   def cmpFunc(a,b):
2192      (s1,e1),(s2,e2) = a,b
2193      if s1<s2: return -1
2194      if s1>s2: return 1
2195      if e1>e2: return -1
2196      if e1<e2: return 1
2197      return 0
2198   for start,end in sorted(list(matches.keys()),cmpFunc):
2199      if start<i: continue # overlap??
2200      r.append(text[i:start])
2201      if start==end: m = "&nbsp;"
2202      else: m = text[start:end].replace(maybe_bytes("&",text),maybe_bytes("&amp;",text)).replace(maybe_bytes("<",text),maybe_bytes("&lt;",text))
2203      try: rt = rubyList.pop()
2204      except: rt = "ERROR" # we've lost synchronisation
2205      if debug: title = as_utf8(" title=")+as_utf8(str(matches[(start,end)]))
2206      else: title = as_utf8("")
2207      r.append(as_utf8("<ruby")+title+as_utf8("><rb>")+m+as_utf8("</rb><rt>")+rt+as_utf8("</rt></ruby>"))
2208      i = end
2209   r.append(text[i:])
2210   while rubyList: # oops, lost synchronisation the other way (TODO: show this per-paragraph? but don't call eSpeak too many times if processing many short paragraphs)
2211      r.append(as_utf8("<ruby><rb>ERROR</rb><rt>")+rubyList.pop()+as_utf8("</rt></ruby>"))
2212   out = as_utf8("").join(r)
2213   if not out.endswith(as_utf8("\n")): out += as_utf8("\n")
2214   getBuf(sys.stdout).write(out)
2215
2216def pipeThroughEspeak(inpt):
2217   "Writes inpt to espeak -q -x (in chunks if necessary) and returns the result"
2218   assert type(inpt)==bytes
2219   bufsize = 8192 # careful not to set this too big, as the OS might limit it (TODO can we check?)
2220   ret = []
2221   while len(inpt) > bufsize:
2222      splitAt = inpt.rfind('\n',0,bufsize)+1
2223      if not splitAt: # no newline, try to split on space
2224         splitAt = inpt.rfind(' ',0,bufsize)+1
2225         if not splitAt:
2226            sys.stderr.write("Note: had to split eSpeak input and couldn't find a newline or space to do it on\n")
2227            splitAt = bufsize
2228      response = pipeThroughEspeak(inpt[:splitAt])
2229      if not '\n' in response.rstrip() and 'command' in response: return response.strip() # 'bad cmd' / 'cmd not found'
2230      ret.append(response) ; inpt=inpt[splitAt:]
2231   try: w,r=os.popen4("espeak -q -x",bufsize=bufsize) # Python 2
2232   except AttributeError: # Python 3
2233      import subprocess
2234      proc=subprocess.Popen(['espeak','-q','-x'],stdin=subprocess.PIPE,stdout=subprocess.PIPE)
2235      w = proc.stdin
2236      r = None
2237   if r:
2238      getBuf(w).write(inpt) ; w.close()
2239      r = getBuf(r).read()
2240   else: # Python 3
2241      w.write(inpt)
2242      out,err=proc.communicate()
2243      r = as_utf8("")
2244      if out: r += out
2245      if err: r += err
2246   return as_utf8("\n").join(ret) + r
2247
2248def espeak_version_line(): return os.popen("espeak -h 2>&1").read().strip().split("\n")[0]
2249
2250def writeFormatHeader(format):
2251   "Writes a header for 'format' when outputting in all formats.  Assumes the output MIGHT end up being more than one line."
2252   global writeFormatHeader_called
2253   if writeFormatHeader_called: print("")
2254   print(format)
2255   print('-'*len(format))
2256   writeFormatHeader_called = True
2257writeFormatHeader_called = False
2258
2259def mainopt_check_variants(i):
2260   # undocumented (won't appear in help text)
2261   groups = {}
2262   for k,v in lexFormats['espeak'].items():
2263      if type(k)==str:
2264         intV = int(v)
2265         if not intV in consonants:
2266            groups.setdefault(intV,[]).append((v,k))
2267   i = groups.items() ; i.sort()
2268   for k,v in i:
2269      if len(v)==1: continue
2270      v.sort()
2271      while True:
2272         print("Group "+str(k))
2273         es = os.popen("espeak -x","w")
2274         getBuf(es).write(as_utf8('\n').join([markup_inline_word("espeak",w) for _,w in v]))
2275         del es
2276         if not int(str(input("Again? 1/0: "))): break
2277
