2278def mainopt_check_for_similar_formats(i):
2279   # undocumented (won't appear in help text)
2280   items = lexFormats.items() ; r = []
2281   while items:
2282      k1,dic1 = items[0]
2283      for k2,dic2 in items[1:]:
2284         diff = 0
2285         for kk,vv in dic1.items():
2286            if not type(kk)==int: continue
2287            if kk==syllable_separator: continue
2288            if not dic2.get(kk,"!"+vv)==vv: diff += 1
2289         r.append((diff,k1,k2))
2290      items = items[1:]
2291   r.sort() ; had = set()
2292   for diffs,format1,format2 in r:
2293      if format1 in had and format2 in had: continue
2294      had.add(format1) ; had.add(format2)
2295      if "names" in had: break
2296      print(str(diffs)+" phoneme differences between "+format1+" and "+format2)
2297
2298def festival_group_stress(pronunc):
2299   "Special-case cleanup_func for the Festival format"
2300   # TODO: do we ever need to add extra consonants to the
2301   # previous group instead of the next group?  (not sure
2302   # what difference it makes to the synthesis, but it
2303   # might make the entry a bit more readable)
2304   groups = [] ; thisGroup = [[],'0',False] # phon,stress,complete
2305   for phon in pronunc.split():
2306      if phon in ['0','1','2']:
2307         if groups and phon >= groups[-1][1]:
2308            groups[-1][1]=phon
2309         continue
2310      thisGroup[0].append(phon)
2311      if phon[:1] in 'aeiou@':
2312         thisGroup[2]=True
2313         groups.append(thisGroup)
2314         thisGroup = [[],'0',False]
2315   if thisGroup[0]: groups.append(thisGroup)
2316   if len(groups)>=2 and not groups[-1][2]:
2317      groups[-2][0] += groups[-1][0]
2318      del groups[-1]
2319   return "("+' '.join(("(("+' '.join(g[0])+') '+g[1]+")") for g in groups)+")"
2320
2321def mainopt_convert(i):
2322   """*<from-format> <to-format>
2323Convert a user lexicon (generally from its default filename; if this cannot be found then lexconvert will tell you what it should be).
2324E.g.: python lexconvert.py --convert festival cepstral"""
2325   fromFormat = sys.argv[i+1]
2326   toFormat = sys.argv[i+2]
2327   if fromFormat==toFormat: return "Cannot convert a lexicon to its own format (that could result in it being truncated)"
2328   if toFormat=="mac-uk": return "Cannot permanently save a Mac-UK lexicon; please use the --mac-uk option to read text"
2329   if toFormat=="example": return "Cannot overwrite the built-in example lexicon"
2330   for f in [fromFormat,toFormat]:
2331      if not f in lexFormats: return "No such format "+repr(f)+" (use --formats to see a list of formats)"
2332   try:
2333      fname=getSetting(toFormat,"lex_filename")
2334      getSetting(toFormat,"lex_entry_format") # convert_user_lexicon will need this
2335   except KeyError: fname = None
2336   if not fname: return "Write support for lexicons of format '%s' not yet implemented (need at least lex_filename and lex_entry_format); try using --phones or --phones2phones options instead" % (toFormat,)
2337   if toFormat=="espeak":
2338      assert fname=="en_extra", "If you changed eSpeak's lex_filename in the table you also need to change the code below"
2339      if os.system("mv en_extra en_extra~ && (grep \" // \" en_extra~ || true) > en_extra"): sys.stderr.write("Warning: en_extra not found, making a new one\n(espeak compile will probably fail in this directory)\n") # otherwise keep the commented entries, so can incrementally update the user lexicon only
2340      outFile=open(fname,"a", encoding='utf-8')
2341   else:
2342      l = 0
2343      try:
2344         f = open(fname, encoding='utf-8')
2345         l = getBuf(f).read()
2346         del f
2347      except: pass
2348      assert not l, "File "+replHome(fname)+" already exists and is not empty; are you sure you want to overwrite it?  (Delete it first if so)" # (if you run with python -O then this is ignored, as are some other checks so be careful)
2349      outFile=open(fname,"w", encoding='utf-8')
2350   print ("Writing %s lexicon entries to %s file %s" % (fromFormat,toFormat,fname))
2351   try: convert_user_lexicon(fromFormat,toFormat,outFile)
2352   except Message:
2353     print (" - error, deleting "+fname)
2354     os.remove(fname) ; raise
2355
2356def mainopt_festival_dictionary_to_espeak(i):
2357   """<location>
2358Convert the Festival Oxford Advanced Learners Dictionary (OALD) pronunciation lexicon to eSpeak.
2359You need to specify the location of the OALD file in <location>,
2360e.g. for Debian festlex-oald package: python lexconvert.py --festival-dictionary-to-espeak /usr/share/festival/dicts/oald/all.scm
2361or if you can't install the Debian package, try downloading http://ftp.debian.org/debian/pool/non-free/f/festlex-oald/festlex-oald_1.4.0.orig.tar.gz, unpack it into /tmp, and do: python lexconvert.py --festival-dictionary-to-espeak /tmp/festival/lib/dicts/oald/oald-0.4.out
2362In all cases you need to cd to the eSpeak source directory before running this.  en_extra will be overwritten.  Converter will also read your ~/.festivalrc if it exists.  (You can later incrementally update from ~/.festivalrc using the --convert option; the entries from the system dictionary will not be overwritten in this case.)  Specify --without-check to bypass checking the existing eSpeak pronunciation for OALD entries (much faster, but makes a larger file and in some cases compromises the pronunciation quality)."""
2363   try: festival_location=sys.argv[i+1]
2364   except IndexError: return "Error: --festival-dictionary-to-espeak must be followed by the location of the festival OALD file (see help text)"
2365   try: open(festival_location, encoding='utf-8')
2366   except: return "Error: The specified OALD location '"+festival_location+"' could not be opened"
2367   try: open("en_list", encoding='utf-8')
2368   except: return "Error: en_list could not be opened (did you remember to cd to the eSpeak dictsource directory first?"
2369   convert_system_festival_dictionary_to_espeak(festival_location,not '--without-check' in sys.argv,not os.system("test -e ~/.festivalrc"))
2370
2371def mainopt_syllables(i):
2372   """[<words>]
2373Attempt to break 'words' into syllables for music lyrics (uses espeak to determine how many syllables are needed)"""
2374   # As explained on mainopt_ruby's help text, espeak -x output can't be relied on to always put a space between every input word.  Rather than try to guess what espeak is going to do, here we simply put a newline after every input word instead.  This might affect eSpeak's output (so not recommended for mainopt_ruby), but it should be OK for just counting the syllables.  (Also, the assumption that the input words have been taken from song lyrics usefully rules out certain awkward punctuation cases.)
2375   for txt in getInputText(i+1,"word(s)",'maybe'):
2376      words=txt.split()
2377      response = pipeThroughEspeak(as_utf8('\n').join(as_utf8(w) for w in words).replace(as_utf8("!"),as_utf8("")).replace(as_utf8(":"),as_utf8("")).replace(as_utf8("."),as_utf8("")))
2378      if not as_utf8('\n') in response.rstrip() and as_utf8('command') in response: return response.strip() # 'bad cmd' / 'cmd not found'
2379      rrr = response.split(as_utf8("\n"))
2380      print (" ".join([hyphenate(word,sylcount(convert(line,"espeak","example"))) for word,line in zip(words,filter(lambda x:x,rrr))]))
2381      sys.stdout.flush() # in case piped
2382
2383def wordSeparator(format):
2384   """Returns the effective word separator of format (remembering that it defaults to same as phoneme_separator"""
2385   return checkSetting(format,"word_separator",checkSetting(format,"phoneme_separator"," "))
2386
2387def mainopt_phones2phones(i):
2388   """*<format1> <format2> [<phonemes in format1>]
2389Perform a one-off conversion of phonemes from format1 to format2 (format2 can be 'all' if you want)""" # If format1 is 'example' and you don't specify phonemes, we take the words from the example lexicon.  But don't say that in the help string because it might confuse the issue about phonemes being optional on the command line and prompted for if not specified and stdin is not piped in all formats other than 'example'.
2390   format1,format2 = sys.argv[i+1],sys.argv[i+2]
2391   if not format1 in lexFormats: return "No such format "+repr(format1)+" (use --formats to see a list of formats)"
2392   if not format2 in lexFormats and not format2=="all": return "No such format "+repr(format2)+" (use --formats to see a list of formats)"
2393   if format1=="example" and len(sys.argv)<=i+3:
2394     if stdin_is_terminal(): txt=""
2395     else: txt=getBuf(sys.stdin).read() # and it might still be ""
2396     if txt: parseIntoWordsAndClauses(format1,txt)
2397     else: clauses=[[x[1]] for x in getSetting('example','lex_read_function')()]
2398   else: clauses = parseIntoWordsAndClauses(format1,getInputText(i+3,"phonemes in "+format1+" format"))
2399   if format2=="all": formats = sorted(k for k in lexFormats.keys() if not k=="example")
2400   else: formats = [format2]
2401   for format2 in formats:
2402     if len(formats)>1: writeFormatHeader(format2)
2403     getBuf(sys.stdout).write(as_utf8(checkSetting(format2,"inline_header")))
2404     output_clauses(format2,convert(clauses,format1,format2))
2405     getBuf(sys.stdout).write(as_utf8(checkSetting(format2,"inline_footer"))) ; print("")
2406
2407def parseIntoWordsAndClauses(format,phones):
2408   "Returns list of clauses, each of which is a list of words, assuming 'phones' are in format 'format'"
2409   wordSep = checkSetting(format,"word_separator") # don't use wordSeparator() here - we're splitting, not joining, so we don't want it to default to phoneme_separator
2410   clauseSep = checkSetting(format,"clause_separator","\n")
2411   def s(sep):
2412      if sep==" ": return None # " " means ANY whitespace (TODO: document this?)
2413      else: return maybe_bytes(sep,phones)
2414   if clauseSep and type(clauseSep) in [bytes,unicode]:
2415      clauses = phones.split(s(clauseSep))
2416   else: clauses = [phones]
2417   for i in range(len(clauses)):
2418      if wordSep: clauses[i]=clauses[i].split(s(wordSep))
2419      else: clauses[i] = [clauses[i]]
2420      clauses[i] = list(filter(lambda x:x, clauses[i]))
2421   return list(filter(lambda x:x,clauses))
2422
2423def mainopt_mac_uk(i):
2424   """<from-format> [<text>]
2425Speak text in Mac OS 10.7+ British voices while using a lexicon converted in from <from-format>. As these voices do not have user-modifiable lexicons, lexconvert must binary-patch your system's master lexicon; this is at your own risk! (Superuser privileges are needed the first time. A backup of the system file is made, and all changes are restored on normal exit but if you force-quit then you might need to restore the backup manually. Text speaking needs to be under lexconvert's control because it usually has to change the input words to make them fit the available space in the binary lexicon.) By default the Daniel voice is used; Emily or Serena can be selected by setting the MACUK_VOICE environment variable."""
2426   # If you have xterm etc, then text will also be printed, with words from the altered lexicon underlined.
2427   assert sys.version_info[0]==2, "--mac-uk has not been tested with Python 3, I don't want to risk messing up your system files, please use Python 2"
2428   fromFormat = sys.argv[i+1]
2429   if not fromFormat in lexFormats: return "No such format "+repr(fromFormat)+" (use --formats to see a list of formats)"
2430   lex = get_macuk_lexicon(fromFormat)
2431   try:
2432      for line in getInputText(i+2,"text",True):
2433         m = MacBritish_System_Lexicon(line,os.environ.get("MACUK_VOICE","Daniel"))
2434         try: m.readWithLex(lex)
2435         finally: m.close()
2436   except KeyboardInterrupt:
2437      sys.stderr.write("Interrupted\n")
2438
2439class Counter(object):
2440    "A simple class with two static members, count and subcount, for use by the consonant(), vowel() and other() functions"
2441    c=sc=0
2442def other():
2443    "Used by Phonemes() when creating something that is neither a vowel nor a consonant, e.g. a stress mark"
2444    Counter.c += 1 ; Counter.sc=0 ; return Counter.c
2445consonants = set() ; mainVowels = set()
2446def consonant():
2447    "Used by Phonemes() when creating a consonant"
2448    r = other() ; consonants.add(r) ; return r
2449def vowel():
2450    "Used by Phonemes() when creating a vowel"
2451    r = other() ; mainVowels.add(r) ; return r
2452def opt_vowel():
2453    "Used by Phonemes() when creating an optional vowel (one that has no warning issued if some format doesn't support it)"
2454    return other()
2455def variant():
2456    "Used by Phonemes() when creating a variant of the just-defined vowel/consonant/etc"
2457    Counter.sc += 1
2458    while str(Counter.sc).endswith('0'): Counter.sc += 1
2459    return 0, float('%d.%d' % (Counter.c,Counter.sc))
2460    # the 0 is so we can say _, name = variant()
2461    # so as to get some extra indentation
2462
2463def ifset(var,a,b=""):
2464   "Checks the environment variable var; if it is set (non-empty), return a, otherwise return b.  Used in LexFormats to create tables with variations set by the environment."
2465   import os
2466   if os.environ.get(var,""): return a
2467   else: return b
2468
2469def speakjet(symbol,opcode):
2470   "Special-case function for the Speakjet table"
2471   assert type(opcode)==int
2472   if ifset('SPEAKJET_BINARY',1):
2473      assert not ifset('SPEAKJET_SYM',1), "Cannot set both SPEAKJET_SYM and SPEAKJET_BINARY"
2474      return chr(opcode)
2475   else: return ifset('SPEAKJET_SYM',symbol,str(opcode))
2476
2477def makeDic(doc,*args,**kwargs):
2478    "Make a dictionary with a doc string, default-bidirectional mappings and extra settings; see LexFormats for how this is used."
2479    assert type(doc)==str, "doc must be a string"
2480    d = {} ; duplicates = set()
2481    for a in args:
2482        assert type(a)==tuple and (len(a)==2 or len(a)==3)
2483        k=a[0]
2484        if k in d: duplicates.add(k)
2485        v=a[1]
2486        assert (type(k) in [bytes,unicode] and type(v) in [int,float]) or (type(v) in [bytes,unicode] and type(k) in [int,float]), "Wrong types "+repr(a)+" (did you forget a _, before calling variant() or something?)"
2487        d[k] = v
2488        if type(k)==unicode: d[as_utf8(k)] = v
2489        if len(a)==3: bidir=a[2]
2490        else: bidir=True
2491        if bidir:
2492            # (k,v,True) = both (k,v) and (v,k)
2493            if v in d: duplicates.add(v)
2494            d[v] = k
2495    assert not duplicates, " Duplicate key(s) in "+repr(doc)+": "+", ".join((repr(dup)+"".join(" (="+g+")" for g,val in globals().items() if val==dup)) for dup in sorted(list(duplicates)))+". Did you forget a ,False to suppress bidirectional mapping?" # by the way, Python does not detect duplicate keys in {...} notation - it just lets you overwrite
2496    missing = [l for l in (list(consonants)+list(mainVowels)) if not l in d]
2497    # did_approx = False
2498    if missing and 'approximate_missing' in kwargs:
2499      for miss,approxTo in [
2500          # TODO: put this table somewhere else?
2501          # (If the thing on the right is just 1 item, we could make the thing on the left a variant of it.  But that might not be a good idea unless they're really very close, since if it's a variant then the substitution is done without warning even if approximate_missing is not set.)
2502          (a_as_in_ago, [u_as_in_but]),
2503          (a_as_in_air, [e_as_in_them,r]),
2504          (ear, [e_as_in_eat,u_as_in_but]),
2505          (oor_as_in_poor, [close_to_or]), # TODO: ,r?
2506          (a_as_in_ah,[a_as_in_apple]), # this seems to be missing in some American voices (DecTalk, Keynote, SAM); TODO: is this the best approximation we can do?
2507          ]:
2508        if miss in missing and all(x in d for x in approxTo):
2509          d[miss]=maybe_bytes(kwargs.get("phoneme_separator"," "),d[approxTo[0]]).join(d[x] for x in approxTo)
2510          # did_approx = True
2511          missing.remove(miss)
2512    # if did_approx: doc="(approx.) "+doc # and see also the code in makeVariantDic.  Commenting out because this is misleading: the formats where we didn't do a did_approx might also contain approximations of some kind.  Incidentally there are some British English voices that need approximate_missing (e.g. Apollo 2)
2513    d[("settings","doc")] = doc
2514    if missing:
2515       import sys ; sys.stderr.write("WARNING: Some non-optional vowels/consonants are missing from "+repr(doc)+"\nThe following are missing: "+", ".join("/".join(g for g,val in globals().items() if val==m) for m in missing)+"\n")
2516    for k,v in kwargs.items(): d[('settings',k)] = v
2517    assert type(d.get(('settings','cleanup_regexps'),[]))==list, "cleanup_regexps must be a list" # not one tuple
2518    assert type(d.get(('settings','cvtOut_regexps'),[]))==list, "cvtOut_regexps must be a list" # not one tuple
2519    wsep = d.get(('settings','word_separator'),None)
2520    psep = d.get(('settings','phoneme_separator'),' ')
2521    if not wsep==None: assert not wsep in d, "word_separator duplicates with a key in "+repr(doc)
2522    if not psep==None: assert not psep in d, "phoneme_separator duplicates with a key (did you forget to change the default, or to add a ,False somewhere?) in "+repr(doc)
2523    global lastDictionaryMade ; lastDictionaryMade = d
2524    return d
2525def makeVariantDic(doc,*args,**kwargs):
2526    "Like makeDic but create a new 'variant' version of the last-made dictionary, modifying some phonemes and settings (and giving it a new doc string) but keeping everything else the same.  Any list settings (e.g. cleanup_regexps) are ADDED to by the variant; other settings and phonemes are REPLACED if they are specified in the variant.  If you don't want subsequent variants to inherit the changes made by this variant, add noInherit=True to the keyword args."
2527    global lastDictionaryMade
2528    ldmOld = lastDictionaryMade
2529    toUpdate = lastDictionaryMade.copy()
2530    global mainVowels,consonants
2531    oldV,oldC = mainVowels,consonants
2532    mainVowels,consonants = [],[] # so makeDic doesn't complain if some vowels/consonants are missing
2533    if 'noInherit' in kwargs:
2534       noInherit = kwargs['noInherit']
2535       del kwargs['noInherit']
2536    else: noInherit = False
2537    d = makeDic(doc,*args,**kwargs)
2538    if noInherit: lastDictionaryMade = ldmOld
2539    mainVowels,consonants = oldV,oldC
2540    # if toUpdate[("settings","doc")].startswith("(approx.) ") and not d[("settings","doc")].startswith("(approx.) "): d[("settings","doc")]="(approx.) "+d[("settings","doc")] # TODO: always?
2541    for k,v in toUpdate.items():
2542       if type(v)==list and k in d: d[k] = v+d[k]
2543    toUpdate.update(d) ; return toUpdate
2544def getSetting(formatName,settingName):
2545  "Gets a setting from lexFormats, exception if not there"
2546  return lexFormats[formatName][('settings',settingName)]
2547def checkSetting(formatName,settingName,default=""):
2548  "Gets a setting from lexFormats, default if not there"
2549  return lexFormats[formatName].get(('settings',settingName),default)
2550
2551import sys,re,os
2552try: from subprocess import getoutput
2553except: from commands import getoutput # Python 2
2554try: bytes # Python 3 and newer Python 2
2555except: bytes = str # older Python 2
2556try: unicode # Python 2
2557except: # Python 3
2558   unicode,unichr,xrange = str,chr,range
2559   def chr(x): return bytes([x])
2560   _builtin_sorted = sorted
2561   from functools import cmp_to_key
2562   def sorted(l,theCmp=None):
2563      if theCmp:
2564         return _builtin_sorted(l,key=cmp_to_key(theCmp))
2565      else: return _builtin_sorted(l)
2566   assert sys.version_info[1] > 4, "lexconvert cannot run on Python 3.4 due to lack of byte-string percent formatting (PEP 461).  Please use Python 3.5+ or stick with Python 2."
2567def getBuf(f):
2568   "Return a buffer to which bytes may be written, for Python 2 and 3 compatibility"
2569   try: return f.buffer # Python 3
2570   except AttributeError: return f # Python 2
2571
2572cached_sourceName,cached_destName,cached_dict = None,None,None
2573def make_dictionary(sourceName,destName):
2574    "Uses lexFormats to make a mapping dictionary from a particular source format to a particular dest format, and also sets module variables for that particular conversion (TODO: put those module vars into an object in case someone wants to use this code in a multithreaded server)"
2575    global cached_sourceName,cached_destName,cached_dict
2576    if (sourceName,destName) == (cached_sourceName,cached_destName): return cached_dict
2577    source = lexFormats[sourceName]
2578    dest = lexFormats[destName]
2579    d = {}
2580    global dest_consonants ; dest_consonants = set()
2581    global dest_syllable_sep ; dest_syllable_sep = dest.get(syllable_separator,"")
2582    global implicit_vowel_before_NL
2583    implicit_vowel_before_NL = None
2584    for k,v in source.items():
2585      if type(k)==tuple: continue # settings
2586      if type(v) in [bytes,unicode]: continue # (num->string entries are for converting IN to source; we want the string->num entries for converting out)
2587      if not v in dest: v = int(v) # (try the main version of a variant)
2588      if not v in dest: continue # (haven't got it - will have to ignore or break into parts)
2589      assert type(k) in [bytes,unicode]
2590      d[k] = dest[v]
2591      if int(v) in consonants: dest_consonants.add(d[k])
2592      if int(v)==e_as_in_herd and (not implicit_vowel_before_NL or v==int(v)): # TODO: or u_as_in_but ?  used by festival and some other synths before words ending 'n' or 'l' (see usage of implicit_vowel_before_NL later)
2593        implicit_vowel_before_NL = d[k]
2594      d[as_utf8(k)] = d[k]
2595      try: d[as_unicode(k)] = d[k]
2596      except UnicodeDecodeError: pass
2597    try:
2598       if any(type(v)==unicode for v in d.values()): d,dest_consonants=dict((k,as_unicode(v)) for k,v in d.items()),set(as_unicode(v) for v in dest_consonants) # Python 2: if ANY dest are Unicode, make them ALL Unicode
2599    except UnicodeDecodeError: d,dest_consonants=dict((k,as_utf8(v)) for k,v in d.items()),set(as_utf8(v) for v in dest_consonants) # ... or make them ALL byte-strings if some were binary and not readable as UTF-8
2600    cached_sourceName,cached_destName,cached_dict=sourceName,destName,d
2601    return d
2602
2603warnedAlready = set()
2604def convert(pronunc,source,dest):
2605    "Convert pronunc from source to dest.  pronunc can be a string or a list; if a list then we'll recurse on each of the list elements and return a new list (this is meant for batch-converting clauses etc)"
2606    assert type(pronunc) in [bytes,unicode,list], type(pronunc)
2607    if source==dest: return pronunc # essential for --try experimentation with codes not yet supported by lexconvert
2608    if type(pronunc)==list: return [convert(p,source,dest) for p in pronunc]
2609    func = checkSetting(source,'cvtOut_func')
2610    if func: pronunc=func(pronunc)
2611    for s,r in checkSetting(source,'cvtOut_regexps'):
2612        pronunc=re.sub(maybe_bytes(s,pronunc),maybe_bytes(r,pronunc),pronunc)
2613    ret = [] ; toAddAfter = None
2614    dictionary = make_dictionary(source,dest)
2615    maxLen=max(len(l) for l in dictionary.keys())
2616    debugInfo=""
2617    separator = checkSetting(dest,'phoneme_separator',' ')
2618    safe_to_drop = checkSetting(source,"safe_to_drop_characters")
2619    while pronunc:
2620        for lettersToTry in range(maxLen,-1,-1):
2621            if not lettersToTry:
2622              if safe_to_drop==True: pass
2623              elif (not safe_to_drop) or not pronunc[:1] in maybe_bytes(safe_to_drop,pronunc) and not (pronunc[:1],debugInfo) in warnedAlready:
2624                 warnedAlready.add((pronunc[:1],debugInfo))
2625               #   sys.stderr.write("Warning: ignoring "+source+" character "+repr(pronunc[:1])+debugInfo+" (unsupported in "+dest+")\n")
2626              pronunc=pronunc[1:] # ignore
2627            elif pronunc[:lettersToTry] in dictionary:
2628                debugInfo=" after "+as_printable(pronunc[:lettersToTry])
2629                toAdd=dictionary[pronunc[:lettersToTry]]
2630                assert type(toAdd) in [bytes,unicode], type(toAdd)
2631                isStressMark=(toAdd and toAdd in [maybe_bytes(lexFormats[dest].get(primary_stress,''),toAdd),maybe_bytes(lexFormats[dest].get(secondary_stress,''),toAdd)])
2632                if toAdd==maybe_bytes(lexFormats[dest].get(syllable_separator,''),toAdd): pass
2633                elif isStressMark and not checkSetting(dest,"stress_comes_before_vowel"):
2634                    if checkSetting(source,"stress_comes_before_vowel"): toAdd, toAddAfter = maybe_bytes("",toAdd),toAdd # move stress marks from before vowel to after
2635                    else: # stress is already after, but:
2636                        # With Cepstral synth (and kana-approx), stress mark should be placed EXACTLY after the vowel and not any later.  Might as well do this for others also.
2637                        r=len(ret)-1
2638                        while ret[r] in dest_consonants or ret[r].endswith(maybe_bytes("*added",ret[r])): r -= 1 # (if that raises IndexError then the input had a stress mark before any vowel) ("*added" condition is there so that implicit vowels don't get the stress)
2639                        ret.insert(r+1,toAdd) ; toAdd=maybe_bytes("",toAdd)
2640                elif isStressMark and not checkSetting(source,"stress_comes_before_vowel"): # it's a stress mark that should be moved from after the vowel to before it
2641                    i=len(ret)
2642                    while i and (ret[i-1] in dest_consonants or ret[i-1].endswith(maybe_bytes("*added",ret[i-1]))): i -= 1
2643                    if i: i-=1
2644                    ret.insert(i,toAdd)
2645                    if dest_syllable_sep: ret.append(maybe_bytes(dest_syllable_sep,toAdd)) # (TODO: this assumes stress marks are at end of syllable rather than immediately after vowel; correct for Festival; check others; probably a harmless assumption though; mac-uk is better with syllable separators although espeak basically ignores them)
2646                    toAdd = maybe_bytes("",toAdd)
2647                # attempt to sort out the festival dictionary's (and other's) implicit_vowel_before_NL
2648                elif implicit_vowel_before_NL and ret and ret[-1] and toAdd in [maybe_bytes('n',toAdd),maybe_bytes('l',toAdd)] and ret[-1] in dest_consonants: ret.append(maybe_bytes(implicit_vowel_before_NL,toAdd)+maybe_bytes('*added',toAdd))
2649                elif len(ret)>2 and ret[-2].endswith(maybe_bytes('*added',ret[-2])) and toAdd and not toAdd in dest_consonants and not toAdd==dest_syllable_sep: del ret[-2]
2650                if toAdd:
2651                    # Add it, but if toAdd is multiple phonemes, try to put toAddAfter after the FIRST phoneme
2652                    if separator: toAddList=toAdd.split(separator)
2653                    else: toAddList = [toAdd] # TODO: won't work for formats that don't have a phoneme separator (doesn't really matter for eSpeak though)
2654                    ret.append(toAddList[0])
2655                    if toAddAfter and not toAddList[0] in dest_consonants:
2656                        ret.append(toAddAfter)
2657                        toAddAfter=None
2658                    ret += toAddList[1:]
2659                pronunc=pronunc[lettersToTry:]
2660                break
2661    if toAddAfter: ret.append(toAddAfter)
2662    if ret and ret[-1]==dest_syllable_sep: del ret[-1] # spurious syllable separator at end
2663    if not ret: ret = ""
2664    else: ret=maybe_bytes(separator,ret[0]).join(ret).replace(maybe_bytes('*added',ret[0]),maybe_bytes('',ret[0]))
2665    for s,r in checkSetting(dest,'cleanup_regexps'):
2666      ret=re.sub(maybe_bytes(s,ret),maybe_bytes(r,ret),ret)
2667    func = checkSetting(dest,'cleanup_func')
2668    if func: return func(ret)
2669    else: return ret
2670
2671def unicode_preprocess(pronunc):
2672   "Special-case cvtOut_func for unicode-ipa: tries to catch \\uNNNN etc"
2673   if maybe_bytes("\\u",pronunc) in pronunc and not maybe_bytes('"',pronunc) in pronunc: # maybe \uNNNN copied from Gecko on X11, can just evaluate it to get the unicode
2674      # (NB make sure to quote the \'s if pasing in on the command line)
2675      try: pronunc=eval('u"'+pronunc+'"')
2676      except: pass
2677   else: # see if it makes sense as utf-8
2678      try: pronunc = pronunc.decode('utf-8')
2679      except: pass
2680   return pronunc
2681
2682def ascii_braille_to_unicode(a):
2683  "Special-case cleanup_func for braille-ipa (set by braille-ipa if BRAILLE_UNICODE is set).  Converts Braille ASCII to Unicode dot patterns."
2684  d=dict(zip(list(" A1B'K2L@CIF/MSP\"E3H9O6R^DJG>NTQ,*5<-U8V.%[$+X!&;:4\\0Z7(_?W]#Y)="),[unichr(c) for c in range(0x2800,0x2840)]))
2685  return u''.join(d.get(c,c) for c in list(a))
2686def unicode_to_ascii_braille(u):
2687  d=dict(zip([unichr(c) for c in range(0x2800,0x2840)],list(" A1B'K2L@CIF/MSP\"E3H9O6R^DJG>NTQ,*5<-U8V.%[$+X!&;:4\\0Z7(_?W]#Y)=")))
2688  r=''.join(d.get(c,c) for c in list(as_unicode(u)))
2689  if r.startswith(",7") and r.endswith("7'"): r=r[2:-2]
2690  return r
2691
2692def hiragana_to_katakana(u):
2693   "Special-case cleanup_func for kana-approx; converts all hiragana characters in unicode string 'u' into katakana if KANA_TYPE is set to anything beginning with a 'k'"
2694   assert type(u)==unicode
2695   if not os.environ.get("KANA_TYPE","").lower().startswith("k"): return u
2696   u = list(u)
2697   for i in xrange(len(u)):
2698      if 0x3041 <= ord(u[i]) <= 0x3096:
2699         u[i]=unichr(ord(u[i])+0x60)
2700   return u"".join(u)
2701
2702def espeak_probably_right_already(existing_pronunc,new_pronunc):
2703    """Used by convert_system_festival_dictionary_to_espeak to compare a "new" pronunciation with eSpeak's existing pronunciation.  As the transcription from OALD to eSpeak is only approximate, it could be that our new pronunciation is not identical to the existing one but the existing one is actually correct; try to detect when this happens by checking if the pronunciations are the same after some simplifications."""
2704    if existing_pronunc==new_pronunc: return True
2705    def simplify(pronunc): return \
2706        pronunc.replace(maybe_bytes(";",pronunc),maybe_bytes("",pronunc)).replace(maybe_bytes("%",pronunc),maybe_bytes("",pronunc)) \
2707        .replace(maybe_bytes("a2",pronunc),maybe_bytes("@",pronunc)) \
2708        .replace(maybe_bytes("3",pronunc),maybe_bytes("@",pronunc)) \
2709        .replace(maybe_bytes("L",pronunc),maybe_bytes("l",pronunc)) \
2710        .replace(maybe_bytes("I2",pronunc),maybe_bytes("i:",pronunc)) \
2711        .replace(maybe_bytes("I",pronunc),maybe_bytes("i:",pronunc)).replace(maybe_bytes("i@",pronunc),maybe_bytes("i:@",pronunc)) \
2712        .replace(maybe_bytes(",",pronunc),maybe_bytes("",pronunc)) \
2713        .replace(maybe_bytes("s",pronunc),maybe_bytes("z",pronunc)) \
2714        .replace(maybe_bytes("aa",pronunc),maybe_bytes("A:",pronunc)) \
2715        .replace(maybe_bytes("A@",pronunc),maybe_bytes("A:",pronunc)) \
2716        .replace(maybe_bytes("O@",pronunc),maybe_bytes("O:",pronunc)) \
2717        .replace(maybe_bytes("o@",pronunc),maybe_bytes("O:",pronunc)) \
2718        .replace(maybe_bytes("r-",pronunc),maybe_bytes("r",pronunc))
2719    # TODO: rewrite @ to 3 whenever not followed by a vowel?
2720    if as_printable(simplify(existing_pronunc))==as_printable(simplify(new_pronunc)): return True # almost the same, and festival @/a2 etc seems to be a bit ambiguous so leave it alone
2721
2722def parse_festival_dict(festival_location):
2723    "For OALD; yields word,part-of-speech,pronunciation"
2724    ret = []
2725    for line in open(festival_location, encoding='utf-8'):
2726        line=line.strip()
2727        if "((pos" in line: line=line[:line.index("((pos")]
2728        if line.startswith('( "'): line=line[3:]
2729        line=line.replace('"','').replace('(','').replace(')','')
2730        try:
2731            word, pos, pronunc = line.split(None,2)
2732        except ValueError: continue # malformed line
2733        if pos not in ['n','v','a','cc','dt','in','j','k','nil','prp','uh']: continue # two or more words
2734        yield (word.lower(), pos, pronunc)
2735
2736class Message(Exception): pass
2737def convert_system_festival_dictionary_to_espeak(festival_location,check_existing_pronunciation,add_user_dictionary_also):
2738    "See mainopt_festival_dictionary_to_espeak"
2739    os.system("mv en_extra en_extra~") # start with blank 'extra' dictionary
2740    if check_existing_pronunciation: os.system("espeak --compile=en") # so that the pronunciation we're checking against is not influenced by a previous version of en_extra
2741    outFile=open("en_extra","w", encoding='utf-8')
2742    print ("Reading dictionary lists")
2743    wordDic = {} ; ambiguous = {}
2744    el = open("en_list", encoding='utf-8')
2745    for line in filter(lambda x:x.split() and not re.match(maybe_bytes(r'^[a-z]* *\$',x),x),getBuf(el).read().split(as_utf8('\n'))): ambiguous[line.split()[0]]=ambiguous[line.split()[0]+as_utf8('s')]=True # this stops the code below from overriding anything already in espeak's en_list.  If taking out then you need to think carefully about words like "a", "the" etc.
2746    for word,pos,pronunc in parse_festival_dict(festival_location):
2747        pronunc=pronunc.replace("i@ 0 @ 0","ii ou 2 ").replace("i@ 0 u 0","ii ou ") # (hack for OALD's "radio"/"video"/"stereo"/"embryo" etc)
2748        pronunc=pronunc.replace("0","") # 0's not necessary, and OALD sometimes puts them in wrong places, confusing the converter
2749        if word in ['mosquitoes']: continue # OALD bug (TODO: any others?)
2750        if word in wordDic and not wordDic[word]==(pronunc,pos):
2751            ambiguous[as_utf8(word)] = True
2752            del wordDic[word] # better not go there
2753        if not as_utf8(word) in ambiguous:
2754            wordDic[word] = (pronunc, pos)
2755    toDel = []
2756    if check_existing_pronunciation:
2757        print ("Checking existing pronunciation")
2758        proc=os.popen("espeak -q -x -v en-rp > /tmp/.pronunc 2>&1","w")
2759        wList = []
2760    progressCount=0 ; oldPercent=-1
2761    itemList = list(wordDic.items())
2762    # Make sure it's NOT sorted, to ensure eSpeak doesn't
2763    # cache pronunciation of previous word when add suffix
2764    # (which can subtly change eSpeak's pronunciation in
2765    # some versions of eSpeak, leading to
2766    # Python 2/3 differences as Python 3 sorts by default) :
2767    itemList.sort()
2768    i0,i1 = itemList[:int(len(itemList)/2)],itemList[int(len(itemList)/2):]
2769    itemList = []
2770    while i0 or i1:
2771       if i0: itemList.append(i0.pop())
2772       if i1: itemList.append(i1.pop())
2773    for word,(pronunc,pos) in itemList:
2774        if check_existing_pronunciation:
2775            percent = int(progressCount*100/len(wordDic))
2776            if not percent==oldPercent: sys.stdout.write(str(percent)+"%\r") ; sys.stdout.flush()
2777            oldPercent=percent
2778            progressCount += 1
2779        if not re.match("^[A-Za-z]*$",word): # (some versions of eSpeak also OK with "-", but not all)
2780            # contains special characters - better not go there
2781            toDel.append(word)
2782        elif word.startswith("plaque") or word in "friday saturday sunday tuesday thursday yesterday".split():
2783            # hack to accept eSpeak's pl'ak instead of pl'A:k - order was reversed in the March 2009 draft
2784            toDel.append(word)
2785        elif word[-1]=="s" and word[:-1] in wordDic:
2786            # unnecessary plural (espeak will pick up on them anyway)
2787            toDel.append(word)
2788        elif word.startswith("year") or "quarter" in word: toDel.append(word) # don't like festival's pronunciation of those (TODO: also 'memorial' why start with [m'I])
2789        elif check_existing_pronunciation:
2790            getBuf(proc).write(as_utf8(word)+as_utf8("\n"))
2791            proc.flush() # so the progress indicator works
2792            wList.append(word)
2793    if check_existing_pronunciation:
2794        proc.close() ; print("")
2795        oldPronDic = {}
2796        tp = open("/tmp/.pronunc", encoding='utf-8')
2797        for k,v in zip(wList,getBuf(tp).read().split(as_utf8("\n"))): oldPronDic[k]=v.strip().replace(as_utf8(" "),as_utf8(""))
2798    for w in toDel: del wordDic[w]
2799    print ("Doing the conversion")
2800    lines_output = 0
2801    total_lines = 0
2802    not_output_because_ok = []
2803    items = list(wordDic.items()) ; items.sort() # necessary because of the hacks below which check for the presence of truncated versions of the word (want to have decided whether or not to output those truncated versions before reaching the hacks)
2804    for word,(pronunc,pos) in items:
2805        total_lines += 1
2806        new_e_pronunc = convert(pronunc,"festival","espeak")
2807        if new_e_pronunc.count("'")==2 and not '-' in word: new_e_pronunc=new_e_pronunc.replace("'",",",1) # if 2 primary accents then make the first one a secondary (except on hyphenated words)
2808        # TODO if not en-rp? - if (word.endswith("y") or word.endswith("ie")) and new_e_pronunc.endswith("i:"): new_e_pronunc=new_e_pronunc[:-2]+"I"
2809        unrelated_word = None
2810        if check_existing_pronunciation: espeakPronunc = oldPronDic.get(word,"")
2811        else: espeakPronunc = ""
2812        if word[-1]=='e' and word[:-1] in wordDic: unrelated_word, espeakPronunc = word[:-1],"" # hack: if word ends with 'e' and dropping the 'e' leaves a valid word that's also in the dictionary, we DON'T want to drop this word on the grounds that espeak already gets it right, because if we do then adding 's' to this word may cause espeak to add 's' to the OTHER word ('-es' rule).
2813        if espeak_probably_right_already(espeakPronunc,new_e_pronunc):
2814            not_output_because_ok.append(word)
2815            continue
2816        if not unrelated_word: lines_output += 1
2817        getBuf(outFile).write(as_utf8(word)+as_utf8(" ")+as_utf8(new_e_pronunc)+as_utf8(" // from Festival's (")+as_utf8(pronunc)+as_utf8(")"))
2818        if espeakPronunc: getBuf(outFile).write(as_utf8(", not [[")+as_utf8(espeakPronunc)+as_utf8("]]"))
2819        elif unrelated_word: getBuf(outFile).write(as_utf8(" (here to stop espeak's affix rules getting confused by Festival's \"")+as_utf8(unrelated_word)+as_utf8("\")"))
2820        getBuf(outFile).write(as_utf8("\n"))
2821    print ("Corrected(?) %d entries out of %d" % (lines_output,total_lines))
2822    if add_user_dictionary_also: convert_user_lexicon("festival","espeak",outFile)
2823    outFile.close()
2824    os.system("espeak --compile=en")
2825    if not_output_because_ok:
2826      print ("Checking for unwanted side-effects of those corrections") # e.g. terrible as Terr + ible, inducing as in+Duce+ing
2827      proc=os.popen("espeak -q -x -v en-rp > /tmp/.pronunc 2>&1","w")
2828      progressCount = 0
2829      for w in not_output_because_ok:
2830          getBuf(proc).write(as_utf8(w)+as_utf8("\n")) ; proc.flush()
2831          percent = int(progressCount*100/len(not_output_because_ok))
2832          if not percent==oldPercent: sys.stdout.write(str(percent)+"%\r") ; sys.stdout.flush()
2833          oldPercent = percent
2834          progressCount += 1
2835      proc.close()
2836      outFile=open("en_extra","a", encoding='utf-8') # append to it
2837      tp = open("/tmp/.pronunc", encoding='utf-8')
2838      for word,pronunc in zip(not_output_because_ok,getBuf(tp).read().split(as_utf8("\n"))):
2839        pronunc = pronunc.strip().replace(as_utf8(" "),as_utf8(""))
2840        if not pronunc==oldPronDic[word] and not espeak_probably_right_already(oldPronDic[word],pronunc):
2841          getBuf(outFile).write(as_utf8(word)+as_utf8(" ")+oldPronDic[word]+as_utf8(" // (undo affix-side-effect from previous words that gave \"")+pronunc+as_utf8("\")\n"))
2842      outFile.close()
2843      os.system("espeak --compile=en")
2844    return not_output_because_ok
2845
2846def read_user_lexicon(fromFormat):
2847    "Calls the appropriate lex_read_function, opening lex_filename first if supplied"
2848    readFunction = checkSetting(fromFormat,"lex_read_function")
2849    if not readFunction: raise Message("Reading from '%s' lexicon file not yet implemented (no lex_read_function); try using --phones or --phones2phones options instead" % (fromFormat,))
2850    try:
2851       lexFilename = getSetting(fromFormat,"lex_filename")
2852       if lexFilename==None: lexfile = None # e.g. the example lexicon
2853       else:
2854          lexfile = open(lexFilename, encoding='utf-8')
2855          if not os.environ.get("LEXCONVERT_OMIT_READING_FROM",""): print ("Reading from "+lexFilename) # TODO: document LEXCONVERT_OMIT_READING_FROM (might be useful for the --mac-uk option)
2856    except KeyError: lexfile = None # lex_read_function without lex_filename is allowed, if the read function can take null param and fetch the lexicon itself
2857    except IOError: raise Message(fromFormat+"'s lexicon is expected to be in a file called "+replHome(lexFilename)+" which could not be read - please fix and try again")
2858    return readFunction(lexfile)
2859
2860def replHome(fname):
2861   "Format fname for printing, substituting ~ for HOME if appropriate"
2862   h = os.environ.get('HOME','')
2863   if h and fname.startswith(h+os.sep):
2864      return "~"+fname[len(h):]
2865   else: return fname
2866    
2867def get_macuk_lexicon(fromFormat):
2868    "Converts lexicon from fromFormat and returns a list suitable for MacBritish_System_Lexicon's readWithLex"
2869    return [(word,convert(pronunc,fromFormat,"mac-uk")) for word, pronunc in read_user_lexicon(fromFormat)]
2870
2871def as_utf8(s):
2872   if type(s)==unicode: return s.encode('utf-8')
2873   else: return s
2874def as_unicode(s):
2875   if type(s)==unicode: return s
2876   else: return s.decode('utf-8')
2877def maybe_bytes(s,i):
2878   "Python 2/3 compatibility: convert s to bytes if i is bytes"
2879   if type(i)==unicode: return s
2880   else: return as_utf8(s)
2881def as_printable(s):
2882   if sys.version_info[0] < 3: return as_utf8(s)
2883   else: return as_utf8(s).decode('utf-8')
2884
2885def convert_user_lexicon(fromFormat,toFormat,outFile):
2886    "See mainopt_convert"
2887    lex = read_user_lexicon(fromFormat)
2888    lex_header = checkSetting(toFormat,"lex_header")
2889    if type(lex_header) in [bytes,unicode]: getBuf(outFile).write(as_utf8(lex_header))
2890    else: lex_header(outFile)
2891    entryFormat=getSetting(toFormat,"lex_entry_format")
2892    wordCase=checkSetting(toFormat,"lex_word_case")
2893    for word, pronunc in lex:
2894        pronunc = as_utf8(convert(pronunc,fromFormat,toFormat))
2895        if wordCase=="upper": word=word.upper()
2896        elif wordCase=="lower": word=word.lower()
2897        getBuf(outFile).write(as_utf8(entryFormat) % (as_utf8(word),as_utf8(pronunc))) # will work in Python 3.6, but not in Python 3.4 (e.g. on jessie) which cannot do % on byte-strings
2898    footer = checkSetting(toFormat,"lex_footer")
2899    if type(footer) in [bytes,unicode]: getBuf(outFile).write(as_utf8(footer))
2900    else: footer(outFile)
2901
2902def bbcMicro_partPhonemeCount(pronunc):
2903   """Returns the number of 'part phonemes' (at least that's what I'm calling them) for the BBC Micro phonemes in pronunc.  The *SPEAK command cannot take more than 117 part-phonemes at a time before saying "Line too long", and in some cases it takes less than that (I'm not sure why); 115 is a safer limit."""
2904   partCount = 0 ; pronunc0 = pronunc
2905   while pronunc:
2906      found = 0
2907      for p in ' ,AA,AE,AH,AI,AO,AW,AY,B,CH,CT,DH,DUX,D,EE,EH,ER,F,G,/H,IH,IX,IY,J,K,L,M,NX,N,OW,OL,OY,O,P,R,SH,S,TH,T,UH,/UL,/U,UW,UX,V,W,Y,ZH,Z'.split(','): # phonemes and space count, but pitch numbers do not count
2908         if pronunc.startswith(as_utf8(p)):
2909            partCount += {
2910               # *SPEAK can take 117 of most single-letter phonemes, or 116 (limited by the 232+6-character input limit) of most 2-letter phonemes
2911               'AW':2,'IY':2,'OW':2,'OL':2,'UW':2,'/UL':2, # *SPEAK can take 58 of these
2912               'DUX':3,'AY':3,'CH':3,'J':3,'OY':3, # *SPEAK can take 39 of these
2913               'CT':4, # *SPEAK can take 29 of these
2914            }.get(p,1)
2915            pronunc=pronunc[len(p):] ; found=1 ; break
2916      if not found:
2917         assert as_printable(pronunc[:1]) in '12345678',"Unrecognised BBC Micro phoneme at "+str(pronunc)+" in "+str(pronunc0)
2918         pronunc=pronunc[1:]
2919   return partCount
2920
2921def markup_inline_word(format,pronunc):
2922    "Returns pronunc with any necessary markup for putting it in a text (using the inline_format setting)"
2923    pronunc = as_utf8(pronunc) # UTF-8 output - ok for pasting into Firefox etc *IF* the terminal/X11 understands utf-8 (otherwise redirect to a file, point the browser at it, and set encoding to utf-8, or try --convert'ing which will o/p HTML)
2924    format = checkSetting(format,"inline_format","%s")
2925    if type(format) in [bytes,unicode]:
2926       if type(format)==unicode: format=format.encode('utf-8') # see above
2927       return format % pronunc
2928    else: return format(pronunc)
2929def markup_doubleTalk_word(pronunc):
2930   "Special-case function set as inline_format in doubletalk (checks environment variables for command code)"
2931   cmd = os.environ.get('DTALK_COMMAND_CODE','')
2932   if cmd: cmd=chr(int(cmd))
2933   else: cmd = as_utf8('*')
2934   return as_utf8("%sD%s%sT") % (cmd,pronunc,cmd)
2935def markup_bbcMicro_word(pronunc):
2936   "Special-case function set as inline_format in bbcmicro.  Begins a new *SPEAK command when necessary.  See also write_bbcmicro_phones."
2937   global bbc_partsSoFar,bbc_charsSoFar
2938   thisPartCount = bbcMicro_partPhonemeCount(pronunc)
2939   if (not bbc_partsSoFar or bbc_partsSoFar+thisPartCount > 115) or (not bbc_charsSoFar or bbc_charsSoFar+len(pronunc) > 238): # 238 is max len of BBC BASIC prompt (both the immediate prompt and the one with line number supplied by AUTO, in both BASIC II and BASIC IV); re other limit see bbcMicro_partPhonemeCount
2940      if bbc_charsSoFar: r="\n"
2941      else: r=""
2942      cmd="*SPEAK" # (could add a space if want to make it more readable, at the expense of an extra keystroke in the paste buffer; by the way, when not using the ROM version you must use *SPEAK not OS.("SPEAK"), at least on a Model B; seems OSCLI doesn't go through quite the same vectors as star)
2943      bbc_charsSoFar = len(cmd)+len(pronunc)+1 # +1 for the space that'll be after this word if we don't start a new line
2944      bbc_partsSoFar = thisPartCount+1 # ditto
2945      return as_utf8(r+cmd)+pronunc
2946   else:
2947      bbc_charsSoFar += len(pronunc)+1
2948      bbc_partsSoFar += thisPartCount+1
2949      return pronunc
2950bbc_partsSoFar=bbc_charsSoFar=0
2951
2952def sylcount(example_format_festival):
2953  """Tries to count the number of syllables in a Festival string (see mainopt_syllables).  We treat @ as counting the same as the previous syllable (e.g. "fire", "power"), but this can vary in different songs, so the result will likely need a bit of proofreading."""
2954  count = inVowel = maybeCount = hadAt = 0
2955  festival = example_format_festival.split() # no brackets, emphasis by vowels, but spaces between each syllable
2956  for phone,i in zip(festival,range(len(festival))):
2957    if phone[:1] in "aeiou": inVowel=0 # unconditionally start new syllable
2958    if phone[:1] in "aeiou@12":
2959      if not inVowel: count += 1
2960      elif phone[:1]=="@" and not hadAt: maybeCount = 1 # (e.g. "loyal", but NOT '1', e.g. "world")
2961      if "@" in phone: hadAt = 1 # for words like "cheerful" ("i@ 1 @" counts as one)
2962      inVowel = 1
2963      if phone[:1]=="@" and i>=3 and festival[i-2:i]==["ai","1"] and festival[i-3] in ["s","h"]: # special rule for higher, Messiah, etc - like "fire" but usually 2 syllables
2964        maybeCount = 0 ; count += 1
2965    else:
2966      if not phone[:1] in "drz": count += maybeCount # not 'r/z' e.g. "ours", "fired" usually 1 syllable in songs, "desirable" usually 4 not 5
2967      # TODO steward?  y u@ 1 d but usally 2 syllables
2968      inVowel = maybeCount = hadAt = 0
2969  return count
2970def hyphenate(word,numSyls):
2971  "See mainopt_syllables"
2972  orig = word
2973  try: word,isu8 = word.decode('utf-8'),True
2974  except: isu8 = False
2975  pre=[] ; post=[]
2976  while word and not 'a'<=word[:1].lower()<='z':
2977    pre.append(word[:1]) ; word=word[1:]
2978  while word and not 'a'<=word[-1].lower()<='z':
2979    post.insert(0,word[-1:]) ; word=word[:-1]
2980  if numSyls>len(word): return orig # probably numbers or something
2981  l = int((len(word)+numSyls/2)/numSyls) ; syls = []
2982  for i in range(numSyls):
2983    if i==numSyls-1: syls.append(word[i*l:])
2984    else: syls.append(word[i*l:(i+1)*l])
2985    if len(syls)>1:
2986      if syls[-1].startswith('-') or (len(syls[-1])>2 and syls[-1][:1]==syls[-1][1:2] and not syls[-1][:1].lower() in "aeiou"):
2987        # repeated consonant at start - put one on previous
2988        # (or hyphen at start - move it to the previous)
2989        syls[-2] += syls[-1][:1]
2990        syls[-1] = syls[-1][1:]
2991      elif len(syls[-1])>2 and syls[-1][1]=='-':
2992        # better move this splitpoint after that hyphen (TODO: move more than one character?)
2993        syls[-2] += syls[-1][:2]
2994        syls[-1] = syls[-1][2:]
2995      elif ((len(syls[-2])>2 and syls[-2][-1]==syls[-2][-2] and not syls[-2][-1].lower() in "aeiou") \
2996            or (syls[-1] and syls[-1][:1].lower() in "aeiouy" and len(syls[-2])>2)) \
2997            and list(filter(lambda x:x.lower() in "aeiou",list(syls[-2][:-1]))):
2998        # repeated consonant at end - put one on next
2999        # or vowel on right: move a letter over (sometimes the right thing to do...)
3000        # (unless doing so leaves no vowels)
3001        syls[-1] = syls[-2][-1]+syls[-1]
3002        syls[-2] = syls[-2][:-1]
3003  word = ''.join(pre)+"- ".join(syls)+''.join(post)
3004  if isu8: word=word.encode('utf-8')
3005  return word
3006
3007def macSayCommand():
3008  """Return the environment variable SAY_COMMAND if it is set and if it is non-empty, otherwise return "say".
3009  E.g. SAY_COMMAND="say -o file.aiff" (TODO: document this in the help text?)
3010  In Gradint you can set (e.g. if you have a ~/.festivalrc) extra_speech=[("en","python lexconvert.py --mac-uk festival")] ; extra_speech_tofile=[("en",'echo %s | SAY_COMMAND="say -o /tmp/said.aiff" python lexconvert.py --mac-uk festival && sox /tmp/said.aiff /tmp/said.wav',"/tmp/said.wav")]"""
3011  s = os.environ.get("SAY_COMMAND","")
3012  if s: return s
3013  else: return "say"
3014
3015def stdin_is_terminal():
3016   "Returns True if it seems the standard input is connected to a terminal (rather than piped from a file etc)"
3017   return (not hasattr(sys.stdin,"isatty")) or sys.stdin.isatty()
3018
3019def getInputText(i,prompt,as_iterable=False):
3020  """Gets text either from the command line or from standard input.  Issue prompt if there's nothing on the command line and standard input is connected to a tty instead of a pipe or file.  If as_iterable, return an iterable object over the lines instead of reading and returning all text at once.  If as_iterable=='maybe', return the iterable but if not reading from a tty then read everything into one item."""
3021  txt = ' '.join(sys.argv[i:])
3022  if txt:
3023    if as_iterable=='maybe': return [txt]
3024    elif as_iterable: return txt.split('\n')
3025    else: return txt
3026  if stdin_is_terminal(): sys.stderr.write("Enter "+prompt+" (EOF when done)\n")
3027  elif as_iterable=='maybe': return [getBuf(sys.stdin).read()]
3028  if as_iterable: return my_xreadlines()
3029  else:
3030     try: return getBuf(sys.stdin).read()
3031     except KeyboardInterrupt: raise SystemExit
3032
3033try: raw_input # Python 2
3034except NameError: raw_input = input # Python 3
3035def my_xreadlines():
3036   "On some platforms this might be a bit more responsive than sys.stdin.xreadlines"
3037   while True:
3038      try: yield raw_input()
3039      except EOFError: return
3040      except KeyboardInterrupt: raise SystemExit
3041
3042def output_clauses(format,clauses):
3043   "Writes out clauses and words in format 'format' (clauses is a list of lists of words in the phones of 'format').  By default, calls markup_inline_word and join as appropriate.  If however the format's 'clause_separator' has been set to a special case, calls that."
3044   if checkSetting(format,"output_is_binary") and hasattr(sys.stdout,"isatty") and sys.stdout.isatty():
3045      print ("This is a binary format - not writing to terminal.\nPlease direct output to a file or pipe.")
3046      return
3047   clause_sep = checkSetting(format,"clause_separator","\n")
3048   if type(clause_sep) in [bytes,unicode]: getBuf(sys.stdout).write(as_utf8(clause_sep).join(as_utf8(wordSeparator(format)).join(markup_inline_word(format,word) for word in clause) for clause in clauses))
3049   else: clause_sep(clauses)
3050def write_bbcmicro_phones(clauses):
3051  """Special-case function set as clause_separator in bbcmicro format.  Must be a special case because it needs to track any extra keystrokes to avoid "Line too long".  And while we're at it, we might as well start a new *SPEAK command with each clause, using the natural brief delay between commands; this should minimise the occurrence of additional delays in arbitrary places.  Also calls print_bbc_warnings"""
3052  totalKeystrokes = 0 ; lines = 0
3053  for clause in clauses:
3054    global bbc_charsSoFar ; bbc_charsSoFar=0
3055    l=as_utf8(" ").join([markup_inline_word("bbcmicro",word) for word in clause])
3056    getBuf(sys.stdout).write(l.replace(as_utf8(" \n"),as_utf8("\n")))
3057    totalKeystrokes += len(l)+1 ; lines += 1
3058  print_bbc_warnings(totalKeystrokes,lines)
3059def print_bbc_warnings(keyCount,lineCount):
3060  "Print any relevant size warnings regarding sending 'keyCount' keys in 'lineCount' lines to the BBC Micro"
3061  sys.stdout.flush() # try to keep in sync if someone's doing 2>&1 | less
3062  limits_exceeded = [] ; severe=0
3063  if keyCount >= 32768:
3064    severe=1 ; limits_exceeded.append("BeebEm 32K keystroke limit") # At least in version 3, the clipboard is defined in beebwin.h as a char of size 32768 and its bounds are not checked.  Additionally, if you script a second paste before the first has finished (or if you try to use BeebEm's Copy command) then the first paste will be interrupted.  So if you really want to make BeebEm read more then I suggest setting a printer destination file, putting a VDU 2,10,3 after each batch of commands, and waiting for that \n to appear in that printer file before sending the next batch, or perhaps write a set of programs to a disk image and have them CHAIN each other or whatever.
3065  shadow_himem=0x8000 # if using a 'shadow mode' on the Master/B+/Integra-B (modes 128-135, which leave all main RAM free)
3066  mode7_himem=0x7c00 # (40x25 characters = 1000 bytes, by default starting at 7c00 with 24 bytes spare at the top, but the scrolling system uses the full 1024 bytes and can tell the video controller to start rendering at any one of them; if you get Jeremy Ruston's book and program the VIDC yourself then you could fix it at 7c18 if you really want, or just set HIMEM=&8000 and don't touch the screen, but that doesn't give you very much more room)
3067  default_speech_loc=0x5500
3068  overhead_per_program_line = 4
3069  for page,model in [
3070        (0x1900,"Model B"), # with Acorn DFS (a reasonable assumption although alternate DFS ROMs are different)
3071        (0xE00,"Master")]: # (the Master has 8k of special paged-in "filing system RAM", so doesn't need 2816 bytes of main RAM for DFS)
3072     top = page+keyCount+lineCount*(overhead_per_program_line-1)+2 # the -1 is because keyCount includes a carriage return at the end of each line
3073     if model=="Master": x=" (use Speech's Sideways RAM version instead, e.g. *SRLOAD SP8000 8000 7 and reset, but sound quality might be worse)" # I don't know why but SP8000 can play higher and more distorted than SPEECH, at least on emulation (and changing the emulation speed doesn't help, because that setting, at least in BeebEm3, just controls extra usleep every frame; it doesn't actually slow down the 6502 *between* frames; anyway timing of sound changes is done by CyclesToSamples stuff in beebsound.cc's SoundTrigger).  If on the Master you go into View (*WORD) and then try SP8000, it plays _lower_ than *SPEECH (even if you do *BASIC first) and *SAY can corrupt a View document; ViewSheet (*SHEET) doesn't seem to have this effect; neither does *TERMINAL but *SAY can confuse the terminal.
3074     # Re bank numbers, by default banks 4 to 7 are Sideways RAM (4*16k=64k) and I suppose filling up from 7 makes sense because banks 8-F are ROMs (ANFS,DFS,ViewSheet,Edit,BASIC,ADFS,View,Terminal; OS is a separate 16k so there's scope for 144k of supplied ROM).  Banks 0-3 are ROM expansion slots.  The "128" in the name "Master 128" comes from 32k main RAM, 64k Sideways RAM, 20k shadow RAM (for screen modes 128-135), 4k OS "private RAM" (paged on top of 8000-8FFF) and 8k filing system RAM (paged on top of C000-DFFF) = 128k.  Not sure what happened on the B+.
3075     # By the way BeebEm's beebsound.cc also shows us why SOUND was always out of tune especially in the higher pitches.  The 16-bit freqval given to the chip is 125000/freq and must be an integer, so the likely temperament in cents for non-PCM is given by [int(math.log(125000.0/math.ceil(125000/freq)/freq,2**(1.0/1200))) for freq in [440*((2**(1.0/12))**semi) for semi in range(-12*3+2,12*2+6)]] (the actual temperament will depend on the OS's implementation of mapping SOUND pitch values to freqval's, unless you program the chip directly, but this list is indicative and varies over 10% in the top 2 octaves)
3076     # Some other ROMs (e.g. Alan Blundell's "Informant" 1989) seem to result in a crash after the *SPEECH and/or *SPEAK commands complete, at least in some emulator configurations; this may or may not be resolved via timing adjustments or adjustments in the ROM order; not sure exactly what the problem is
3077     else: x=" (Speech program will be overwritten unless relocated)" # (could use Sideways RAM for it instead if you have it fitted, see above)
3078     if top > default_speech_loc: limits_exceeded.append("%s TOP=&%X limit%s" % (model,default_speech_loc,x)) # The Speech program does nothing to stop your program (or its variables etc) from growing large enough to overwrite &5500, nor does it stop the stack pointer (coming down from HIMEM) from overwriting &72FF. For more safety on a Model B you could use RELOCAT to put Speech at &5E00 and be sure to set HIMEM=&5E00 before loading, but then you must avoid commands that change HIMEM, such as MODE (but selecting any non-shadow mode other than 7 will overwrite Speech anyway, although if you set the mode before loading Speech then it'll overwrite screen memory and still work as long as the affected part of the screen is undisturbed).  You can't do tricks like ditching the lexicon because RELOCAT won't let you go above 5E00 (unless you fix it, but I haven't looked in detail; if you can fix RELOCAT to go above 5E00 then you can create a lexicon-free Speech by taking the 1st 0x1560 bytes of SPEECH and append two * bytes, relocate to &6600 and set HIMEM, but don't expect *SAY to work, unless you put a really small lexicon into the spare 144 bytes that are left - RELOCAT needs an xx00 address so you can't have those bytes at the bottom).  You could even relocate to &6A00 and overwrite (non-shadow) screen memory if you don't mind the screen being filled with gibberish that you'd better not erase! (well if you program the VIDC as mentioned above and you didn't re-add a small lexicon then you could get yourself 3.6 lines of usable Mode 7 display from the spare bytes but it's probably not worth the effort)
3079     if top > mode7_himem:
3080        if model=="Master":
3081           if top > shadow_himem: limits_exceeded.append(model+" 32k HIMEM limit (even for shadow modes)") # TODO: maybe add instructions for using BAS128 on the B+ or Master; this sets PAGE=&10000 and HIMEM=&20000 (i.e. 64k for programs), which uses all 4 SRAM slots so you can't use SP8000 (unless it's on a real ROM); if using Speech in main memory you need to RELOCAT it to leave &3000 upwards for Bas128 code; putting it at &1900 for B+/DFS leaves you only 417 bytes for lexicon (which might not matter if you're using only *SPEECH: just create a shortened lexicon); putting it at &E00 for Master allows space for the default 2204-byte lexicon with 1029 bytes to spare; TODO check if Bas128 uses any workspace between &E00 and &3000 though.  Alternatively (if you really want to store such a long program on the BBC) then you'd better split it into several programs that CHAIN each other (as mentioned above).
3082           else: limits_exceeded.append(model+" Mode 7 HIMEM limit (use shadow modes 128-135)")
3083        else: limits_exceeded.append(model+" Mode 7 HIMEM limit") # unless you overwrite the screen (see above) - let's assume the Model B hasn't been fitted with shadow modes (although the Integra-B add-on does give them to the Model B, and leaves PAGE at &1900; B+ has shadow modes but I don't know what's supposed to happen to PAGE on it).  65C02 Tube doesn't help much (it'll try to run Speech on the coprocessor instead of the host, and this results in silence because it can't send its sound back across the Tube; don't know if there's a way to make it run on the host in these circumstances or what the host's memory map is like)
3084  if lineCount > 32768: limits_exceeded.append("BBC BASIC line number limit") # and you wouldn't get this far without filling the memory, even with 128k (4 bytes per line)
3085  elif 10*lineCount > 32767: limits_exceeded.append("AUTO line number limit (try AUTO 0,1)") # (default AUTO increments in steps of 10; you can use AUTO 0,1 to start at 0 and increment in steps of 1.  BBC BASIC stores its line info in a compact form which allows a range of 0-32767.)
3086  if severe: warning,after="WARNING: ",""
3087  else: warning,after="Note: ","It should still work if pasted into BeebEm as immediate commands. "
3088  after = ". "+after+"See comments in lexconvert for more details.\n"
3089  if len(limits_exceeded)>1: sys.stderr.write(warning+"this text may be too big for the BBC Micro. The following limits were exceeded: "+", ".join(limits_exceeded)+after)
3090  elif limits_exceeded: sys.stderr.write(warning+"this text may be too big for the BBC Micro because it exceeds the "+limits_exceeded[0]+after)
3091def bbc_prepDefaultLex(outFile):
3092  """Special-case function set as lex_header in bbcmicro format.  If SPEECH_DISK and MAKE_SPEECH_ROM is set, then read the ROM code from SPEECH_DISK and write to outFile (meant to go before the lexicon, to make a modified BBC Micro Speech ROM with custom lexicon)"""
3093  if not os.environ.get("MAKE_SPEECH_ROM",0): return
3094  sd = open(os.environ['SPEECH_DISK'], encoding='utf-8')
3095  d=getBuf(sd).read() # if this fails, SPEECH_DISK was not set or was set incorrectly (it's required for MAKE_SPEECH_ROM)
3096  i=d.index(as_utf8('LO')+chr(0x80)+as_utf8('LP')+chr(0x80)+chr(0x82)+chr(0x11)) # start of SP8000 file (if this fails, it wasn't a Speech disk)
3097  j=d.index(as_utf8('>OUS_'),i) # start of lexicon (ditto)
3098  assert j-i==0x1683, "Is this really an original disk image?"
3099  getBuf(outFile).write(d[i:j])
3100def bbc_appendDefaultLex(outFile):
3101  """Special-case function set as lex_footer in bbcmicro format.  If SPEECH_DISK is set, read Speech's default lexicon from it and append this to outFile.  Otherwise just write a terminating >** to outFile.  In either case, check for exceeding 16k if we're MAKE_SPEECH_ROM, close the file and call print_bbclex_instructions."""
3102  if os.environ.get("SPEECH_DISK",""):
3103     sd = open(os.environ['SPEECH_DISK'], encoding='utf-8')
3104     d=getBuf(sd).read()
3105     i=d.index(as_utf8('>OUS_')) # if this fails, it wasn't a Speech disk
3106     j=d.index(as_utf8(">**"),i)
3107     assert j-i==2201, "Lexicon on SPEECH_DISK is wrong size (%d). Is this really an original disk image?" % (j-i)
3108     getBuf(outFile).write(d[i:j])
3109     # TODO: can we compress the BBC lexicon?  i.e. detect if a rule will happen anyway due to subsequent wildcard rules, and delete it if so (don't know how many bytes that would save)
3110  outFile.write(">**")
3111  fileLen = outFile.tell()
3112  assert not os.environ.get("MAKE_SPEECH_ROM",0) or fileLen <= 16384, "Speech ROM file got too big (%d)" % fileLen
3113  outFile.close()
3114  print_bbclex_instructions(getSetting("bbcmicro","lex_filename"),fileLen)
3115
3116def bbcshortest(n):
3117  """Convert integer n into the shortest possible number of BBC Micro keystrokes; prefer hex if and only if the extra '&' keystroke won't make it any longer than its decimal equivalent"""
3118  if len(str(n)) < len('&%X'%n): return as_utf8(str(n))
3119  else: return as_utf8('&%X'%n)
3120def bbcKeystrokes(data,start):
3121  "Return BBC BASIC keystrokes to put data into RAM starting at address start, without using the BASIC heap in the process (although we do use one of the page-4 integer variables to save some keystrokes).  Assumes the data is mostly ASCII so the $ operator is the least-keystrokes method of getting it in (rather than ? and ! operators, assembler EQUB/EQUW/EQUS, 6502 mnemonics, etc); we don't mind about overwriting the byte after with a CHR$(13).  Keystrokes are limited to ASCII for easier copy/paste.  See comments for more details."
3122  # Taken to the extreme, a 'find the least keystrokes' function would be some kind of data compressor; we're not doing that here as we assume this is going to be used to poke in a lexicon, which is basically ASCII with a few CHR$(128)s thrown in; this '$ operator' method is highly likely to yield the least keystrokes for that kind of data, apart from setting and using temporary string variables, but then (1) you're in the realms of data compression and (2) you require heap memory, which might not be a good idea depending on where we're putting our lexicon.
3123  # I suppose it wouldn't hurt in most cases to have an A$=CHR$(128), but not doing this for now because you might be in a situation where you can't touch the heap at all (I'm not sure where the workspace for assembling strings is though).
3124  # However, just to be pedantic about saving a few bytes, there is one thing we CAN do: if we have a lexicon with a lot of CHR$(128)s in it, let's set up BASIC's page-4 integer variables such that $A%=CHR$(128), saving 6 keystrokes per entry without needing the heap (an additional 1 keystroke per entry could be saved if we didn't mind putting an A$ on the heap).
3125  use_int_hack = ((start>=1030 or start+len(data)<=1026) and len(data.split(chr(128))) >= 4)
3126  i=0 ; ret=[]
3127  if use_int_hack: thisLine = as_utf8("A%=&408:B%=&D80:") # (@% is at &400 and each is 4 byte LSB-MSB; $x reads to next 0D)
3128  # (If we're guaranteed to NOT be using Bas128 and therefore all memory addresses are effectively masked by &FFFF, we can instead set A%=&D800406 (using A%'s low 2 bytes to point to A%'s high 2 bytes) for a 1-off saving of 5 keystrokes and 1 page-4 variable, but this saving is not really worth the readability compromise and the risk posed by the possibility of Bas128 - I don't know how Bas128 treats addresses above &1FFFF)
3129  # (An even 'nastier' trick would be to put !13=&D80 and then use $13, as those bytes are used by BASIC's random number generator, which presumably isn't called during the paste and we don't mind disrupting it; again I don't know about Bas128.  But you can't do it because BASIC gives a "$ range" error on anything below 256.)
3130  # (I suppose one thing you _could_ do is LOMEM=&400:A$=CHR$(13) and end with LOMEM=TOP, which would overwrite 3 page-4 variables and let you use just A$ instead of $A%, saving keystrokes over A%=&D800406 after 21 more lexicon words, at the expense of losing track of any variables you had on the heap.  But this is getting silly.)
3131  else: thisLine = as_utf8("")
3132  bbc_max_line_len = 238
3133  inQuote=needPlus=0 ; needCmd=1
3134  while i<len(data):
3135    if needCmd:
3136       thisLine += (as_utf8('$')+bbcshortest(start)+as_utf8('='))
3137       inQuote=needPlus=needCmd=0
3138    if data[i:i+1]==as_utf8('"'): c,inQ = as_utf8('""'),1 # inQ MUST be 0 or 1, not False/True, because it's also used as 'len of necessary close quote' below
3139    elif 32<=ord(data[i:i+1])<127: c,inQ = data[i:i+1],1
3140    elif use_int_hack and ord(data[i:i+1])==128: c,inQ=as_utf8("$A%"),0
3141    else: c,inQ=(as_utf8("CHR$("+str(ord(data[i:i+1]))+")")),0
3142    addToLine = [] ; newNeedPlus = needPlus
3143    if inQ and not inQuote:
3144       if needPlus: addToLine.append(as_utf8('+'))
3145       addToLine.append(as_utf8('"'))
3146       newNeedPlus=0
3147    elif inQuote and not inQ:
3148       addToLine.append(as_utf8('"+'))
3149       newNeedPlus=1 # after what we'll add
3150    elif not inQ:
3151       if needPlus: addToLine.append(as_utf8('+'))
3152       newNeedPlus=1 # after what we'll add
3153    addToLine.append(c)
3154    addToLine=as_utf8('').join(addToLine)
3155    if len(thisLine)+len(addToLine)+inQ > bbc_max_line_len: # oops, we've gone too far, back off and end prev line
3156       if inQuote: thisLine += as_utf8('"')
3157       ret.append(thisLine)
3158       thisLine=as_utf8("") ; needCmd=1 ; continue
3159    thisLine += addToLine ; inQuote=inQ
3160    needPlus=newNeedPlus ; i += 1 ; start += 1
3161  if inQuote: thisLine += as_utf8('"')
3162  if not needCmd: ret.append(thisLine)
3163  return as_utf8('\n').join(ret)+as_utf8('\n')
3164def print_bbclex_instructions(fname,size):
3165 """Print suitable instructions for a BBC Micro lexicon of the given filename and size (the exact nature of the instructions depends on the size).  If appropriate, create a .key file containing keystrokes for transferring to an emulator."""
3166 if os.environ.get("MAKE_SPEECH_ROM",0): print ("%s (%d bytes, hex %X) can now installed on an emulator (set in Roms.cfg or whatever), or loaded onto a chip.  The sound quality of this might be worse than that of the main-RAM version." % (fname,size,size)) # (at least on emulation - see comment on sound quality above)
3167 else:
3168  print ("The size of this lexicon is %d bytes (hex %X)" % (size,size)) # (the default lexicon is 2204 bytes)
3169  bbcStart=None
3170  noSRAM_lex_offset=0x155F # (on the BBC Micro, SRAM means Sideways RAM, not Static RAM as it does elsewhere; for clarity we'd better say "Sideways RAM" in all output)
3171  SRAM_lex_offset=0x1683
3172  SRAM_max=0x4000 # 16k
3173  noSRAM_default_addr=0x5500
3174  noSRAM_min_addr=0xE00 # minimum supported by RELOCAT
3175  page=0x1900 # or 0xE00 for Master (but OK to just leave this at 0x1900 regardless of model; it harmlessly increases the range where special_relocate_instructions 'kick in')
3176  noSRAM_himem=0x7c00 # unless you're in a shadow mode or something (see comments on himem above), however leaving this at 0x7c00 is usually harmless (just causes the 'need to relocate' to 'kick in' earlier, although if memory is really full it might say 'too big' 1k too early)
3177  def special_relocate_instructions(reloc_addr):
3178    pagemove_min,pagemove_max = max(0xE00,page-0x1E00), page+0xE00 # if relocating to within this range, must move PAGE before loading RELOCAT. RELOCAT's supported range is 0xE00 to 0x5E00, omitting (PAGE-&1E00) to (PAGE+&E00)
3179    if reloc_addr < 0x1900: extra=" On a Model B with Acorn DFS you won't be able to use the disk after relocating below &1900, and you can't run star commands from tape so you have to initialise via CALL. (On a Master, DFS is not affected as it doesn't use &E00-&1900.)"
3180    else: extra = ""
3181    if not pagemove_min<=reloc_addr<pagemove_max:
3182      return extra # no other special instructions needed
3183    newpage = reloc_addr+0x1E00
3184    page_max = min(0x5E00,noSRAM_default_addr-0xE00)
3185    if newpage > page_max: return False # "Unfortunately RELOCAT can't put it at &%X even with PAGE changes." % reloc_addr
3186    return " Please run RELOCAT with PAGE in the range of &%X to &%X for this relocation to work.%s" % (newpage,page_max,extra)
3187  if noSRAM_default_addr+noSRAM_lex_offset+size > noSRAM_himem:
3188    reloc_addr = noSRAM_himem-noSRAM_lex_offset-size
3189    reloc_addr -= (reloc_addr%256)
3190    if reloc_addr >= noSRAM_min_addr:
3191      instr = special_relocate_instructions(reloc_addr)
3192      if instr==False: print ("This lexicon is too big for Speech in main RAM even with relocation, unless RELOCAT is rewritten to work from files.")
3193      else:
3194        bbcStart = reloc_addr+noSRAM_lex_offset
3195        reloc_call = reloc_addr + 0xB00
3196        print ("This lexicon is too big for Speech at its default address of &%X, but you could use RELOCAT to put a version at &%X and then initialise it with CALL %s (or do the suggested *SAVE, reset, and run *SP). Be sure to set HIMEM=&%X. Then *LOAD %s %X or change the relocated SP file from offset &%X.%s" % (noSRAM_default_addr,reloc_addr,bbcshortest(reloc_call),reloc_addr,fname,bbcStart,noSRAM_lex_offset,instr))
3197    else: print ("This lexicon is too big for Speech in main RAM even with relocation.")
3198  else: # fits at default location - no relocation needed
3199    bbcStart = noSRAM_default_addr+noSRAM_lex_offset
3200    print ("You can load this lexicon by *LOAD %s %X or change the SPEECH file from offset &%X. Suggest you also set HIMEM=&%X for safety." % (fname,bbcStart,noSRAM_lex_offset,noSRAM_default_addr))
3201  if bbcStart: # we managed to fit it into main RAM
3202     f = open(fname, encoding='utf-8')
3203     keys = bbcKeystrokes(getBuf(f).read(),bbcStart)
3204     f = open(fname+".key","w", encoding='utf-8')
3205     getBuf(f).write(keys)
3206     del f
3207     print ("For ease of transfer to emulators etc, a self-contained keystroke file for putting %s data at &%X has been written to %s.key" % (fname,bbcStart,fname))
3208     if len(keys) > 32767: print ("(This file looks too big for BeebEm to paste though)") # see comments elsewhere
3209  # Instructions for replacing lex in SRAM:
3210  if size > SRAM_max-SRAM_lex_offset: print ("This lexicon is too big for Speech in Sideways RAM.") # unless you can patch Speech to run in SRAM but read its lexicon from main RAM, or run in main RAM but page in multiple banks of SRAM for the lexicon (but even then there'll be a limit)
3211  else: print ("You can load this lexicon into Sideways RAM by *SRLOAD %s %X 7 (or whichever bank number you're using), or change the SP8000 file from offset &%X." % (fname,SRAM_lex_offset+0x8000,SRAM_lex_offset))
3212  if not os.environ.get("SPEECH_DISK",""): print ("If you want to append the default lexicon to this one, set SPEECH_DISK to the image of the original Speech disk before running lexconvert, e.g. export SPEECH_DISK=/usr/local/BeebEm3/diskimg/Speech.ssd")
3213  if size <= SRAM_max-SRAM_lex_offset: print ("You can also set MAKE_SPEECH_ROM=1 (along with SPEECH_DISK) to create a SPEECH.ROM file instead")
3214 print ("If you get 'Mistake in speech' when testing some words, try starting with '*SAY, ' (this seems to be a Speech bug)") # - can't track down which words it does and doesn't apply to
3215 print ("It might be better to load your lexicon into eSpeak and use lexconvert's --phones option to drive the BBC with phonemes.")
3216
3217def mainopt_version(i):
3218   # TODO: doc string for the help? (or would this option clutter it needlessly) - just print lexconvert's version number and nothing else
3219   print (__doc__.split("\n")[0].split(" - ")[0])
3220
3221def main():
3222    """Introspect the module to find the mainopt_ functions, and either call one of them or print the help.  Returns the error code to send back to the OS."""
3223    def funcToOpt(n): return "--"+n[n.index("_")+1:].replace("_","-")
3224    for k,v in globals().items():
3225        if k.startswith('mainopt_') and funcToOpt(k) in sys.argv:
3226           try: msg = v(sys.argv.index(funcToOpt(k)))
3227           except Message:
3228              # Python 2.6+ can have "except Message as e",
3229              # but Python 2.5 has to have "except Message,e"
3230              # which is disallowed in Python 3, so
3231              msg=sys.exc_info()[1].message
3232           if msg:
3233              sys.stdout.flush()
3234              sys.stderr.write(msg+"\n") ; return 1
3235           else: return 0
3236    html = ('--htmlhelp' in sys.argv) # (undocumented option used for my website, don't rely on it staying)
3237    def htmlify(h): return re.sub('(--[2A-Za-z-]*)',r'<kbd>\1</kbd>',h.replace('&','&amp;').replace('<','&lt;').replace('>','&gt;').replace('\n','<br>'))
3238    if not html: htmlify = lambda x:x
3239    print (htmlify(__doc__))
3240    if html: missALine = "<p>"
3241    else: missALine = ""
3242    print (missALine)
3243    if '--formats' in sys.argv: # non-HTML mode only (format descriptions are included in HTML anyway, and don't worry about the capability summary)
3244       print ("Available pronunciation formats (and support levels):")
3245       keys=list(lexFormats.keys()) ; keys.sort()
3246       for k in keys:
3247          types = []
3248          if not k=="example": types.append("phones")
3249          if k=="mac-uk": types.append("speaking")
3250          else:
3251             if checkSetting(k,"lex_read_function"): types.append("lex-read")
3252             if checkSetting(k,"lex_filename") and checkSetting(k,"lex_entry_format"):
3253                ltype = checkSetting(k,"lex_type")
3254                if ltype: ltype=" as "+ltype
3255                types.append("lex-write"+ltype)
3256          print ("\n"+k+" ("+", ".join(types)+")")
3257          print (getSetting(k,"doc"))
3258       return 0
3259    elif html:
3260       print ("Available pronunciation formats:")
3261       if html: print ('<table id="formats">')
3262       keys=list(lexFormats.keys()) ; keys.sort()
3263       for k in keys: print ('<tr><td valign="top"><nobr>'+k+'</nobr></td><td valign="top">'+htmlify(getSetting(k,"doc"))+"</td></tr>")
3264       print ("</table><script><!-- try to be more readable on some smartphones\nif(((screen && screen.width<600) || navigator.userAgent.slice(-6)==\"Gecko/\" /* UC Browser? */) && document.getElementById && document.getElementById('formats').outerHTML) document.getElementById('formats').outerHTML = document.getElementById('formats').outerHTML.replace(/<table/g,'<dl').replace(/<.table/g,'<'+'/dl').replace(/<tr><td/g,'<dt').replace(/<.td><td/g,'<'+'/dt><dd').replace(/<.td><.tr/g,'<'+'/dd');\n//--></script>")
3265    else: print ("Available pronunciation formats: "+", ".join(sorted(list(lexFormats.keys())))+"\n(Use --formats to see their descriptions)")
3266    print (missALine)
