1842  "pinyin-approx" : makeDic(
1843    "Rough approximation using roughly the spelling rules of Chinese Pinyin (for getting Chinese-only voices to speak some English words - works with some words better than others)", # write-only for now
1844    ('4',primary_stress),
1845    ('2',secondary_stress),
1846    ('a5',a_as_in_ah),
1847    ('ya5',a_as_in_apple),
1848    ('e5',u_as_in_but),
1849    ('yo5',o_as_in_orange),
1850    ('ao5',o_as_in_now),
1851    (e_as_in_herd,'e5',False),
1852    ('ai5',eye),
1853    ('bu0',b),
1854    ('che0',ch),
1855    ('de0',d),
1856    ('ze0',th_as_in_them),
1857    ('ye5',e_as_in_them),
1858    (a_as_in_air,'ye5',False),
1859    ('ei5',a_as_in_ate),
1860    ('fu0',f),
1861    ('ge0',g),
1862    ('he0',h),
1863    ('yi5',i_as_in_it),
1864    ('yi3re5',ear),
1865    (e_as_in_eat,'yi5',False),
1866    ('zhe0',j_as_in_jump),
1867    ('ke0',k),
1868    ('le0',l),
1869    ('me0',m),
1870    ('ne0',n),
1871    ('eng0',ng),
1872    ('ou5',o_as_in_go),
1873    ('ruo2yi5',oy_as_in_toy),
1874    ('pu0',p),
1875    ('re0',r),
1876    ('se0',s),
1877    ('she0',sh),
1878    ('te0',t),
1879    (th_as_in_think,'zhe0',False),
1880    (oor_as_in_poor,'wu5',False),
1881    ('yu5',oo_as_in_food),
1882    ('huo5',close_to_or),
1883    (v,'fu0',False),
1884    ('wu0',w),
1885    ('yu0',y),
1886    (z,'ze0',False),
1887    (ge_of_blige_etc,'zhe0',False),
1888    approximate_missing=True,
1889    lex_filename="words-pinyin-approx.txt", # write-only for now
1890    lex_type = "text",
1891    lex_header = "Pinyin approxmations (very approximate!)\n----------------------------------------\n",
1892    lex_entry_format = "%s ~= %s\n",
1893    word_separator=" ",phoneme_separator="",
1894    cleanup_regexps=[
1895      ("te0ye","tie"),
1896      ("e0e5","e5"),("([^aeiou][uo])0e(5)",r"\1\2"),
1897      ("yu0y","y"),
1898      ("wu0yo5","wo5"),
1899      ("([bdfghklmnpwz])[euo]0ei",r"\1ei"),
1900      ("([bdghklmnpstwz])[euo]0ai",r"\1ai"),
1901      ("([ghklmnpstyz])[euo]0ya",r"\1a"),("([ghklmnpstz])a([0-5]*)ne0",r"\1an\2"),
1902      ("([bdfghklmnpstwyz])[euo]0a([1-5])",r"\1a\2"),
1903      ("([bdjlmnpt])[euo]0yi",r"\1i"),("([bjlmnp])i([1-5]*)ne0",r"\1in\2"),
1904      ("([zs])he0ei",r"\1hei"),
1905      ("([dfghklmnprstyz])[euo]0ou",r"\1ou"),
1906      ("([dghklnrst])[euo]0huo",r"\1uo"),
1907      ("([bfpm])[euo]0huo",r"\1o"),
1908      ("([bdghklmnprstyz])[euo]0ao",r"\1ao"),
1909      ("([zcs])h[eu]0ao",r"\1hao"),
1910      ("re0r","r"),
1911      ("zhe0ne0","zhun5"),
1912      ("54","4"),
1913      ("52","2"),
1914      ("([bdjlmnpty])i([1-9])eng0",r"\1ing\2"),
1915      ("ya([1-9])eng0",r"yang\1"),
1916      ("ya([1-9])ne0",r"an\1"),
1917      ("ye([1-9])ne0",r"yan\1"),("([wr])[eu]0yan",r"\1en"),
1918      ("yi([1-9])ne0",r"yin\1"),
1919      
1920      ("yu0","yu5"),("eng0","eng5"), # they won't work unvoiced anyway
1921      ("0","5"), # comment out if the synth supports 'tone 0 for unvoiced'
1922      #("[euo]0","0"), # comment in if it expects consonants only when doing that
1923    ],
1924  ),
1925
1926  "kana-approx" : makeDic(
1927  "Rough approximation using kana (for getting Japanese computer voices to speak some English words - works with some words better than others).  Set KANA_TYPE environment variable to hiragana or katakana (which can affect the sounds of some voices); default is hiragana", # for example on Mac OS 10.7+ (with Japanese voice installed in System Preferences) try PHONES_PIPE_COMMAND='say -v Kyoko' (this voice has a built-in converter from English as well, but lexconvert --phones kana-approx can work better with some complex words, although the built-in converter does seem to have access to slightly more phonemes and can therefore produce words like "to" better).  Default is hiragana because I find hiragana easier to read than katakana, although the Kyoko voice does seem to be able to say 'v' a little better when using kata.  Mac OS 10.7+'s Korean voices (Yuna and Narae) can also read kana, and you could try doing a makeVariantDic and adding in some Korean jamo letters for them (you'd be pushed to represent everything in jamo but kana+jamo seems more hopeful in theory), but again some words work better than others (not all phonetic combinations are supported and some words aren't clear at all).
1928    # This kana-approx format is 'write-only' for now (see comment in cleanup_regexps re possible reversal)
1929    (u'\u30fc',primary_stress),
1930    (secondary_stress,ifset('KANA_MORE_EMPH',u'\u30fc'),False), # set KANA_MORE_EMPH environment variable if you want to try doubling the secondary-stressed vowels as well (doesn't always work very well; if it did, I'd put this line in a makeVariantDic called kana-approx-moreEmph or something)
1931    # The following Unicode codepoints are hiragana; KANA_TYPE is handled by cleanup_func below
1932    (u'\u3042',a_as_in_apple),
1933    (u'\u3044',e_as_in_eat),
1934    (u'\u3046',oo_as_in_food),
1935    (u'\u3048',e_as_in_them),
1936    (u'\u304a',o_as_in_orange),
1937    (u'\u3042\u3044',eye), # ai
1938    (u'\u3042\u304a',o_as_in_now), # ao
1939    (u'\u3048\u3044',a_as_in_ate), # ei
1940    (u'\u304a\u3044',oy_as_in_toy), # oi
1941    (u'\u304a\u3046',o_as_in_go), # ou
1942    (a_as_in_ah,u'\u3042',False),
1943    (a_as_in_ago,u'\u3046\u304a',False), # TODO: \u3042, \u304a or \u3046 depending on the word?
1944    (e_as_in_herd,u'\u3042',False), # TODO: really?
1945    (i_as_in_it,u'\u3044',False), # TODO: really?
1946    (u_as_in_but,u'\u3046',False), # TODO: really?
1947    (ar_as_in_year,u'\u3048',False), # TODO: really?
1948    (ear,u'\u3044\u304a',False), # TODO: really?
1949    (a_as_in_air,u'\u3048',False), # TODO: really?
1950    (oor_as_in_poor,u'\u304a',False), # TODO: really?
1951    (close_to_or,u'\u304a\u30fc'), # TODO: really?
1952    (u'\u3076',b), # bu (with vowel replacements later)
1953    (u'\u3061\u3047',ch), # chu (ditto)
1954    (u'\u3065',d), # du (and so on)
1955    (u'\u3066\u3085',th_as_in_think), (th_as_in_them,u'\u3066\u3085',False),
1956    (u'\u3075',f),
1957    (u'\u3050',g),
1958    (u'\u306f',h), # ha (as hu == fu)
1959    (u'\u3058\u3085',j_as_in_jump), (ge_of_blige_etc,u'\u3058\u3085',False),
1960    (u'\u304f',k),
1961    (u'\u308b',l), (r,u'\u308b',False),
1962    (u'\u3080',m),
1963    (u'\u306c',n),
1964    (u'\u3093\u3050',ng),
1965    (u'\u3077',p),
1966    (u'\u3059',s),
1967    (u'\u3057\u3085',sh),
1968    (u'\u3064',t),
1969    (u'\u308f',w), # use 'wa' (as 'wu' == 'u')
1970    (v,ifset('KANA_V_AS_W',u'\u308f',u'\u3094'),False), # TODO: document KANA_V_AS_W variable.  Is vu always supported? (it doesn't seem to show up in all fonts)
1971    (u'\u3086',y),
1972    (u'\u305a',z),
1973    lex_filename="words-kana-approx.txt",
1974    lex_type = "text",
1975    lex_header = "Kana approxmations (very approximate!)\n--------------------------------------\n",
1976    lex_entry_format = "%s ~= %s\n",
1977    word_separator=" ",phoneme_separator="",
1978    clause_separator=u"\u3002\n".encode('utf-8'),
1979    cleanup_regexps=[(u"\u306c$",u"\u3093\u30fc"), # TODO: or u"\u3093\u3093" ?
1980       # now the vowel replacements (bu+a -> ba, etc) (in most cases these can be reversed into cvtOut_regexps if you want to use the kana-approx table to convert hiragana into approximate English phonemes (plus add a (u"\u3093\u30fc*",u"\u306c") and perhaps de-doubling rules to convert back to emphasis) but the result is unlikely to be any good)
1981       (u"\u3076\u3042",u"\u3070"),(u"\u3076\u3044",u"\u3073"),(u"\u3076\u3048",u"\u3079"),(u"\u3076\u304a",u"\u307c"),(u"\u3076\u3046",u"\u3076"),
1982       (u"\u3061\u3085\u3042",u"\u3061\u3083"),(u"\u3061\u3085\u3046",u"\u3061\u3085"),(u"\u3061\u3085\u3048",u"\u3061\u3047"),(u"\u3061\u3085\u304a",u"\u3061\u3087"),(u"\u3061\u3085\u3044",u"\u3061"),
1983       (u"\u3065\u3042",u"\u3060"),(u"\u3065\u3044",u"\u3062"),(u"\u3065\u3048",u"\u3067"),(u"\u3065\u304a",u"\u3069"),(u"\u3065\u3046",u"\u3065"),
1984       (u"\u3066\u3085\u3042",u"\u3066\u3083"),(u"\u3066\u3085\u3044",u"\u3066\u3043"),(u"\u3066\u3043\u3046",u"\u3066\u3085"),(u"\u3066\u3085\u3048",u"\u3066\u3047"),(u"\u3066\u3085\u304a",u"\u3066\u3087"),
1985       (u"\u3075\u3042",u"\u3075\u3041"),(u"\u3075\u3044",u"\u3075\u3043"),(u"\u3075\u3048",u"\u3075\u3047"),(u"\u3075\u304a",u"\u3075\u3049"),(u"\u3075\u3046",u"\u3075"),
1986       (u"\u306f\u3044",u"\u3072"),(u"\u306f\u3046",u"\u3075"),(u"\u306f\u3048",u"\u3078"),(u"\u306f\u304a",u"\u307b"),(u"\u306f\u3042",u"\u306f"),
1987       (u"\u3050\u3042",u"\u304c"),(u"\u3050\u3044",u"\u304e"),(u"\u3050\u3048",u"\u3052"),(u"\u3050\u304a",u"\u3054"),(u"\u3050\u3046",u"\u3050"),
1988       (u"\u3058\u3085\u3042",u"\u3058\u3083"),(u"\u3058\u3085\u3046",u"\u3058\u3085"),(u"\u3058\u3085\u3048",u"\u3058\u3047"),(u"\u3058\u3085\u304a",u"\u3058\u3087"),(u"\u3058\u3085\u304a",u"\u3058"),
1989       (u"\u304f\u3042",u"\u304b"),(u"\u304f\u3044",u"\u304d"),(u"\u304f\u3048",u"\u3051"),(u"\u304f\u304a",u"\u3053"),(u"\u304f\u3046",u"\u304f"),
1990       (u"\u308b\u3042",u"\u3089"),(u"\u308b\u3044",u"\u308a"),(u"\u308b\u3048",u"\u308c"),(u"\u308b\u304a",u"\u308d"),(u"\u308b\u3046",u"\u308b"),
1991       (u"\u3080\u3042",u"\u307e"),(u"\u3080\u3044",u"\u307f"),(u"\u3080\u3048",u"\u3081"),(u"\u3080\u304a",u"\u3082"),(u"\u3080\u3046",u"\u3080"),
1992       (u"\u306c\u3042",u"\u306a"),(u"\u306c\u3044",u"\u306b"),(u"\u306c\u3048",u"\u306d"),(u"\u306c\u304a",u"\u306e"),(u"\u306c\u3046",u"\u306c"),
1993       (u"\u3077\u3042",u"\u3071"),(u"\u3077\u3044",u"\u3074"),(u"\u3077\u3048",u"\u307a"),(u"\u3077\u304a",u"\u307d"),(u"\u3077\u3046",u"\u3077"),
1994       (u"\u3059\u3042",u"\u3055"),(u"\u3059\u3048",u"\u305b"),(u"\u3059\u304a",u"\u305d"),(u"\u3059\u3046",u"\u3059"),
1995       (u"\u3057\u3085\u3042",u"\u3057\u3083"),(u"\u3057\u3085\u3046",u"\u3057\u3085"),(u"\u3057\u3085\u3048",u"\u3057\u3047"),(u"\u3057\u3085\u304a",u"\u3057\u3087"),(u"\u3057\u3085\u3044",u"\u3057"),
1996       (u"\u3064\u3042",u"\u305f"),(u"\u3064\u3044",u"\u3061"),(u"\u3064\u3048",u"\u3066"),(u"\u3064\u304a",u"\u3068"),(u"\u3064\u3046",u"\u3064"),
1997       (u"\u3086\u3042",u"\u3084"),(u"\u3086\u3048",u"\u3044\u3047"),(u"\u3086\u304a",u"\u3088"),(u"\u3086\u3046",u"\u3086"),
1998       (u"\u305a\u3042",u"\u3056"),(u"\u305a\u3044",u"\u3058"),(u"\u305a\u3048",u"\u305c"),(u"\u305a\u304a",u"\u305e"),(u"\u305a\u3046",u"\u305a"),
1999       (u"\u308f\u3044",u"\u3046\u3043"),(u"\u308f\u3046",u"\u3046"),(u"\u308f\u3048",u"\u3046\u3047"),(u"\u308f\u304a",u"\u3092"),(u"\u308f\u3042",u"\u308f"),
2000       (u'\u3046\u3043\u3066\u3085', u'\u3046\u3043\u3065'), # sounds a bit better for words like 'with'
2001       (u'\u3085\u3046',u'\u3085'), # and 'the' (especially with a_as_in_ago mapping to u'\u3046\u304a'; it's hard to get a convincing 'the' though, especially in isolation)
2002       (u'\u3050\u3050',u'\u3050'), # gugu -> gu, sometimes comes up with 'gl-' combinations
2003       (u'\u30fc\u30fc+',u'\u30fc'), # in case we put 30fc in the table AND a stress mark has been applied to it
2004       (u'^(.)$',u'\\1\u30fc'), # lengthen any word that ends up as a single kana (otherwise can be clipped badly)
2005    (u'^([\u3042\u3070\u3060\u304c\u304b\u3089\u307e\u306a\u3071\u3055\u305f\u3084\u3056\u308f]\u3044)$',u'\\1\u30fc'), # ditto for -ai (TODO: -ao might need lengthening sometimes?? depends on context.  -ei, -oi, -ou seem OK)
2006    ],
2007    cleanup_func = hiragana_to_katakana
2008  ),
2009  "names" : makeDic(
2010    "Lexconvert internal phoneme names (sometimes useful with the --phones option while developing new formats)",
2011     *[(phName,phVal) for phName,phVal in phonemes.items()])}

Makes the phoneme conversion tables of each format. Each table has string to phoneme entries and phoneme to string entries. The string to phoneme entries are used when converting OUT of that format, and the phoneme to string entries are used when converting IN (so you can recognise phonemes you don't support and convert them to something else). By default, a tuple of the form (string,phoneme) will create entries in BOTH directions; one-directional entries are created via (string,phoneme,False) or (phoneme,string,False). The makeDic function checks the keys are unique.

First parameter is always a description of the format, then come the phoneme entries as described above, then any additional settings:

stress_comes_before_vowel (default False means any stress mark goes AFTER the affected vowel; set to True if the format requires stress placed before)

word_separator (default same as phoneme_separator) phoneme_separator (default " ") clause_separator (default newline)

(For a special case, clause_separator can also be set to a function. If that happens, the function will be called whenever lexconvert needs to output a list of (lists of words) in this format. See bbcmicro for an example function clause_separator)

safe_to_drop_characters (default False, can be a string of safe characters or True = all; controls warnings when unrecognised characters are found)

approximate_missing (default False) - if True, makeDic will attempt to compensate for missing phonemes by approximating them to others, instead of warning about them. This is useful for American codes that can't cope with all the British English phonemes. (Approximation is done automatically anyway in the case of variant phonemes; approximate_missing adds in some additional approximations - see comments in code)

cleanup_regexps (default none) - optional list of (search,replace) regular expressions to "clean up" after converting each word INTO this format cleanup_func (default none) - optional special-case function to pass result through after cleanup_regexps

cvtOut_regexps (default none) - optional list of (search,replace) regular expressions to "clean up" before starting to convert OUT of this format cvtOut_func (default none) - optional special-case function to pass through before any cvtOut_regexps

inline_format (default "%s") the format string for printing a word with --phones or --phones2phones (can be used to put markup around each word) (can also be a function taking the phonetic word and returning the resulting string, e.g. bbcmicro)

output_is_binary (default False) - True if the output is almost certainly unsuitable for a terminal; will cause lexconvert to refuse to print phonemes unless its standard output is redirected to a file or pipe (affects the --phones and --phones2phones options)

inline_header (default none) text to print first when outputting from --phones or --phones2phones inline_footer (default none) text to print last inline_oneoff_header (default none) text to print before inline_header on the first time only

lex_filename - filename of a lexicon file. If this is not specified, there is no support for writing a lexicon in this format: there can still be READ support if you define lex_read_function to open the lexicon by itself, but otherwise the format can be used only with --phones and --phones2phones.

lex_entry_format - format string for writing each (word, pronunciation) entry to the lexicon file. This is also needed for lexicon-write support.

lex_header, lex_footer - optional strings to write at the beginning and at the end of the lexicon file (can also be functions that take the open file as a parameter, e.g. for bbcmicro; lex_footer is allowed to close the file if it needs to do something with it afterwards)

lex_word_case - optional "upper" or "lower" to force a particular case for lexicon words (not pronunciations - they're determined by the table). The default is to allow words to be in either case.

lex_type (default "") - used by the --formats option when summarising the support for each format

lex_read_function - Python function to READ the lexicon file and return a (word,phonemes) list. If this is not specified, there's no read support for lexicons in this format (but there can still be write support - see above - and you can still use --phones and --phones2phones). If lex_filename is specified then this function will be given the open file as a parameter.

def mainopt_try(i): 
2023def mainopt_try(i):
2024   """*<format> [<pronunciation>]
2025Convert input from <format> into eSpeak and try it out.
2026(Requires the 'espeak' command.)
2027E.g.: python lexconvert.py --try festival h @0 l ou1
2028 or: python lexconvert.py --try unicode-ipa '\\u02c8\\u0279\\u026adn\\u0329' (for Unicode put '\\uNNNN' or UTF-8)"""
2029   format = sys.argv[i+1]
2030   if not format in lexFormats: return "No such format "+repr(format)+" (use --formats to see a list of formats)"
2031   for phones in getInputText(i+2,"phonemes in "+format+" format",'maybe'):
2032      espeak = convert(phones,format,'espeak')
2033      w = os.popen("espeak -x","w")
2034      getBuf(w).write(markup_inline_word("espeak",espeak)+as_utf8('\n')) # separate process each item for more responsiveness from the console (sending 'maybe' to getInputText means won't lose efficiency if not read from console)

* [] Convert input from into eSpeak and try it out. (Requires the 'espeak' command.) E.g.: python lexconvert.py --try festival h @0 l ou1 or: python lexconvert.py --try unicode-ipa '\u02c8\u0279\u026adn\u0329' (for Unicode put '\uNNNN' or UTF-8)

def mainopt_trymac(i): 
2036def mainopt_trymac(i):
2037   """*<format> [<pronunciation>]
2038Convert phonemes from <format> into Mac and try it using the Mac OS 'say' command"""
2039   format = sys.argv[i+1]
2040   if not format in lexFormats: return "No such format "+repr(format)+" (use --formats to see a list of formats)"
2041   for resp in getInputText(i+2,"phonemes in "+format+" format",'maybe'):
2042      mac = convert(resp,format,'mac')
2043      toSay = markup_inline_word("mac",mac)
2044      print(as_printable(toSay))
2045      w = os.popen(macSayCommand()+" -v Vicki","w")
2046      getBuf(w).write(toSay) # Need to specify a voice because the default voice might not be able to take Apple phonemes.  Vicki has been available since 10.3, as has the 'say' command (previous versions need osascript, see Gradint's code)

* [] Convert phonemes from into Mac and try it using the Mac OS 'say' command

def mainopt_trymac_uk(i): 
2048def mainopt_trymac_uk(i):
2049   """*<format> [<pronunciation>]
2050Convert phonemes from <format> and try it with Mac OS British voices (see --mac-uk for details)"""
2051   assert sys.version_info[0]==2, "--trymac-uk has not been tested with Python 3, I don't want to risk messing up your system files, please use Python 2"
2052   format = sys.argv[i+1]
2053   if not format in lexFormats: return "No such format "+repr(format)+" (use --formats to see a list of formats)"
2054   for resp in getInputText(i+2,"phonemes in "+format+" format",'maybe'):
2055     macuk = convert(resp,format,'mac-uk')
2056     m = MacBritish_System_Lexicon("",os.environ.get("MACUK_VOICE","Daniel"))
2057     try:
2058      try: m.speakPhones(macuk.split())
2059      finally: m.close()
2060     except KeyboardInterrupt:
2061      sys.stderr.write("Interrupted\n")

* [] Convert phonemes from and try it with Mac OS British voices (see --mac-uk for details)

def mainopt_phones(i): 
2063def mainopt_phones(i):
2064   """*<format> [<words>]
2065Use eSpeak to convert text to phonemes, and then convert the phonemes to format 'format'.
2066E.g.: python lexconvert.py --phones unicode-ipa This is a test sentence.
2067Set environment variable PHONES_PIPE_COMMAND to an additional command to which to write the phones as well as standard output.  (If standard input is a terminal then this will be done separately after each line.)
2068(Some commercial speech synthesizers do not work well when driven entirely from phonemes, because their internal format is different and is optimised for normal text.)
2069Set format to 'all' if you want to see the phonemes in ALL supported formats."""
2070   format = sys.argv[i+1]
2071   if format=="example": return "The 'example' format cannot be used with --phones; try --convert, or did you mean --phones festival" # could allow example anyway as it's basically Festival, but save confusion as eSpeak might not generate the same phonemes if our example words haven't been installed in the system's eSpeak.  (Still allow it to be used in --try etc though.)
2072   if not format in lexFormats and not format=="all": return "No such format "+repr(format)+" (use --formats to see a list of formats)"
2073   hadOneoff = False
2074   for response in getInputText(i+2,"text",'maybe'):
2075    response = pipeThroughEspeak(as_utf8(response).replace(u'\u2032'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8('')).replace(u'\u00b4'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8('')).replace(u'\u02b9'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8('')).replace(u'\u00b7'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8(''))) # (remove any 2032 and b7 pronunciation marks before passing to eSpeak)
2076    if not as_utf8('\n') in response.rstrip() and as_utf8('command') in response: return response.strip() # 'bad cmd' / 'cmd not found'
2077    if format=="all": formats = sorted(k for k in lexFormats.keys() if not k=="example")
2078    else: formats = [format]
2079    for format in formats:
2080       def out(doOneoff=True):
2081          if len(formats)>1: writeFormatHeader(format)
2082          if doOneoff: getBuf(sys.stdout).write(as_utf8(checkSetting(format,"inline_oneoff_header")))
2083          getBuf(sys.stdout).write(as_utf8(checkSetting(format,"inline_header")))
2084          output_clauses(format,convert(parseIntoWordsAndClauses("espeak",response),"espeak",format))
2085          getBuf(sys.stdout).write(as_utf8(checkSetting(format,"inline_footer")))
2086          print("")
2087          sys.stdout.flush() # in case it's being piped
2088       out(not hadOneoff) ; hadOneoff = True
2089       if os.environ.get("PHONES_PIPE_COMMAND",""):
2090          o,sys.stdout = sys.stdout,os.popen(os.environ["PHONES_PIPE_COMMAND"],'w')
2091          out()
2092          sys.stdout = o

* [] Use eSpeak to convert text to phonemes, and then convert the phonemes to format 'format'. E.g.: python lexconvert.py --phones unicode-ipa This is a test sentence. Set environment variable PHONES_PIPE_COMMAND to an additional command to which to write the phones as well as standard output. (If standard input is a terminal then this will be done separately after each line.) (Some commercial speech synthesizers do not work well when driven entirely from phonemes, because their internal format is different and is optimised for normal text.) Set format to 'all' if you want to see the phonemes in ALL supported formats.

def mainopt_ruby(i): 
2094def mainopt_ruby(i):
2095   """*<format> [<words>]
2096Like --phones but outputs the result as HTML RUBY markup, with each word's pronunciation symbols placed above the corresponding English word.
2097E.g.: python lexconvert.py --ruby unicode-ipa This is a test sentence.
2098This option is made more complicated by the fact that different versions of eSpeak may space the phoneme output differently, for example when handling numbers; if your eSpeak version is not recognised then all numbers are unannotated. Anyway you are advised not to rely on this option working with the new development NG versions of eSpeak. If the version you have behaves unexpectedly, words and phonemes output might lose synchronisation. However this option is believed to be stable when used with simple text and the original eSpeak.
2099You can optionally set the RUBY_GRADINT_CGI environment variable to the URL of an instance of Gradint Web Edition to generate audio links for each word.  If doing this in a Web Adjuster filter, see comments in the lexconvert source for setup details."""
2100   # htmlFilter with --htmlText of course.  Set separator to two newlines and copy the generated 'h5a' function (from a manual run or the lexconvert source) into Adjuster's headAppend option (but don't expect HTML5 audio to work from Adjuster's submitBookmarklet option; pronunciation links will take you off the page if it doesn't).
2101   # Use double newlines as single newlines are used in the h5a script; adding that script via bookmarklet doesn't always run it
2102   format = sys.argv[i+1]
2103   if format=="example": return "The 'example' format cannot be used with --ruby; did you mean festival?" # as above
2104   elif format=="all": return "The --phones all option cannot be used with --ruby" # (well you could implement it if you want but the resulting ruby would be quite unwieldy)
2105   if not format in lexFormats: return "No such format "+repr(format)+" (use --formats to see a list of formats)"
2106   text = as_utf8(getInputText(i+2,"text")).replace(u'\u2019'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8("'")).replace(u'\u2032'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8("'")).replace(u'\u00b4'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8("'")).replace(u'\u02b9'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8("'")).replace(u'\u00b7'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8('')).replace(u'\u00a0'.encode('utf-8'),as_utf8(' '))
2107   # eSpeak's basic idea of an alphabetical word (most versions?) -
2108   wordRegexps = [r"(?:[A-Z]+['?-])*(?:(?:(?<![A-z.])(?:[A-z]\.)+[A-z](?![A-z.]))|[A-Z]+[a-z](?![A-z])|[A-Z][A-Z]+(?![a-z][A-z])|[A-Z]?(?:[a-z]['?-]?)+|[A-Z])"]
2109   # A dot, when not part of an elipses, followed by a letter is pronounced "dot", and two of them are pronounced "dot dot":
2110   wordRegexps.append(r"(?<!\.\.)\.(?=[A-z])|(?<!\.)\.(?=\.[A-z])")
2111   # ! followed by a letter is pronounced "exclamation", and .! is "dotexclamation"; @ symbols similarly; copyright
2112   atEtc = u"(?:[@!:]|\u00a9)*".encode('utf-8')
2113   wordRegexps.append(as_utf8(r"\.?[!@]+(?=[A-z])|(?<![A-z])@")+atEtc+as_utf8("(?![A-z])|")+unichr(0xa9).encode('utf-8')+atEtc)
2114   # : between numbers if NOT followed by 2 digits:
2115   wordRegexps.append(r"(?<![A-z]):(?![A-z]|[0-9][0-9])")
2116   # - between numbers
2117   wordRegexps.append(r"(?<=[0-9])-(?=[0-9])")
2118   # TODO: if you paste in (e.g.) CJK characters, eSpeak will say "symbol-symbol-symbol" etc, but this is not accounted for by the above regexp so it'll go onto following words.
2119   vLine = espeak_version_line()
2120   if "1.45." in vLine:
2121      # This seems to work in eSpeak 1.45:
2122      # (TODO: test leading 0s & leading decimal)
2123      # a number of 4 digits or less (with any number of digits after the decimal point) is grouped as 1 word:
2124      wordRegexps.append(r"(?<![0-9])[0-9]{1,4}(?:\.[0-9]+)?(?!,?[0-9])")
2125      # and a number of 1 to 3 digits with any number of 000 or ,000 groups, with optional decimal point followed by any number of digits, OR when placed before an integer number of 3-digit groups, is grouped as 1 word:
2126      wordRegexps.append(r"[0-9]{1,3}(?:,?000)*(?:\.[0-9]+)?,?(?=(?:,?[0-9]{3,3})*,?(?:[^0-9]|$))")
2127      text2 = text
2128   elif "1.48." in vLine:
2129      # In eSpeak 1.48 the groups are smaller.
2130      # Decimal point and everything after it = individual
2131      wordRegexps.append(r"(?<=[0-9])\.(?=[0-9])")
2132      for places in range(25): # TODO: really want unbounded, but (?<=...) is fixed-length
2133         wordRegexps.append(r"(?<=[0-9]\."+"[0-9]"*places+r")[0-9]")
2134      # Number with a leading dot grouped as 1 word:
2135      wordRegexps.append(r"(?<![0-9])\.[0-9]+")
2136      # TODO: leading 0s (0000048 goes to 0 000 048)
2137      # For normal numbers:
2138      # A null string w. 3 or 6 digits to go and digits b4 shld match for 'thousand', 'million' (unless 3+ digits are leading 0s, or fewer than 3 leading 0s and whole thing begins with a 0, or it's part of a decimal expansion, in which case different rules apply, but (?<=...) must be fixed-length, so we need another one of these awful loops) :
2139      for prevDigits in range(10):
2140         for beforeThat in ["^",r"[^.0-9,]"]: # beginning of string, or something OTHER than a decimal point / num
2141            wordRegexps.append(r"(?<="+beforeThat+"[1-9]"+"[0-9,]"*prevDigits+r")(?<!,)(?<!000)(?# empty string )(?=(?:,?(?:[0-9]{3,3}))+(?:[^0-9]|$))")
2142      # 1-9 (not 0) with 2, 5 or 8 etc digits to go = "N-hundred-and" :
2143      wordRegexps.append(r"[1-9](?=[0-9][0-9](?:,?(?:[0-9]{3,3}))*(?:[^0-9]|$))")
2144      # + 0 with 2 digits to go when preceded by digits = "and", as long as followed by at least one non-0:
2145      wordRegexps.append(r"(?<=[0-9,])0(?=(?:[0-9][1-9]|[1-9][0-9])(?:[^0-9,]|$))")
2146      # 1 or 2 digits with 0,3,6.. to go = "seventy-six" or whatever, as long as they're not both 0 :
2147      wordRegexps.append(r"(?:0[1-9]|[1-9][0-9]?)(?=(?:,?(?:[0-9]{3,3}))*(?:[^0-9]|$))")
2148      # 0 by itself (not preceded by digits) = "nought" :
2149      wordRegexps.append(r"(?<![0-9])0(?=[^0-9]|$)")
2150      wordRegexps.insert(0,"(?<=[^A-Za-z0-9_-])(?:of|on|in|that|with|for|was) (?:the|a)(?= )")
2151      wordRegexps.insert(0,"(?:Of|On|In|That|With|For|Was) (?:the|a)(?= )")
2152      wordRegexps.insert(0,"(?<=[^A-Za-z0-9_-])not a(?= )")
2153      wordRegexps.insert(0,"(?<=[^A-Za-z0-9_-])(?:some|that) one(?= )")
2154      wordRegexps.insert(0,"(?:Some|That) one(?= )")
2155      text2 = text
2156   else: text2 = re.sub(r"\.?[0-9]+","",text) # unknown eSpeak version: don't annotate the numbers
2157   response = pipeThroughEspeak(text2)
2158   if not as_utf8('\n') in response.rstrip() and as_utf8('command') in response: return response.strip() # 'bad cmd' / 'cmd not found'
2159   gradint_cgi = os.environ.get("RUBY_GRADINT_CGI","")
2160   if gradint_cgi:
2161      linkStart,linkEnd = lambda w:maybe_bytes('<a href="',w)+maybe_bytes(gradint_cgi,w)+maybe_bytes('?js=[[',w)+w.replace(maybe_bytes('%',w),maybe_bytes('%25',w)).replace(maybe_bytes('&',w),maybe_bytes('%26',w))+maybe_bytes(']]&jsl=en" onclick="return h5a(this);">',w), '</a>'
2162      print(r"""<script><!-- // HTML5-audio function
2163function h5a(link) {
2164 if (document.createElement) {
2165   var ae = document.createElement('audio');
2166   if (ae.canPlayType && function(s){return s!="" && s!="no"}(ae.canPlayType('audio/mpeg'))) {
2167     ae.setAttribute('src', link.href);
2168     ae.play(); return false;
2169   } else if (ae.canPlayType && function(s){return s!="" && s!="no"}(ae.canPlayType('audio/ogg'))) {
2170     ae.setAttribute('src', link.href+"&filetype=ogg");
2171     ae.play(); return false; }
2172 } return true; }
2173//--></script>""")
2174   else: linkStart,linkEnd = lambda w:maybe_bytes("",w), ""
2175   rubyList = []
2176   for clause in parseIntoWordsAndClauses("espeak",response):
2177      for w in clause:
2178         converted = convert(w,"espeak",format)
2179         if not converted: continue # e.g. a lone _:_:
2180         m = markup_inline_word(format,converted)
2181         rubyList.append(linkStart(w)+m.replace(maybe_bytes("&",m),maybe_bytes("&amp;",m)).replace(maybe_bytes("<",m),maybe_bytes("&lt;",m))+maybe_bytes(linkEnd,w))
2182   rubyList.reverse() # so can pop() left-to-right order
2183   # Write out re.sub ourselves, because (1) some versions of the library (e.g. on 2.7.12) try to do some things in-place, and we're using previous-context regexps that aren't compatible with previous things having been already <ruby>'ified, and (2) if we match a 0-length string, re.finditer won't ALSO return a non-0 length match starting in the same place, and we want both (so we're using wordRegexps as a list rather than an | expression)
2184   matches = {}
2185   debug = False # if True, will add ruby title=(index of the regexp that matched)
2186   debugCount = 0
2187   for r in wordRegexps:
2188      for match in re.finditer(maybe_bytes(r,text),text):
2189         matches[(match.start(),match.end())] = debugCount
2190      debugCount += 1
2191   i = 0 ; r = []
2192   def cmpFunc(a,b):
2193      (s1,e1),(s2,e2) = a,b
2194      if s1<s2: return -1
2195      if s1>s2: return 1
2196      if e1>e2: return -1
2197      if e1<e2: return 1
2198      return 0
2199   for start,end in sorted(list(matches.keys()),cmpFunc):
2200      if start<i: continue # overlap??
2201      r.append(text[i:start])
2202      if start==end: m = "&nbsp;"
2203      else: m = text[start:end].replace(maybe_bytes("&",text),maybe_bytes("&amp;",text)).replace(maybe_bytes("<",text),maybe_bytes("&lt;",text))
2204      try: rt = rubyList.pop()
2205      except: rt = "ERROR" # we've lost synchronisation
2206      if debug: title = as_utf8(" title=")+as_utf8(str(matches[(start,end)]))
2207      else: title = as_utf8("")
2208      r.append(as_utf8("<ruby")+title+as_utf8("><rb>")+m+as_utf8("</rb><rt>")+rt+as_utf8("</rt></ruby>"))
2209      i = end
2210   r.append(text[i:])
2211   while rubyList: # oops, lost synchronisation the other way (TODO: show this per-paragraph? but don't call eSpeak too many times if processing many short paragraphs)
2212      r.append(as_utf8("<ruby><rb>ERROR</rb><rt>")+rubyList.pop()+as_utf8("</rt></ruby>"))
2213   out = as_utf8("").join(r)
2214   if not out.endswith(as_utf8("\n")): out += as_utf8("\n")
2215   getBuf(sys.stdout).write(out)

* [] Like --phones but outputs the result as HTML RUBY markup, with each word's pronunciation symbols placed above the corresponding English word. E.g.: python lexconvert.py --ruby unicode-ipa This is a test sentence. This option is made more complicated by the fact that different versions of eSpeak may space the phoneme output differently, for example when handling numbers; if your eSpeak version is not recognised then all numbers are unannotated. Anyway you are advised not to rely on this option working with the new development NG versions of eSpeak. If the version you have behaves unexpectedly, words and phonemes output might lose synchronisation. However this option is believed to be stable when used with simple text and the original eSpeak. You can optionally set the RUBY_GRADINT_CGI environment variable to the URL of an instance of Gradint Web Edition to generate audio links for each word. If doing this in a Web Adjuster filter, see comments in the lexconvert source for setup details.

def pipeThroughEspeak(inpt): 
2217def pipeThroughEspeak(inpt):
2218   "Writes inpt to espeak -q -x (in chunks if necessary) and returns the result"
2219   assert type(inpt)==bytes
2220   bufsize = 8192 # careful not to set this too big, as the OS might limit it (TODO can we check?)
2221   ret = []
2222   while len(inpt) > bufsize:
2223      splitAt = inpt.rfind('\n',0,bufsize)+1
2224      if not splitAt: # no newline, try to split on space
2225         splitAt = inpt.rfind(' ',0,bufsize)+1
2226         if not splitAt:
2227            sys.stderr.write("Note: had to split eSpeak input and couldn't find a newline or space to do it on\n")
2228            splitAt = bufsize
2229      response = pipeThroughEspeak(inpt[:splitAt])
2230      if not '\n' in response.rstrip() and 'command' in response: return response.strip() # 'bad cmd' / 'cmd not found'
2231      ret.append(response) ; inpt=inpt[splitAt:]
2232   try: w,r=os.popen4("espeak -q -x",bufsize=bufsize) # Python 2
2233   except AttributeError: # Python 3
2234      import subprocess
2235      proc=subprocess.Popen(['espeak','-q','-x'],stdin=subprocess.PIPE,stdout=subprocess.PIPE)
2236      w = proc.stdin
2237      r = None
2238   if r:
2239      getBuf(w).write(inpt) ; w.close()
2240      r = getBuf(r).read()
2241   else: # Python 3
2242      w.write(inpt)
2243      out,err=proc.communicate()
2244      r = as_utf8("")
2245      if out: r += out
2246      if err: r += err
2247   return as_utf8("\n").join(ret) + r

Writes inpt to espeak -q -x (in chunks if necessary) and returns the result

def espeak_version_line(): 
2249def espeak_version_line(): return os.popen("espeak -h 2>&1").read().strip().split("\n")[0]
def writeFormatHeader(format): 
2251def writeFormatHeader(format):
2252   "Writes a header for 'format' when outputting in all formats.  Assumes the output MIGHT end up being more than one line."
2253   global writeFormatHeader_called
2254   if writeFormatHeader_called: print("")
2255   print(format)
2256   print('-'*len(format))
2257   writeFormatHeader_called = True

Writes a header for 'format' when outputting in all formats. Assumes the output MIGHT end up being more than one line.

writeFormatHeader_called = False
def mainopt_check_variants(i): 
2260def mainopt_check_variants(i):
2261   # undocumented (won't appear in help text)
2262   groups = {}
2263   for k,v in lexFormats['espeak'].items():
2264      if type(k)==str:
2265         intV = int(v)
2266         if not intV in consonants:
2267            groups.setdefault(intV,[]).append((v,k))
2268   i = groups.items() ; i.sort()
2269   for k,v in i:
2270      if len(v)==1: continue
2271      v.sort()
2272      while True:
2273         print("Group "+str(k))
2274         es = os.popen("espeak -x","w")
2275         getBuf(es).write(as_utf8('\n').join([markup_inline_word("espeak",w) for _,w in v]))
2276         del es
2277         if not int(str(input("Again? 1/0: "))): break
def mainopt_check_for_similar_formats(i): 
2279def mainopt_check_for_similar_formats(i):
2280   # undocumented (won't appear in help text)
2281   items = lexFormats.items() ; r = []
2282   while items:
2283      k1,dic1 = items[0]
2284      for k2,dic2 in items[1:]:
2285         diff = 0
2286         for kk,vv in dic1.items():
2287            if not type(kk)==int: continue
2288            if kk==syllable_separator: continue
2289            if not dic2.get(kk,"!"+vv)==vv: diff += 1
2290         r.append((diff,k1,k2))
2291      items = items[1:]
2292   r.sort() ; had = set()
2293   for diffs,format1,format2 in r:
2294      if format1 in had and format2 in had: continue
2295      had.add(format1) ; had.add(format2)
2296      if "names" in had: break
2297      print(str(diffs)+" phoneme differences between "+format1+" and "+format2)
def festival_group_stress(pronunc): 
2299def festival_group_stress(pronunc):
2300   "Special-case cleanup_func for the Festival format"
2301   # TODO: do we ever need to add extra consonants to the
2302   # previous group instead of the next group?  (not sure
2303   # what difference it makes to the synthesis, but it
2304   # might make the entry a bit more readable)
2305   groups = [] ; thisGroup = [[],'0',False] # phon,stress,complete
2306   for phon in pronunc.split():
2307      if phon in ['0','1','2']:
2308         if groups and phon >= groups[-1][1]:
2309            groups[-1][1]=phon
2310         continue
2311      thisGroup[0].append(phon)
2312      if phon[:1] in 'aeiou@':
2313         thisGroup[2]=True
2314         groups.append(thisGroup)
2315         thisGroup = [[],'0',False]
2316   if thisGroup[0]: groups.append(thisGroup)
2317   if len(groups)>=2 and not groups[-1][2]:
2318      groups[-2][0] += groups[-1][0]
2319      del groups[-1]
2320   return "("+' '.join(("(("+' '.join(g[0])+') '+g[1]+")") for g in groups)+")"

Special-case cleanup_func for the Festival format

def mainopt_convert(i): 
2322def mainopt_convert(i):
2323   """*<from-format> <to-format>
2324Convert a user lexicon (generally from its default filename; if this cannot be found then lexconvert will tell you what it should be).
2325E.g.: python lexconvert.py --convert festival cepstral"""
2326   fromFormat = sys.argv[i+1]
2327   toFormat = sys.argv[i+2]
2328   if fromFormat==toFormat: return "Cannot convert a lexicon to its own format (that could result in it being truncated)"
2329   if toFormat=="mac-uk": return "Cannot permanently save a Mac-UK lexicon; please use the --mac-uk option to read text"
2330   if toFormat=="example": return "Cannot overwrite the built-in example lexicon"
2331   for f in [fromFormat,toFormat]:
2332      if not f in lexFormats: return "No such format "+repr(f)+" (use --formats to see a list of formats)"
2333   try:
2334      fname=getSetting(toFormat,"lex_filename")
2335      getSetting(toFormat,"lex_entry_format") # convert_user_lexicon will need this
2336   except KeyError: fname = None
2337   if not fname: return "Write support for lexicons of format '%s' not yet implemented (need at least lex_filename and lex_entry_format); try using --phones or --phones2phones options instead" % (toFormat,)
2338   if toFormat=="espeak":
2339      assert fname=="en_extra", "If you changed eSpeak's lex_filename in the table you also need to change the code below"
2340      if os.system("mv en_extra en_extra~ && (grep \" // \" en_extra~ || true) > en_extra"): sys.stderr.write("Warning: en_extra not found, making a new one\n(espeak compile will probably fail in this directory)\n") # otherwise keep the commented entries, so can incrementally update the user lexicon only
2341      outFile=open(fname,"a", encoding='utf-8')
2342   else:
2343      l = 0
2344      try:
2345         f = open(fname, encoding='utf-8')
2346         l = getBuf(f).read()
2347         del f
2348      except: pass
2349      assert not l, "File "+replHome(fname)+" already exists and is not empty; are you sure you want to overwrite it?  (Delete it first if so)" # (if you run with python -O then this is ignored, as are some other checks so be careful)
2350      outFile=open(fname,"w", encoding='utf-8')
2351   print ("Writing %s lexicon entries to %s file %s" % (fromFormat,toFormat,fname))
2352   try: convert_user_lexicon(fromFormat,toFormat,outFile)
2353   except Message:
2354     print (" - error, deleting "+fname)
2355     os.remove(fname) ; raise

* Convert a user lexicon (generally from its default filename; if this cannot be found then lexconvert will tell you what it should be). E.g.: python lexconvert.py --convert festival cepstral

def mainopt_festival_dictionary_to_espeak(i): 
2357def mainopt_festival_dictionary_to_espeak(i):
2358   """<location>
2359Convert the Festival Oxford Advanced Learners Dictionary (OALD) pronunciation lexicon to eSpeak.
2360You need to specify the location of the OALD file in <location>,
2361e.g. for Debian festlex-oald package: python lexconvert.py --festival-dictionary-to-espeak /usr/share/festival/dicts/oald/all.scm
2362or if you can't install the Debian package, try downloading http://ftp.debian.org/debian/pool/non-free/f/festlex-oald/festlex-oald_1.4.0.orig.tar.gz, unpack it into /tmp, and do: python lexconvert.py --festival-dictionary-to-espeak /tmp/festival/lib/dicts/oald/oald-0.4.out
2363In all cases you need to cd to the eSpeak source directory before running this.  en_extra will be overwritten.  Converter will also read your ~/.festivalrc if it exists.  (You can later incrementally update from ~/.festivalrc using the --convert option; the entries from the system dictionary will not be overwritten in this case.)  Specify --without-check to bypass checking the existing eSpeak pronunciation for OALD entries (much faster, but makes a larger file and in some cases compromises the pronunciation quality)."""
2364   try: festival_location=sys.argv[i+1]
2365   except IndexError: return "Error: --festival-dictionary-to-espeak must be followed by the location of the festival OALD file (see help text)"
2366   try: open(festival_location, encoding='utf-8')
2367   except: return "Error: The specified OALD location '"+festival_location+"' could not be opened"
2368   try: open("en_list", encoding='utf-8')
2369   except: return "Error: en_list could not be opened (did you remember to cd to the eSpeak dictsource directory first?"
2370   convert_system_festival_dictionary_to_espeak(festival_location,not '--without-check' in sys.argv,not os.system("test -e ~/.festivalrc"))

Convert the Festival Oxford Advanced Learners Dictionary (OALD) pronunciation lexicon to eSpeak. You need to specify the location of the OALD file in , e.g. for Debian festlex-oald package: python lexconvert.py --festival-dictionary-to-espeak /usr/share/festival/dicts/oald/all.scm or if you can't install the Debian package, try downloading http://ftp.debian.org/debian/pool/non-free/f/festlex-oald/festlex-oald_1.4.0.orig.tar.gz, unpack it into /tmp, and do: python lexconvert.py --festival-dictionary-to-espeak /tmp/festival/lib/dicts/oald/oald-0.4.out In all cases you need to cd to the eSpeak source directory before running this. en_extra will be overwritten. Converter will also read your ~/.festivalrc if it exists. (You can later incrementally update from ~/.festivalrc using the --convert option; the entries from the system dictionary will not be overwritten in this case.) Specify --without-check to bypass checking the existing eSpeak pronunciation for OALD entries (much faster, but makes a larger file and in some cases compromises the pronunciation quality).

def mainopt_syllables(i): 
2372def mainopt_syllables(i):
2373   """[<words>]
2374Attempt to break 'words' into syllables for music lyrics (uses espeak to determine how many syllables are needed)"""
2375   # As explained on mainopt_ruby's help text, espeak -x output can't be relied on to always put a space between every input word.  Rather than try to guess what espeak is going to do, here we simply put a newline after every input word instead.  This might affect eSpeak's output (so not recommended for mainopt_ruby), but it should be OK for just counting the syllables.  (Also, the assumption that the input words have been taken from song lyrics usefully rules out certain awkward punctuation cases.)
2376   for txt in getInputText(i+1,"word(s)",'maybe'):
2377      words=txt.split()
2378      response = pipeThroughEspeak(as_utf8('\n').join(as_utf8(w) for w in words).replace(as_utf8("!"),as_utf8("")).replace(as_utf8(":"),as_utf8("")).replace(as_utf8("."),as_utf8("")))
2379      if not as_utf8('\n') in response.rstrip() and as_utf8('command') in response: return response.strip() # 'bad cmd' / 'cmd not found'
2380      rrr = response.split(as_utf8("\n"))
2381      print (" ".join([hyphenate(word,sylcount(convert(line,"espeak","example"))) for word,line in zip(words,filter(lambda x:x,rrr))]))
2382      sys.stdout.flush() # in case piped

[] Attempt to break 'words' into syllables for music lyrics (uses espeak to determine how many syllables are needed)

def wordSeparator(format): 
2384def wordSeparator(format):
2385   """Returns the effective word separator of format (remembering that it defaults to same as phoneme_separator"""
2386   return checkSetting(format,"word_separator",checkSetting(format,"phoneme_separator"," "))

Returns the effective word separator of format (remembering that it defaults to same as phoneme_separator

def mainopt_phones2phones(i): 
2388def mainopt_phones2phones(i):
2389   """*<format1> <format2> [<phonemes in format1>]
2390Perform a one-off conversion of phonemes from format1 to format2 (format2 can be 'all' if you want)""" # If format1 is 'example' and you don't specify phonemes, we take the words from the example lexicon.  But don't say that in the help string because it might confuse the issue about phonemes being optional on the command line and prompted for if not specified and stdin is not piped in all formats other than 'example'.
2391   format1,format2 = sys.argv[i+1],sys.argv[i+2]
2392   if not format1 in lexFormats: return "No such format "+repr(format1)+" (use --formats to see a list of formats)"
2393   if not format2 in lexFormats and not format2=="all": return "No such format "+repr(format2)+" (use --formats to see a list of formats)"
2394   if format1=="example" and len(sys.argv)<=i+3:
2395     if stdin_is_terminal(): txt=""
2396     else: txt=getBuf(sys.stdin).read() # and it might still be ""
2397     if txt: parseIntoWordsAndClauses(format1,txt)
2398     else: clauses=[[x[1]] for x in getSetting('example','lex_read_function')()]
2399   else: clauses = parseIntoWordsAndClauses(format1,getInputText(i+3,"phonemes in "+format1+" format"))
2400   if format2=="all": formats = sorted(k for k in lexFormats.keys() if not k=="example")
2401   else: formats = [format2]
2402   for format2 in formats:
2403     if len(formats)>1: writeFormatHeader(format2)
2404     getBuf(sys.stdout).write(as_utf8(checkSetting(format2,"inline_header")))
2405     output_clauses(format2,convert(clauses,format1,format2))
2406     getBuf(sys.stdout).write(as_utf8(checkSetting(format2,"inline_footer"))) ; print("")

* [] Perform a one-off conversion of phonemes from format1 to format2 (format2 can be 'all' if you want)

def parseIntoWordsAndClauses(format, phones): 
2408def parseIntoWordsAndClauses(format,phones):
2409   "Returns list of clauses, each of which is a list of words, assuming 'phones' are in format 'format'"
2410   wordSep = checkSetting(format,"word_separator") # don't use wordSeparator() here - we're splitting, not joining, so we don't want it to default to phoneme_separator
2411   clauseSep = checkSetting(format,"clause_separator","\n")
2412   def s(sep):
2413      if sep==" ": return None # " " means ANY whitespace (TODO: document this?)
2414      else: return maybe_bytes(sep,phones)
2415   if clauseSep and type(clauseSep) in [bytes,unicode]:
2416      clauses = phones.split(s(clauseSep))
2417   else: clauses = [phones]
2418   for i in range(len(clauses)):
2419      if wordSep: clauses[i]=clauses[i].split(s(wordSep))
2420      else: clauses[i] = [clauses[i]]
2421      clauses[i] = list(filter(lambda x:x, clauses[i]))
2422   return list(filter(lambda x:x,clauses))

Returns list of clauses, each of which is a list of words, assuming 'phones' are in format 'format'

def mainopt_mac_uk(i): 
2424def mainopt_mac_uk(i):
2425   """<from-format> [<text>]
2426Speak text in Mac OS 10.7+ British voices while using a lexicon converted in from <from-format>. As these voices do not have user-modifiable lexicons, lexconvert must binary-patch your system's master lexicon; this is at your own risk! (Superuser privileges are needed the first time. A backup of the system file is made, and all changes are restored on normal exit but if you force-quit then you might need to restore the backup manually. Text speaking needs to be under lexconvert's control because it usually has to change the input words to make them fit the available space in the binary lexicon.) By default the Daniel voice is used; Emily or Serena can be selected by setting the MACUK_VOICE environment variable."""
2427   # If you have xterm etc, then text will also be printed, with words from the altered lexicon underlined.
2428   assert sys.version_info[0]==2, "--mac-uk has not been tested with Python 3, I don't want to risk messing up your system files, please use Python 2"
2429   fromFormat = sys.argv[i+1]
2430   if not fromFormat in lexFormats: return "No such format "+repr(fromFormat)+" (use --formats to see a list of formats)"
2431   lex = get_macuk_lexicon(fromFormat)
2432   try:
2433      for line in getInputText(i+2,"text",True):
2434         m = MacBritish_System_Lexicon(line,os.environ.get("MACUK_VOICE","Daniel"))
2435         try: m.readWithLex(lex)
2436         finally: m.close()
2437   except KeyboardInterrupt:
2438      sys.stderr.write("Interrupted\n")

[] Speak text in Mac OS 10.7+ British voices while using a lexicon converted in from . As these voices do not have user-modifiable lexicons, lexconvert must binary-patch your system's master lexicon; this is at your own risk! (Superuser privileges are needed the first time. A backup of the system file is made, and all changes are restored on normal exit but if you force-quit then you might need to restore the backup manually. Text speaking needs to be under lexconvert's control because it usually has to change the input words to make them fit the available space in the binary lexicon.) By default the Daniel voice is used; Emily or Serena can be selected by setting the MACUK_VOICE environment variable.

class Counter: 
2440class Counter(object):
2441    "A simple class with two static members, count and subcount, for use by the consonant(), vowel() and other() functions"
2442    c=sc=0

A simple class with two static members, count and subcount, for use by the consonant(), vowel() and other() functions

c = 53
sc = 0
def other(): 
2443def other():
2444    "Used by Phonemes() when creating something that is neither a vowel nor a consonant, e.g. a stress mark"
2445    Counter.c += 1 ; Counter.sc=0 ; return Counter.c

Used by Phonemes() when creating something that is neither a vowel nor a consonant, e.g. a stress mark

consonants = {9, 10, 11, 12, 16, 17, 18, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 36, 41, 42, 43, 44, 45}
mainVowels = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 13, 14, 15, 19, 20, 21, 28, 30, 37, 39, 40}

def variant(): 
2456def variant():
2457    "Used by Phonemes() when creating a variant of the just-defined vowel/consonant/etc"
2458    Counter.sc += 1
2459    while str(Counter.sc).endswith('0'): Counter.sc += 1
2460    return 0, float('%d.%d' % (Counter.c,Counter.sc))
2461    # the 0 is so we can say _, name = variant()
2462    # so as to get some extra indentation

Used by Phonemes() when creating a variant of the just-defined vowel/consonant/etc

def ifset(var, a, b=''): 
2464def ifset(var,a,b=""):
2465   "Checks the environment variable var; if it is set (non-empty), return a, otherwise return b.  Used in LexFormats to create tables with variations set by the environment."
2466   import os
2467   if os.environ.get(var,""): return a
2468   else: return b

Checks the environment variable var; if it is set (non-empty), return a, otherwise return b. Used in LexFormats to create tables with variations set by the environment.

def speakjet(symbol, opcode): 
2470def speakjet(symbol,opcode):
2471   "Special-case function for the Speakjet table"
2472   assert type(opcode)==int
2473   if ifset('SPEAKJET_BINARY',1):
2474      assert not ifset('SPEAKJET_SYM',1), "Cannot set both SPEAKJET_SYM and SPEAKJET_BINARY"
2475      return chr(opcode)
2476   else: return ifset('SPEAKJET_SYM',symbol,str(opcode))

Special-case function for the Speakjet table

def makeDic(doc, *args, **kwargs): 
2478def makeDic(doc,*args,**kwargs):
2479    "Make a dictionary with a doc string, default-bidirectional mappings and extra settings; see LexFormats for how this is used."
2480    assert type(doc)==str, "doc must be a string"
2481    d = {} ; duplicates = set()
2482    for a in args:
2483        assert type(a)==tuple and (len(a)==2 or len(a)==3)
2484        k=a[0]
2485        if k in d: duplicates.add(k)
2486        v=a[1]
2487        assert (type(k) in [bytes,unicode] and type(v) in [int,float]) or (type(v) in [bytes,unicode] and type(k) in [int,float]), "Wrong types "+repr(a)+" (did you forget a _, before calling variant() or something?)"
2488        d[k] = v
2489        if type(k)==unicode: d[as_utf8(k)] = v
2490        if len(a)==3: bidir=a[2]
2491        else: bidir=True
2492        if bidir:
2493            # (k,v,True) = both (k,v) and (v,k)
2494            if v in d: duplicates.add(v)
2495            d[v] = k
2496    assert not duplicates, " Duplicate key(s) in "+repr(doc)+": "+", ".join((repr(dup)+"".join(" (="+g+")" for g,val in globals().items() if val==dup)) for dup in sorted(list(duplicates)))+". Did you forget a ,False to suppress bidirectional mapping?" # by the way, Python does not detect duplicate keys in {...} notation - it just lets you overwrite
2497    missing = [l for l in (list(consonants)+list(mainVowels)) if not l in d]
2498    # did_approx = False
2499    if missing and 'approximate_missing' in kwargs:
2500      for miss,approxTo in [
2501          # TODO: put this table somewhere else?
2502          # (If the thing on the right is just 1 item, we could make the thing on the left a variant of it.  But that might not be a good idea unless they're really very close, since if it's a variant then the substitution is done without warning even if approximate_missing is not set.)
2503          (a_as_in_ago, [u_as_in_but]),
2504          (a_as_in_air, [e_as_in_them,r]),
2505          (ear, [e_as_in_eat,u_as_in_but]),
2506          (oor_as_in_poor, [close_to_or]), # TODO: ,r?
2507          (a_as_in_ah,[a_as_in_apple]), # this seems to be missing in some American voices (DecTalk, Keynote, SAM); TODO: is this the best approximation we can do?
2508          ]:
2509        if miss in missing and all(x in d for x in approxTo):
2510          d[miss]=maybe_bytes(kwargs.get("phoneme_separator"," "),d[approxTo[0]]).join(d[x] for x in approxTo)
2511          # did_approx = True
2512          missing.remove(miss)
2513    # if did_approx: doc="(approx.) "+doc # and see also the code in makeVariantDic.  Commenting out because this is misleading: the formats where we didn't do a did_approx might also contain approximations of some kind.  Incidentally there are some British English voices that need approximate_missing (e.g. Apollo 2)
2514    d[("settings","doc")] = doc
2515    if missing:
2516       import sys ; sys.stderr.write("WARNING: Some non-optional vowels/consonants are missing from "+repr(doc)+"\nThe following are missing: "+", ".join("/".join(g for g,val in globals().items() if val==m) for m in missing)+"\n")
2517    for k,v in kwargs.items(): d[('settings',k)] = v
2518    assert type(d.get(('settings','cleanup_regexps'),[]))==list, "cleanup_regexps must be a list" # not one tuple
2519    assert type(d.get(('settings','cvtOut_regexps'),[]))==list, "cvtOut_regexps must be a list" # not one tuple
2520    wsep = d.get(('settings','word_separator'),None)
2521    psep = d.get(('settings','phoneme_separator'),' ')
2522    if not wsep==None: assert not wsep in d, "word_separator duplicates with a key in "+repr(doc)
2523    if not psep==None: assert not psep in d, "phoneme_separator duplicates with a key (did you forget to change the default, or to add a ,False somewhere?) in "+repr(doc)
2524    global lastDictionaryMade ; lastDictionaryMade = d
2525    return d

Make a dictionary with a doc string, default-bidirectional mappings and extra settings; see LexFormats for how this is used.

def makeVariantDic(doc, *args, **kwargs): 
2526def makeVariantDic(doc,*args,**kwargs):
2527    "Like makeDic but create a new 'variant' version of the last-made dictionary, modifying some phonemes and settings (and giving it a new doc string) but keeping everything else the same.  Any list settings (e.g. cleanup_regexps) are ADDED to by the variant; other settings and phonemes are REPLACED if they are specified in the variant.  If you don't want subsequent variants to inherit the changes made by this variant, add noInherit=True to the keyword args."
2528    global lastDictionaryMade
2529    ldmOld = lastDictionaryMade
2530    toUpdate = lastDictionaryMade.copy()
2531    global mainVowels,consonants
2532    oldV,oldC = mainVowels,consonants
2533    mainVowels,consonants = [],[] # so makeDic doesn't complain if some vowels/consonants are missing
2534    if 'noInherit' in kwargs:
2535       noInherit = kwargs['noInherit']
2536       del kwargs['noInherit']
2537    else: noInherit = False
2538    d = makeDic(doc,*args,**kwargs)
2539    if noInherit: lastDictionaryMade = ldmOld
2540    mainVowels,consonants = oldV,oldC
2541    # if toUpdate[("settings","doc")].startswith("(approx.) ") and not d[("settings","doc")].startswith("(approx.) "): d[("settings","doc")]="(approx.) "+d[("settings","doc")] # TODO: always?
2542    for k,v in toUpdate.items():
2543       if type(v)==list and k in d: d[k] = v+d[k]
2544    toUpdate.update(d) ; return toUpdate

Like makeDic but create a new 'variant' version of the last-made dictionary, modifying some phonemes and settings (and giving it a new doc string) but keeping everything else the same. Any list settings (e.g. cleanup_regexps) are ADDED to by the variant; other settings and phonemes are REPLACED if they are specified in the variant. If you don't want subsequent variants to inherit the changes made by this variant, add noInherit=True to the keyword args.

def getSetting(formatName, settingName):

2546  "Gets a setting from lexFormats, exception if not there"
2547  return lexFormats[formatName][('settings',settingName)]

Gets a setting from lexFormats, exception if not there

def checkSetting(formatName, settingName, default=''): 
2548def checkSetting(formatName,settingName,default=""):
2549  "Gets a setting from lexFormats, default if not there"
2550  return lexFormats[formatName].get(('settings',settingName),default)

Gets a setting from lexFormats, default if not there

def getBuf(f):

2569   "Return a buffer to which bytes may be written, for Python 2 and 3 compatibility"
2570   try: return f.buffer # Python 3
2571   except AttributeError: return f # Python 2

Return a buffer to which bytes may be written, for Python 2 and 3 compatibility

def make_dictionary(sourceName, destName): 
2574def make_dictionary(sourceName,destName):
2575    "Uses lexFormats to make a mapping dictionary from a particular source format to a particular dest format, and also sets module variables for that particular conversion (TODO: put those module vars into an object in case someone wants to use this code in a multithreaded server)"
2576    global cached_sourceName,cached_destName,cached_dict
2577    if (sourceName,destName) == (cached_sourceName,cached_destName): return cached_dict
2578    source = lexFormats[sourceName]
2579    dest = lexFormats[destName]
2580    d = {}
2581    global dest_consonants ; dest_consonants = set()
2582    global dest_syllable_sep ; dest_syllable_sep = dest.get(syllable_separator,"")
2583    global implicit_vowel_before_NL
2584    implicit_vowel_before_NL = None
2585    for k,v in source.items():
2586      if type(k)==tuple: continue # settings
2587      if type(v) in [bytes,unicode]: continue # (num->string entries are for converting IN to source; we want the string->num entries for converting out)
2588      if not v in dest: v = int(v) # (try the main version of a variant)
2589      if not v in dest: continue # (haven't got it - will have to ignore or break into parts)
2590      assert type(k) in [bytes,unicode]
2591      d[k] = dest[v]
2592      if int(v) in consonants: dest_consonants.add(d[k])
2593      if int(v)==e_as_in_herd and (not implicit_vowel_before_NL or v==int(v)): # TODO: or u_as_in_but ?  used by festival and some other synths before words ending 'n' or 'l' (see usage of implicit_vowel_before_NL later)
2594        implicit_vowel_before_NL = d[k]
2595      d[as_utf8(k)] = d[k]
2596      try: d[as_unicode(k)] = d[k]
2597      except UnicodeDecodeError: pass
2598    try:
2599       if any(type(v)==unicode for v in d.values()): d,dest_consonants=dict((k,as_unicode(v)) for k,v in d.items()),set(as_unicode(v) for v in dest_consonants) # Python 2: if ANY dest are Unicode, make them ALL Unicode
2600    except UnicodeDecodeError: d,dest_consonants=dict((k,as_utf8(v)) for k,v in d.items()),set(as_utf8(v) for v in dest_consonants) # ... or make them ALL byte-strings if some were binary and not readable as UTF-8
2601    cached_sourceName,cached_destName,cached_dict=sourceName,destName,d
2602    return d

Uses lexFormats to make a mapping dictionary from a particular source format to a particular dest format, and also sets module variables for that particular conversion (TODO: put those module vars into an object in case someone wants to use this code in a multithreaded server)

warnedAlready = set()
def convert(pronunc, source, dest): 
2605def convert(pronunc,source,dest):
2606    "Convert pronunc from source to dest.  pronunc can be a string or a list; if a list then we'll recurse on each of the list elements and return a new list (this is meant for batch-converting clauses etc)"
2607    assert type(pronunc) in [bytes,unicode,list], type(pronunc)
2608    if source==dest: return pronunc # essential for --try experimentation with codes not yet supported by lexconvert
2609    if type(pronunc)==list: return [convert(p,source,dest) for p in pronunc]
2610    func = checkSetting(source,'cvtOut_func')
2611    if func: pronunc=func(pronunc)
2612    for s,r in checkSetting(source,'cvtOut_regexps'):
2613        pronunc=re.sub(maybe_bytes(s,pronunc),maybe_bytes(r,pronunc),pronunc)
2614    ret = [] ; toAddAfter = None
2615    dictionary = make_dictionary(source,dest)
2616    maxLen=max(len(l) for l in dictionary.keys())
2617    debugInfo=""
2618    separator = checkSetting(dest,'phoneme_separator',' ')
2619    safe_to_drop = checkSetting(source,"safe_to_drop_characters")
2620    while pronunc:
2621        for lettersToTry in range(maxLen,-1,-1):
2622            if not lettersToTry:
2623              if safe_to_drop==True: pass
2624              elif (not safe_to_drop) or not pronunc[:1] in maybe_bytes(safe_to_drop,pronunc) and not (pronunc[:1],debugInfo) in warnedAlready:
2625                 warnedAlready.add((pronunc[:1],debugInfo))
2626               #   sys.stderr.write("Warning: ignoring "+source+" character "+repr(pronunc[:1])+debugInfo+" (unsupported in "+dest+")\n")
2627              pronunc=pronunc[1:] # ignore
2628            elif pronunc[:lettersToTry] in dictionary:
2629                debugInfo=" after "+as_printable(pronunc[:lettersToTry])
2630                toAdd=dictionary[pronunc[:lettersToTry]]
2631                assert type(toAdd) in [bytes,unicode], type(toAdd)
2632                isStressMark=(toAdd and toAdd in [maybe_bytes(lexFormats[dest].get(primary_stress,''),toAdd),maybe_bytes(lexFormats[dest].get(secondary_stress,''),toAdd)])
2633                if toAdd==maybe_bytes(lexFormats[dest].get(syllable_separator,''),toAdd): pass
2634                elif isStressMark and not checkSetting(dest,"stress_comes_before_vowel"):
2635                    if checkSetting(source,"stress_comes_before_vowel"): toAdd, toAddAfter = maybe_bytes("",toAdd),toAdd # move stress marks from before vowel to after
2636                    else: # stress is already after, but:
2637                        # With Cepstral synth (and kana-approx), stress mark should be placed EXACTLY after the vowel and not any later.  Might as well do this for others also.
2638                        r=len(ret)-1
2639                        while ret[r] in dest_consonants or ret[r].endswith(maybe_bytes("*added",ret[r])): r -= 1 # (if that raises IndexError then the input had a stress mark before any vowel) ("*added" condition is there so that implicit vowels don't get the stress)
2640                        ret.insert(r+1,toAdd) ; toAdd=maybe_bytes("",toAdd)
2641                elif isStressMark and not checkSetting(source,"stress_comes_before_vowel"): # it's a stress mark that should be moved from after the vowel to before it
2642                    i=len(ret)
2643                    while i and (ret[i-1] in dest_consonants or ret[i-1].endswith(maybe_bytes("*added",ret[i-1]))): i -= 1
2644                    if i: i-=1
2645                    ret.insert(i,toAdd)
2646                    if dest_syllable_sep: ret.append(maybe_bytes(dest_syllable_sep,toAdd)) # (TODO: this assumes stress marks are at end of syllable rather than immediately after vowel; correct for Festival; check others; probably a harmless assumption though; mac-uk is better with syllable separators although espeak basically ignores them)
2647                    toAdd = maybe_bytes("",toAdd)
2648                # attempt to sort out the festival dictionary's (and other's) implicit_vowel_before_NL
2649                elif implicit_vowel_before_NL and ret and ret[-1] and toAdd in [maybe_bytes('n',toAdd),maybe_bytes('l',toAdd)] and ret[-1] in dest_consonants: ret.append(maybe_bytes(implicit_vowel_before_NL,toAdd)+maybe_bytes('*added',toAdd))
2650                elif len(ret)>2 and ret[-2].endswith(maybe_bytes('*added',ret[-2])) and toAdd and not toAdd in dest_consonants and not toAdd==dest_syllable_sep: del ret[-2]
2651                if toAdd:
2652                    # Add it, but if toAdd is multiple phonemes, try to put toAddAfter after the FIRST phoneme
2653                    if separator: toAddList=toAdd.split(separator)
2654                    else: toAddList = [toAdd] # TODO: won't work for formats that don't have a phoneme separator (doesn't really matter for eSpeak though)
2655                    ret.append(toAddList[0])
2656                    if toAddAfter and not toAddList[0] in dest_consonants:
2657                        ret.append(toAddAfter)
2658                        toAddAfter=None
2659                    ret += toAddList[1:]
2660                pronunc=pronunc[lettersToTry:]
2661                break
2662    if toAddAfter: ret.append(toAddAfter)
2663    if ret and ret[-1]==dest_syllable_sep: del ret[-1] # spurious syllable separator at end
2664    if not ret: ret = ""
2665    else: ret=maybe_bytes(separator,ret[0]).join(ret).replace(maybe_bytes('*added',ret[0]),maybe_bytes('',ret[0]))
2666    for s,r in checkSetting(dest,'cleanup_regexps'):
2667      ret=re.sub(maybe_bytes(s,ret),maybe_bytes(r,ret),ret)
2668    func = checkSetting(dest,'cleanup_func')
2669    if func: return func(ret)
2670    else: return ret

Convert pronunc from source to dest. pronunc can be a string or a list; if a list then we'll recurse on each of the list elements and return a new list (this is meant for batch-converting clauses etc)

def unicode_preprocess(pronunc): 
2672def unicode_preprocess(pronunc):
2673   "Special-case cvtOut_func for unicode-ipa: tries to catch \\uNNNN etc"
2674   if maybe_bytes("\\u",pronunc) in pronunc and not maybe_bytes('"',pronunc) in pronunc: # maybe \uNNNN copied from Gecko on X11, can just evaluate it to get the unicode
2675      # (NB make sure to quote the \'s if pasing in on the command line)
2676      try: pronunc=eval('u"'+pronunc+'"')
2677      except: pass
2678   else: # see if it makes sense as utf-8
2679      try: pronunc = pronunc.decode('utf-8')
2680      except: pass
2681   return pronunc

Special-case cvtOut_func for unicode-ipa: tries to catch \uNNNN etc

def ascii_braille_to_unicode(a): 
2683def ascii_braille_to_unicode(a):
2684  "Special-case cleanup_func for braille-ipa (set by braille-ipa if BRAILLE_UNICODE is set).  Converts Braille ASCII to Unicode dot patterns."
2685  d=dict(zip(list(" A1B'K2L@CIF/MSP\"E3H9O6R^DJG>NTQ,*5<-U8V.%[$+X!&;:4\\0Z7(_?W]#Y)="),[unichr(c) for c in range(0x2800,0x2840)]))
2686  return u''.join(d.get(c,c) for c in list(a))

Special-case cleanup_func for braille-ipa (set by braille-ipa if BRAILLE_UNICODE is set). Converts Braille ASCII to Unicode dot patterns.

def unicode_to_ascii_braille(u): 
2687def unicode_to_ascii_braille(u):
2688  d=dict(zip([unichr(c) for c in range(0x2800,0x2840)],list(" A1B'K2L@CIF/MSP\"E3H9O6R^DJG>NTQ,*5<-U8V.%[$+X!&;:4\\0Z7(_?W]#Y)=")))
2689  r=''.join(d.get(c,c) for c in list(as_unicode(u)))
2690  if r.startswith(",7") and r.endswith("7'"): r=r[2:-2]
2691  return r
def hiragana_to_katakana(u): 
2693def hiragana_to_katakana(u):
2694   "Special-case cleanup_func for kana-approx; converts all hiragana characters in unicode string 'u' into katakana if KANA_TYPE is set to anything beginning with a 'k'"
2695   assert type(u)==unicode
2696   if not os.environ.get("KANA_TYPE","").lower().startswith("k"): return u
2697   u = list(u)
2698   for i in xrange(len(u)):
2699      if 0x3041 <= ord(u[i]) <= 0x3096:
2700         u[i]=unichr(ord(u[i])+0x60)
2701   return u"".join(u)

Special-case cleanup_func for kana-approx; converts all hiragana characters in unicode string 'u' into katakana if KANA_TYPE is set to anything beginning with a 'k'

def espeak_probably_right_already(existing_pronunc, new_pronunc): 
2703def espeak_probably_right_already(existing_pronunc,new_pronunc):
2704    """Used by convert_system_festival_dictionary_to_espeak to compare a "new" pronunciation with eSpeak's existing pronunciation.  As the transcription from OALD to eSpeak is only approximate, it could be that our new pronunciation is not identical to the existing one but the existing one is actually correct; try to detect when this happens by checking if the pronunciations are the same after some simplifications."""
2705    if existing_pronunc==new_pronunc: return True
2706    def simplify(pronunc): return \
2707        pronunc.replace(maybe_bytes(";",pronunc),maybe_bytes("",pronunc)).replace(maybe_bytes("%",pronunc),maybe_bytes("",pronunc)) \
2708        .replace(maybe_bytes("a2",pronunc),maybe_bytes("@",pronunc)) \
2709        .replace(maybe_bytes("3",pronunc),maybe_bytes("@",pronunc)) \
2710        .replace(maybe_bytes("L",pronunc),maybe_bytes("l",pronunc)) \
2711        .replace(maybe_bytes("I2",pronunc),maybe_bytes("i:",pronunc)) \
2712        .replace(maybe_bytes("I",pronunc),maybe_bytes("i:",pronunc)).replace(maybe_bytes("i@",pronunc),maybe_bytes("i:@",pronunc)) \
2713        .replace(maybe_bytes(",",pronunc),maybe_bytes("",pronunc)) \
2714        .replace(maybe_bytes("s",pronunc),maybe_bytes("z",pronunc)) \
2715        .replace(maybe_bytes("aa",pronunc),maybe_bytes("A:",pronunc)) \
2716        .replace(maybe_bytes("A@",pronunc),maybe_bytes("A:",pronunc)) \
2717        .replace(maybe_bytes("O@",pronunc),maybe_bytes("O:",pronunc)) \
2718        .replace(maybe_bytes("o@",pronunc),maybe_bytes("O:",pronunc)) \
2719        .replace(maybe_bytes("r-",pronunc),maybe_bytes("r",pronunc))
2720    # TODO: rewrite @ to 3 whenever not followed by a vowel?
2721    if as_printable(simplify(existing_pronunc))==as_printable(simplify(new_pronunc)): return True # almost the same, and festival @/a2 etc seems to be a bit ambiguous so leave it alone

Used by convert_system_festival_dictionary_to_espeak to compare a "new" pronunciation with eSpeak's existing pronunciation. As the transcription from OALD to eSpeak is only approximate, it could be that our new pronunciation is not identical to the existing one but the existing one is actually correct; try to detect when this happens by checking if the pronunciations are the same after some simplifications.

def parse_festival_dict(festival_location): 
2723def parse_festival_dict(festival_location):
2724    "For OALD; yields word,part-of-speech,pronunciation"
2725    ret = []
2726    for line in open(festival_location, encoding='utf-8'):
2727        line=line.strip()
2728        if "((pos" in line: line=line[:line.index("((pos")]
2729        if line.startswith('( "'): line=line[3:]
2730        line=line.replace('"','').replace('(','').replace(')','')
2731        try:
2732            word, pos, pronunc = line.split(None,2)
2733        except ValueError: continue # malformed line
2734        if pos not in ['n','v','a','cc','dt','in','j','k','nil','prp','uh']: continue # two or more words
2735        yield (word.lower(), pos, pronunc)

For OALD; yields word,part-of-speech,pronunciation

class Message(builtins.Exception): 
2737class Message(Exception): pass

Common base class for all non-exit exceptions.

Inherited Members
builtins.Exception
Exception
builtins.BaseException
with_traceback
args
def convert_system_festival_dictionary_to_espeak( festival_location, check_existing_pronunciation, add_user_dictionary_also): 
2738def convert_system_festival_dictionary_to_espeak(festival_location,check_existing_pronunciation,add_user_dictionary_also):
2739    "See mainopt_festival_dictionary_to_espeak"
2740    os.system("mv en_extra en_extra~") # start with blank 'extra' dictionary
2741    if check_existing_pronunciation: os.system("espeak --compile=en") # so that the pronunciation we're checking against is not influenced by a previous version of en_extra
2742    outFile=open("en_extra","w", encoding='utf-8')
2743    print ("Reading dictionary lists")
2744    wordDic = {} ; ambiguous = {}
2745    el = open("en_list", encoding='utf-8')
2746    for line in filter(lambda x:x.split() and not re.match(maybe_bytes(r'^[a-z]* *\$',x),x),getBuf(el).read().split(as_utf8('\n'))): ambiguous[line.split()[0]]=ambiguous[line.split()[0]+as_utf8('s')]=True # this stops the code below from overriding anything already in espeak's en_list.  If taking out then you need to think carefully about words like "a", "the" etc.
2747    for word,pos,pronunc in parse_festival_dict(festival_location):
2748        pronunc=pronunc.replace("i@ 0 @ 0","ii ou 2 ").replace("i@ 0 u 0","ii ou ") # (hack for OALD's "radio"/"video"/"stereo"/"embryo" etc)
2749        pronunc=pronunc.replace("0","") # 0's not necessary, and OALD sometimes puts them in wrong places, confusing the converter
2750        if word in ['mosquitoes']: continue # OALD bug (TODO: any others?)
2751        if word in wordDic and not wordDic[word]==(pronunc,pos):
2752            ambiguous[as_utf8(word)] = True
2753            del wordDic[word] # better not go there
2754        if not as_utf8(word) in ambiguous:
2755            wordDic[word] = (pronunc, pos)
2756    toDel = []
2757    if check_existing_pronunciation:
2758        print ("Checking existing pronunciation")
2759        proc=os.popen("espeak -q -x -v en-rp > /tmp/.pronunc 2>&1","w")
2760        wList = []
2761    progressCount=0 ; oldPercent=-1
2762    itemList = list(wordDic.items())
2763    # Make sure it's NOT sorted, to ensure eSpeak doesn't
2764    # cache pronunciation of previous word when add suffix
2765    # (which can subtly change eSpeak's pronunciation in
2766    # some versions of eSpeak, leading to
2767    # Python 2/3 differences as Python 3 sorts by default) :
2768    itemList.sort()
2769    i0,i1 = itemList[:int(len(itemList)/2)],itemList[int(len(itemList)/2):]
2770    itemList = []
2771    while i0 or i1:
2772       if i0: itemList.append(i0.pop())
2773       if i1: itemList.append(i1.pop())
2774    for word,(pronunc,pos) in itemList:
2775        if check_existing_pronunciation:
2776            percent = int(progressCount*100/len(wordDic))
2777            if not percent==oldPercent: sys.stdout.write(str(percent)+"%\r") ; sys.stdout.flush()
2778            oldPercent=percent
2779            progressCount += 1
2780        if not re.match("^[A-Za-z]*$",word): # (some versions of eSpeak also OK with "-", but not all)
2781            # contains special characters - better not go there
2782            toDel.append(word)
2783        elif word.startswith("plaque") or word in "friday saturday sunday tuesday thursday yesterday".split():
2784            # hack to accept eSpeak's pl'ak instead of pl'A:k - order was reversed in the March 2009 draft
2785            toDel.append(word)
2786        elif word[-1]=="s" and word[:-1] in wordDic:
2787            # unnecessary plural (espeak will pick up on them anyway)
2788            toDel.append(word)
2789        elif word.startswith("year") or "quarter" in word: toDel.append(word) # don't like festival's pronunciation of those (TODO: also 'memorial' why start with [m'I])
2790        elif check_existing_pronunciation:
2791            getBuf(proc).write(as_utf8(word)+as_utf8("\n"))
2792            proc.flush() # so the progress indicator works
2793            wList.append(word)
2794    if check_existing_pronunciation:
2795        proc.close() ; print("")
2796        oldPronDic = {}
2797        tp = open("/tmp/.pronunc", encoding='utf-8')
2798        for k,v in zip(wList,getBuf(tp).read().split(as_utf8("\n"))): oldPronDic[k]=v.strip().replace(as_utf8(" "),as_utf8(""))
2799    for w in toDel: del wordDic[w]
2800    print ("Doing the conversion")
2801    lines_output = 0
2802    total_lines = 0
2803    not_output_because_ok = []
2804    items = list(wordDic.items()) ; items.sort() # necessary because of the hacks below which check for the presence of truncated versions of the word (want to have decided whether or not to output those truncated versions before reaching the hacks)
2805    for word,(pronunc,pos) in items:
2806        total_lines += 1
2807        new_e_pronunc = convert(pronunc,"festival","espeak")
2808        if new_e_pronunc.count("'")==2 and not '-' in word: new_e_pronunc=new_e_pronunc.replace("'",",",1) # if 2 primary accents then make the first one a secondary (except on hyphenated words)
2809        # TODO if not en-rp? - if (word.endswith("y") or word.endswith("ie")) and new_e_pronunc.endswith("i:"): new_e_pronunc=new_e_pronunc[:-2]+"I"
2810        unrelated_word = None
2811        if check_existing_pronunciation: espeakPronunc = oldPronDic.get(word,"")
2812        else: espeakPronunc = ""
